The proposal for a transitional period and the declaration that the British government will continue to contribute to the joint budget for 2014-2020 should be assessed positively. It seems that the issue of protecting the rights of EU citizens living in Great Britain will also find a suitable solution. Now the Union should take a step forward. Perhaps President Juncker should make a similar speech as the Prime Minister did. Besides, we in Poland have recently been worried more about the rights of our employees in France than the rights of Poles living in Great Britain. In general, the paradox of these negotiations is that the talks with the British about the free market and the movement of people and their rights take place in a situation where within the EU, under the slogan of combating social dumping, the desire for protectionism within the EU becomes more and more visible.

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: - Sir. Chairman! This week there were visits from Copenhagen in London. The Danish Minister of Business and Economy left with the Danish Governor and with him 20 CEOs from the largest Danish financial houses and pension funds. So what were they going to do in London? Yes, they should be in the fight to attract some of the 30,000 financial jobs currently on the way out of London to other parts of Europe. From all over Europe - Germany, France, the Netherlands, Sweden and everywhere else - the financial bosses are now in London to find out how to attract all these people. It seems that in some parts of the UK, people have found out that this is the wrong course to take and that they are paying the price for the consequences of what is happening. In the year and a half that has passed since Brexit, I have been shaken by the predictability of moving out into the swamp from the British side. I still need to hear what the British Government will do with the 759 agreements with 168 countries outside the EU that are to be renegotiated. How on earth have you imagined it would happen and when? What do you expect to happen? All of us who love Britain, and who follow closely, may wonder why there is so much chaos and that one does not soon find out what to line up. I hope that some kind of realism will soon creep into these Brexit negotiations, and I hope that the United Kingdom will find out so that you can get started on something realistic and in that way also be able to start those negotiations. about the future, which is so really necessary that British business and British society do not squabble.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Mr President, respect for the British people's sovereign and legitimate decision to leave the European Union is not compatible with blackmail, threats or punishment. The impasses and blockades of the negotiations resulting from contradictions of the great British and European capital are not unrelated to an agenda that aims to pervert, circumvent and, eventually, reverse the decision of the British people. The neoliberal nature of the forces at hand, the nature of the class of power on both sides of the negotiations is evident in the announced intention to maintain and deepen common policies, namely in the security, militaristic and response to the refugee crisis. In this context, it is essential to affirm the requirement that the rights of immigrants be guaranteed in negotiations, including Portuguese emigrants in the United Kingdom, their labor rights and other social rights, such as residence, equal treatment or access to public services , portability of social security benefits, family reunification or mutual recognition of academic diplomas and professional qualifications.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: – Mr President, I have to say that at some points this morning this debate has taken me back to my teaching days, where you used to get the occasional pupil who would behave so badly, as if they wanted to be thrown out of your lesson because they felt that way they were going to have an easy time and not have to do any work. I see some have bunked off early today.  So let’s say here that this is a serious setup. It is a serious negotiation, and we do want an ongoing relationship. Some of us would like the same one, but that is not on the table. So we have to ask whether walking away actually makes this a serious relationship. And no, it does not. Aiming and continuing to say that no deal is better than a bad deal, or no deal is okay, is not a serious outcome. And does all of that show to other countries that you want to be a trusted partner in future negotiations? No, it does not.  Let’s also be clear that paying what you promised to pay is not a punishment: it is also about keeping your word. (Applause from the centre)

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: - I would like to warn our British friends about what is going on now. They should not underestimate which opponent they are facing. This is a European elite that is out for revenge, for revenge, for some kind of punitive expedition; in any case, a strategy that saves time and allows the remain strategy to take wind. That's what's going on and that's why this whole procedure is slowly but surely turning into a kind of chaos right now. The parliamentary procedure that should have nothing to do with this as far as I am concerned - because it should simply be a settlement between two executive levels - is part of that. I have known Verhofstadt for 35 years. He is the right man to turn the Brexit procedure into chaos, with all kinds of sideways such as threatening the citizens, talking about money and talking about Northern Ireland. Don't let that happen. Have a good plan B, I say to our British friends: a good plan B for the independence of your country.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - President! In the Brexit negotiations, the European Union's primary task is to represent the interests of the 27 Member States. Above all, guaranteeing the rights of UK citizens on the basis of reciprocity and concluding a favorable free trade agreement. The goal is to leave with an agreed agreement. To do this, however, we must take into account the fair interests of the United Kingdom. Are we fair when we expect the jurisdiction of the Court of Justice of the European Union to continue to be accepted after withdrawal? Are we fair when we want to ban all pre-trade negotiations with third countries? With all this, I am representing the interests of the EU for twenty weeks, because if we want to punish the British for quitting because they have shattered some people's dreams of the European United States, we are on a dangerous path, because there will be no organized exit, no agreement and losers on both sides. .

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, this resolution merely states the obvious, that insufficient progress has been made on the three key issues before us. But I want to accentuate the positive, and I think Michel Barnier, Mr Verhofstadt and others have said that there are welcome developments in the British Prime Minister’s speech. Let me be very clear: on citizens’ rights, we can make progress because we have to. We cannot let people down. Some of the banter in this debate will frighten citizens who are listening to it. So on that issue, let us make progress. On the issue of the financial settlement, there is a solution and that the UK will meet and honour its commitments. They are an honourable nation and I believe they will do that. But let me be very frank. I am the first Member of the European Parliament from the Republic of Ireland to speak. I listened with great respect to my colleagues from Northern Ireland who spoke here. Nobody owns the peace process, but let us salute those who lost their lives for the peace process, those politicians and civil society actors on all sides who won peace so that my children do not see the violence of the past. Nobody, including this Parliament, wants to see that. But I would like to make this observation: we want things to remain the same as they are today on the island of Ireland after Brexit. That is why I say that we do need the United Kingdom to stay in the single market and the Customs Union. If that is not to be, then please tell me what will replace that. I want a solution. I am afraid I hear nothing from the UK side that will leave things as they are today, but we will welcome a proposal with open arms. Michel Barnier wants that too. In the negotiations, we will have to make progress on this issue. I cannot go back home to my constituents in Donegal, in Cavan, in Monaghan, in Louth, in Meath, in all of that constituency, and say that we are going to return to the borders of the past. I will not let that happen.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President!It is of interest to all of us that the Brexit negotiations are concluded with consistency and a sense of reality.For far too long, nothing has progressed substantially, and that is mainly down to the British side.Now there seems to be some movement in the matter.OK then!People are fed up with just talking - results are needed.Despite the willingness to make compromises, these compromises must not be at the expense of certain problem areas.There are two key points to be mentioned: Firstly, this is Ireland.We do not need new frontiers or a revival of the old conflicts.But above all, it is about the millions of EU citizens in the UK and Britons in the EU.This is about people who have planned their life on a completely different basis and who should not be disadvantaged or even discriminated because of that.That is what we have to focus on above all.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: - I think it is very important that we move forward with the Brexit negotiations.Lack of clarity creates uncertainty and that is not good for anyone: not for the United Kingdom, but also not for Europe.Indeed, it is important to be clear about the rights of EU citizens in the United Kingdom, about the financial obligations of the United Kingdom, across the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.But it is even more important to have a good Brexit agreement at the end of the day.Therefore a warm appeal not to want to keep the two phases artificially separated at all times.At the end of the ride, there will be one deal on the table and it will not consist of two parts.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, research has shown that in the event of a hard Brexit, the UK would lose half a million jobs whilst the EU would lose 1.2 million. Crucially, they say that these losses will not be evenly distributed, with Ireland being worst hit, suffering a relatively greater loss in both jobs and GDP than even the UK itself. This must be factored into any final outcome of the negotiations. Largely, today’s debate was positive, and just like the negotiations it must be about establishing a cooperative future – not about settling old scores, or, heaven forbid, opening new wounds. Today’s resolution offers hope in the context of Northern Ireland, where it speaks of Northern Ireland staying in some form in the internal market and Customs Union. I believe the majority of people in Northern Ireland who voted to remain would support today’s proposal, and it would fit in with Theresa May’s proposal to exclude any physical infrastructure at the border.  Those who represent Northern Ireland must be clear: do they want a hardening of the border, will they accept a harder border, or do they support a unique solution for Northern Ireland that will avoid a hardening of the border, maintain the travel area and uphold the Good Friday Agreement?

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Madam President, we knew from the outset that negotiations on Britain's departure from the European Union would not be easy at all.The main problem, however, is that the EU does not have an equal partner on the other side of the negotiating table.The British government is drowning in internal conflicts and the situation on the British political scene is very confusing.Prime Minister May is asking the EU for a creative solution, but it is not bringing anything to the negotiating table.Boris Johnson reiterates his lies about the mythical 350 million, and EU citizens in Britain and the British in the EU are still drowning in uncertainty about how it will be after Brexit with their rights.Citizens are once again forced to watch power and party games that can have a major impact on their lives and future.I agree that it is necessary to agree, but it is really high time to do it.Citizens must not be held hostage and we must not allow this to happen.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Madam President, as a politician I understand that political negotiations take time, that legal studies need to be conducted, that there are political games being played, and maybe I even understand that one side of the House wants to make a circus out of this. But, as a citizen, I must admit I am still completely lost as to what the British Government actually wants out of these negotiations. And I think this is deeply worrying. That is why I have two points to make to Theresa May, and I think she can clarify them tomorrow in her speech at the party congress: Finally, Madam Prime Minister, let us, and the millions of citizens who are waiting for this, know what the British Government actually wants out of these negotiations. And secondly – and this is also an important signal to send here from this European Parliament – never forget that there is still a way out of this mess. The strength of a leader is demonstrated not by stubbornness but by insight. You can still turn this around, Ms May. It is high time to do so!

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: - It's no credit to Mr Juncker that he just left the debate, but okay. Mr President, I visited England last week and the EU has made itself so impossible there that no one feels sympathy for Brussels anymore. Prime Minister May makes a neat proposal for a permanent residence permit for everyone who is now legally there and the EU immediately rejects it. She stated that a reasonable amount can be paid and the EU wants more, more, more. Any negotiation of a future free trade agreement will be rejected until London submits to this extortion. Mr President, where is our eternal gratitude for the country that has beaten the German spiked boot? Brussels wants to impress on British citizens that they have deeply insulted everyone here by voting in favor of leaving the EU, as if that were high treason. Brussels thinks it is okay to frustrate a British referendum. Tomorrow we will hear why Brussels also thinks it's okay to beat up Catalan voters. Mr President, the total moral bankruptcy of the EU cannot be clearer this week.

name: David McALLISTER
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! As someone who has both German and British citizenship, I continue to regret the developments since May 2016. I consider Brexit to be a historic mistake with grave consequences for the United Kingdom. There is nothing good about Brexit, absolutely nothing. But the British way - irrational as it may seem - is of course to be accepted. And that is why we should now - and this is what we in Parliament are campaigning for once again today - to strive for a proper and sensible separation and then a groundbreaking agreement on our future relations. Many previous speakers have already pointed out: Sufficient progress with regard to the divorce conditions has not yet been ascertained. The British side has to deliver on this. And even if some progress has been made through the speech in Florence, it remains Mrs May's task to create a little more clarity tomorrow at the British Conservative Congress. And then we have to see what begins in the next round of negotiations. Otherwise it won't work in October, as has already been mentioned several times. But it is also in our own interest that we organize future relations with the United Kingdom properly and that we continue to cultivate a strong economic and political partnership. Finally, I would like to express my thanks to Michel Barnier and his entire team. I think many of us here in this House feel that our European concerns are in the best of hands with you, dear Michel Barnier.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: - Madam President! After the Beatles split up, Paul McCartney wrote the song Too many people: "That was your first mistake, you took your lucky break and you broke it in two." That fits with Brexit. The British government seems to be slowly getting it: their referendum was their first mistake, and the euphoria of the Brexit supporters - finally lucky break! - has long since vanished. You broke it in two - consequences follow. The indivisibility of the internal market and the customs union, existing financial obligations and full recognition by the ECJ are non-negotiable. There is still no guarantee of reciprocity, equality and non-discrimination of the rights of EU citizens in the UK and of Britons in the EU. And this also for the children born after Brexit, because there are no first or second class family members. Ms. May, you could gamble yourself away. Also a Beatles song: We can work it out - written before the breakup: “Think of what you're saying. You can get it wrong and still you think that it's alright. Think what I am saying, we can work it out and get it straight, or say good night. " It is your decision.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - Mr Verhofstadt, together with others, has drawn up a resolution on Brexit and at the beginning of that text, fine words are said about the unity of the EU and the United Kingdom. For example, that EU citizens are also British citizens and that the European Parliament also represents British citizens. Subsequently, however, the text places all responsibility entirely unilaterally with the British. They must fully guarantee the rights of citizens. The British have full responsibility for the relationship between Northern Ireland and Ireland, and the British must first fully settle payment. If not, the negotiations will be suspended. So not a word on other mutually important topics, such as trade and fishing. Only one-sided Brussels demands and they can only have one goal, Mr President: never should the citizens of any Member State get it in the head and even think of wanting to leave the EU. Verhofstadt and his people want a fighting divorce. That only produces losers on both sides.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, Ireland needs these negotiations to work out more than any other country. Diplomacy is a bit like dating. If you want it to succeed, you need to be careful what you say. One thing you don’t say to your future partner if you want your relationship to work is that they would be a dwarf without you. That is what you said, Mr Verhofstadt, if you could come off your phone for a second.  Another thing you don’t do is run down their family, no matter how bad their brother or sister might be, even if they have a lower of opinion of them, you don’t run them down! Today, Manfred Weber did just that by demanding that Boris Johnson resign. I agree. I don’t like him, but it is the British people’s choice. You have made it harder today, Manfred!  Another thing you don’t do with your date is tell them you are in a hurry. Jean-Claude Juncker, you said you would not have much time to spend on this. Another thing you don’t do is make public what happens in the bedroom! You brought out what happened in private discussions.  We need this to work! We have been bitten by Europe on Lisbon and Nice and on bank debt. It is time to put your egos away, time to make this work, and time to stop insulting people that you ultimately want to work with you.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in this resolution, you demand that the British respect the free movement of individuals and respect the decisions of the European Court of Justice. We have understood that the European Union wants to make the British people pay for their legitimate desire for freedom and the return of their sovereignty. Because, let us remember what happened: barely after Article 50 of the Treaty was triggered, we saw an avalanche of warnings and threats from a European Union at bay. In reality, the European Union is afraid, afraid of seeing the United Kingdom do better outside the Union than inside, which, of course, could encourage other Member States to follow this path towards national sovereignty. The negotiations are a real blackmail, an unbearable blackmail, but Brexit will have had at least this merit: that of showing the true face of an undemocratic European Union and incapable of respecting the will of the peoples because we cannot negotiate with a gun on the temple.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: – Madam President, anyone following the relationship between the European Union and the United Kingdom since the Brexit vote will be struck by a number of factors. First of all, why is everything in slow motion? The Brexit referendum took place well over a year ago, yet the pace of discussions has been glacial. Second, the United Kingdom never seems to have believed that the EU 27 would preserve its unity. Indeed, the UK made a serious diplomatic effort to split that unity. This failed.  Third, the EU’s position was made very clear indeed in the Council mandate and in the various statements by Michel Barnier. Despite the clarity, the message never seems to get through. The UK side, when it responds, does so in vague all too often unfocused language or makes complaints of inflexibility or punishment. Fourth, the discussion in the UK itself seems to be entirely unaware of what the EU is saying. It is as if the UK has become another planet. From the outset, in the 1970s – and I was there – the UK never sought to understand what the EU was for. The attitude was entirely transactional. Equally England – and I mean England, and not the UK as a whole – has become intensely focused on itself, thereby making it very hard to see the EU as it is, a body of values.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Madam President, we were against Brexit, but the British people voted in favor. So, Mr President of the Commission, until 29 March 2019, the British remain members of the European Union, and it is your duty, as President of the Commission, to ensure that the legislation is fully applied. First of all concerning the rights of citizens, who, even before leaving the United Kingdom, are too often victims of discrimination; also concerning the fight against VAT fraud, since the UK has clearly become the hub of fraud generated by imports from China; finally concerning the situation in Gibraltar, which seems to have become a sieve for banking licenses and insurance captives. And then, a new element appeared recently: the “transition phase”. For once, I'm going to surprise you, I agree with Mr. Weber. We should not bring everything back to this transitional phase before it is even effective. The transition will be there when we come to an agreement: 1) on the terms of the divorce, and 2) on the terms of the future relationship. This is the correct sequencing. We have to stick to it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Madam President, Mr Juncker, Mr Barnier, colleagues, it is good that we are finally seeing some progress in the Brexit negotiations with the United Kingdom. In her speech, Ms May showed Britain's readiness to continue negotiations in a spirit of compromise. If we want to maintain our close relations with the United Kingdom after leaving the European Union, we need to move as soon as possible directly to an agreement that will enter into force after Brexit. This will reassure people, employers, the economy and markets. I believe that no one in Europe wants the economic turmoil of recent years to happen again. They are inevitable if the European Union does not reach a good, friendly and reasonable agreement with Britain. Let's stop talking about how Britain should be punished. This attitude is unconstructive and I would say stupid. Obviously, the United Kingdom has the good will to resolve the three important issues: citizens' rights, the Irish issue and the payment of what is due under treaties with the European Union. We cannot expect this payment if there is no good deal. I want to call for rationality, common sense, maintaining good relations. Britain must remain the European Union's best ally after Brexit.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, during these months of negotiations we have seen different positions, more or less harsh, but what we have not seen has been any progress. There is talk of the unity of Europe, of companies, of the rights of citizens, but, throughout this period, nothing, absolutely nothing, has been said about workers, the great forgotten of Brexit. I will give the example of the more than 12,000 Spanish border workers, who make up 27% of Gibraltar's workforce and whose jobs are in danger due to the lack of specification of their future status. In the area there is a social and economic interdependence that will be altered, altered, of course, for the worse, because nothing is said in the negotiations about how to protect the employment and conditions of the workers. All attempts to make Brexit more beneficial serve the economic interests of companies and markets and, once again, it is the workers who are threatened and helpless, being the last priority at the negotiating table.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Madam President! A year ago, it seemed that the British referendum and its consequences would be an existential problem for the entire European Union. Followers in other countries came forward. Today we can see that the Brexit shock has turned into a kind of shock therapy for Europe, because it has renewed the European Union's faith in its own future. On the other hand, the problem that the inhabitants of the British Isles created for themselves is fully revealed. You can sympathize, but we are primarily interested in securing the interests of Ireland, our citizens in the UK, and designing finances with the uncertainty that Brexit creates. That is why the strategy implemented by Michel Barnier in line with the guidelines of the Council and Parliament's resolution makes sense - first progress on these issues, and then talks on the future model of relations between the European Union and Great Britain. But there is no such premise, there is chaos on the other side. I would like to express my personal disappointment. I have the right to express this personal disappointment because in communist Poland in the underground, which posed some personal risk, I indicated Great Britain as a model of mature democracy. Mature, i.e. one that is resistant to demagogy and populism. Unfortunately, the British referendum was fake news and hence my disappointment, but I am also glad that the European Union as a whole has regained faith in its own future.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President Juncker, this morning the speech that Premier May gave in my city, Florence, a few days ago was evoked this morning: let me say that in Theresa May's speech in Florence, there was only Florence and no reassurance, at least on some important points. First: we have always affirmed that compliance with the Good Friday agreements must correspond to the integrity of the single market and the Customs Union, avoiding the creation of passages, from which goods without any control, capable of evading duties, can arrive in Europe customs at entry; secondly, I also believe that in the face of the British government's request for a transitional period, the European Union must certainly prove itself available. But a transition period is not a period without rules and will have to be based on all the current EU rules, including respect for the four fundamental freedoms. Two thousand years ago, Seneca wrote that "there is no favorable wind for the sailor who does not know where to go". Time goes by and we - and I think with us the British citizens too - would like to know which route Mrs May wants to follow.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, we have heard the usual ranting from UKIP and far-right colleagues fuelled by their diminishing testosterone levels. They state the obvious. They say they want a cliff edge, no deal and a complete withdrawal – what Kenneth Clarke called a calamitous act of national self-harm. Well, there is no surprise there: that’s what they want. Be clear about that, colleagues. That’s what they want. But I don't want that, and let me assure you that that’s not what a lot of British Conservatives want. We want to make progress. Ms May has signalled in Florence that she wants to move. Let’s speed this process up. This Parliament can play an important role in moving the deal forward. We are experienced in negotiating; we are experienced in reaching consensus and compromise. I would like to make one point about this resolution, which is the one point I do not agree with. It is really important that this Parliament urges Mr Barnier, the Commission and the Council to move forward with a parallel negotiation on some of the issues that the UK is signalling are important, on the principle that no deal is agreed until everything is agreed. That would open up channels of communication that would show goodwill and the willingness to go forward without digging our heels in and being just as stubborn and just as awkward as those gentlemen that I mentioned earlier. I’m not with them; I’m with this parliament, and I think that we could play a useful role here. Let’s get on and do so.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in barely 420 days, the divorce agreement, masterfully negotiated by Michel Barnier, should be adopted by the Twenty-Seven and voted on by our Parliament, which will have the last word. Now, 420 days before this crucial deadline, what do we see? That once again, a British political class, which is decidedly no more up to the stakes than it is of its own people, is concerned only with its own navel. His problem is not the future of Britain, otherwise it would have remained in Europe. Neither is its problem with the European Union, nor with a supposed supranational technocracy that only exists in their fantasies. No, the only obsession of this navel-blue and cynical political class is to hatch plans to retain or win circumstantial majorities within their own political parties. It doesn't matter if for that she has to lie, deny herself and betray herself by exciting if necessary some dangerous populists. We have to tell him "stop"! Those who believe, in Britain and elsewhere, that the future is to reject the other because one is too rich to be united and too proud to be fraternal, are deceiving their people. For it is not more wealth or independence that they will find at the end of the road, but more poverty and isolation. Dear British colleagues, you still have a few days to build up courage and stop this process which is meaningless. If you do not have this courage, then at least find clarity and stop your procrastination of which you are and will be the only victims. In is in, and out is out.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: - Madam President, Mr Barnier, Mr Verhofstadt! I have now conducted more than 40 negotiations with the Council on legislation and accompanied many trade agreements, but I have never seen situations like the one we are experiencing in the Brexit negotiations. I have never seen such unclear positions on the part of the negotiating partner. If I watch the party convention in Manchester now - who am I listening to? May, Johnson, Davidson, Mogg or Hammond? Total ambiguity, and that cannot be a serious basis for negotiations! We need clarity - internally for the negotiations between the EU and Great Britain, but also beyond! Last week in Geneva I went to see the WTO partners: We want to know how things are going with Great Britain and the EU. Here, too, we need clarity in a situation where the world trading system is already in a destabilized situation. And we also need for our trade contracts in the future z. B. with Australia clarity. So the urgent request to the British government: create clarity so that we can move forward! I think we can really say thank you to Mr Barnier and Mr Verhofstadt for the good cooperation. Cooperative and transparent - this is how we continue to work!

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I too would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt and his team for his good work and for the resolution before us today, and also to thank him for coming to Ireland two weeks ago, where he was well received as was Mr Barnier when he came to the PPE Bureau meeting in May and went to the North to see the position of the border. Thankfully – and I appreciate this very much – there is a determination to maintain the provisions of the Good Friday Agreement, the special circumstances of Northern Ireland, and a seamless border. Some progress has been made was in relation to a transition period. This has now been recognised, and I appreciate that. However, one thing I would say is that a transition period needs to be open-ended, with a target minimum length of maybe two years, without setting a maximum, because it is during that transition period that people will realise what Mr Barnier has said today and what has not been realised up till now: that the consequences, like the extraordinary complexity of the issue, have been underestimated. Given enough time, people will realise that, and then come to an arrangement that would be in the best interests of the EU and the best interests of the United Kingdom and of Ireland. The other point I would like to make is that an awful lot of speeches, even here today, have to be taken with a pinch of salt, because they are aimed at constituents back home. This is grandstanding. We need less of the public speeches and more engagement where it matters most – around the negotiating table. I think that, over a period of time, around the negotiating table, trust can be built and we can come to conclusions that are satisfactory to everybody. (Applause)

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Madam President, this morning we heard here Mister Farage's support for Catalan nationalism, and I think it is a deadly torpedo for the pro-independence cause of Catalonia, because there can be no worse friend, there can be no worse support in Europe and in the world to nationalism than that of Mister Farage, that of the extreme right. Ladies and gentlemen, Europe was built to overcome the wars between our countries; Europe was built to overcome nationalisms, and Brexit, as we are seeing today in this negotiation, is the expression of an old nationalism, it is the claim of an anachronistic independence. Today we are seeing it in a negotiation that is going to require a very long transition - as Mrs May has requested - a transition that we have to negotiate again. Ladies and gentlemen, the independence referendums are loaded by the devil: they are a ship full of citizen problems; they are a ship sailing to nowhere, most of the time. The flag of nationalism is independence, it is sovereignty. But sovereignty today is Europe: a stronger, more united and more democratic Europe, as Juncker and Macron say.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, first of all, I must say I deeply regret the decision of the UK to leave the EU. The UK in this way abandons a community of more than 500 million people, a community that has an essential role in the future of our continent and the world. The economic impact of that is just one small part of the problem, but it is an important one. Let me illustrate that in numbers: the UK, by leaving the single market, will make it complicated for its businesses to join and use the market of 450 million people, while the opposite way around this is just 65 million people.  In today’s interconnected and highly effective world, any uncertainty means job losses, lower wages and budget and investment problems. Unfortunately, for the time being, it seems to me that we are not on the way to reducing this uncertainty. The reason is that while the EU 27 has quite a clear negotiating position, it seems to me that the UK side of the negotiation table is trying to square a circle. We know that squaring a circle is not possible, and we have known that for more than 100 years.  It is time to act. It is important that we can move forward, and the recent speeches by the UK Prime Minister show the possibility to get improvement, but they must understand that there are some limits and some conditions that must be fulfilled. This is the only way to reach progress and reduce the cost and uncertainty of Brexit. The cost will be there, but it depends on whether it is high or low. I hope it will be low!

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, (off the microphone) at least part of it seems to understand or begin to understand that one cannot have access to the single market and at the same time build walls against EU workers; as the English say, you can't have cake and then eat it. The breeders of Brexit, who have all disappeared here, come to terms with the reality that will inevitably be hard for Great Britain and change their tone but we continue on our path: we ask Theresa May for concreteness and certainty on the conditions of withdrawal. I fully appreciate the position presented by Commissioner Barnier this morning. Parliament must make it clear: no delaying tactics, no transition without certainties. You don't play with people's lives. I think that the lives of citizens cannot be put in brackets, for a certain period of time, perhaps waiting to postpone the moment when British conservative politicians, who have often played for their mutual party positions, will be called to account for their mistakes. Ours is not a punitive attitude but the desire to achieve a result. But I see today and hear from the words of my colleagues a lot of fear to answer for the consequences of their choices.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Madam President, I would first like to say one thing about a mistake we must not make here in this Chamber: Mr Farage and his friends might be British, but they are not the representatives of Great Britain. (Applause)  Great Britain is much greater than that. They are loving the conflict and the tensions, and they are, for me, contradictory to what the United Kingdom is, and has been, for Europe. I think Brexit is a sad thing. It is not win-win; it is lose-lose. In the negotiations we need to be counterparts, but in the future we need to be partners. That means that this is time for negotiation more than agitation. We need the British Government to get its act together, and we need to secure the rights of citizens, secure a way to deal with the bill and proceed with the Irish issue. But in day-to-day life, regarding prosperity and our big challenges, we need to be serious about how we manage this divorce and create a new partnership.

name: Jens GEIER
text: - Madam President, President Juncker, Mr Barnier! In the spring of this year, OLAF, the European Union's anti-fraud office, uncovered customs fraud in Great Britain that was the result of systematic undervaluation. The damage to our budget - to the EU budget - amounts to almost two billion euros, a sum of which I do not know whether it will appear in the bills of the EU Commission on the closing costs of Brexit, and additional damage of EUR 3.2 billion in lost VAT for Member States. UK Customs know this and they are not doing anything about it because they are unable to. He has too few staff and he has been instructed by his government to direct the focus of the tasks to another body. I do not know whether the administrative recommendations made by OLAF have been followed up; a legal review does not take place. With this in mind, I believe that we need to pay very close attention to how controls at the Irish border are organized. We cannot tolerate the integrity of the European Union and the Customs Union being compromised by sloppy behavior by British Customs. I would ask you to pay close attention to this point and to ask for guarantees so that what is happening to us does not continue to happen to us, because the scandal is ongoing.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: – Madam President, it has been six months since Article 50: six months in which substantial progress could have been made on citizens’ rights, on the financial settlement, and on the Irish border issue; six months that could have paved the way for a meaningful conversation about our common future; six months in which bridges could have been built between those who voted to leave and those who would have preferred to remain. But all we have seen in the past six months is chaos: a Prime Minister who is so preoccupied with her own position that she cannot focus on these negotiations; a Foreign Secretary who is the main cause of the Prime Minister’s preoccupations; a House of Commons leader who said yesterday that the UK will take back control of its borders, its money and its laws in 2019, denying the idea of a transition period; David Davis, who first agreed to the sequencing of negotiations, but now cannot stop complaining about it; Michael Gove, who is too busy selling pigs’ ears to China to make any meaningful contribution to the process; and then Nigel Farage stands here in this House and demands a meaningful, intelligent conversation while even he himself has said that, if he does not Brexit his way, he will be forced to pick up a rifle. Well, good luck having an intelligent conversation with someone like that.  So please, our friends in London, be serious. Get your act together. Stop your party political games and come to the table as a serious, united and credible negotiating partner. All our citizens deserve that.  (Applause)

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Madam President, for reasons that were largely due to successive errors in economic policy and in the management of the European Union's refugee crisis, a majority of UK voters decided to leave this Union. The realization of that legitimate decision it has to be conducted with all transparency. Protecting the rights of European citizens and the future of the European project under the Treaties is an absolute priority. Portugal has a long tradition of bilateral cooperation with the United Kingdom. This cooperation has always been able to develop within the framework of the common membership of the European Union. Autonomy, identity and cooperation are pillars that do not cancel each other, but rather value each other. I use my country as an example to clarify the message that we must make clear in the European Parliament's resolution. We want to continue to cooperate with the UK. Nothing moves us against his people. But we must do so within the framework of the integrity of the European institutions and their values ​​and principles. With transparent and clear calendars. With guarantees of full respect for the rights of European citizens living in the United Kingdom. Ensuring the indivisibility and protection of the coherence and integrity of the European project. In short, we want a European project that remains strong and learns from the BREXIT experience so that the mistakes that led to it are not made again.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is time to take initiatives to make the European Union stronger and more attractive after Brexit. We need a serious debate on increasing the European Union 's own resources and funding new policies. And do not tell me that the taxpayers of your countries do not want to finance European policies, because I will answer you that David Cameron said the same and you saw what happened! There is no doubt that the City of London will remain a strong financial and shipping center after Brexit. However, we have an obligation to strengthen our comparative position in Frankfurt, Dublin, Paris and Piraeus, especially in terms of merchant shipping. Let us therefore combine the very good negotiation on the part of the European Union, which is in full swing, with the organization of a better future for the European Union of 27.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: - Madam President, it is now sixteen months since the British decided to leave the Union. Those who managed that exit dreamed of a cherry picking strategy: choosing the cherries they liked. They dreamed that, on the other side, in the European Union, there would be division and conflicting interests, but the reality, today, is that where there is confusion and division is in the British part and here we have been able to maintain unity around the process negotiation. This Parliament's resolution underlines this House's support for Mr Barnier's negotiating strategy. I join those who have seen this morning with surprise how the UKIP leader and the leader of the National Front group enthusiastically supported Catalonia's independence strategy. I just want to remind you to take note that these are two parties, two supremacist movements, among whose fundamental objectives is to remove their countries from the European Union, that union that the other twenty-seven want to maintain and strengthen.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: - Madam President! No one should be surprised that these negotiations on a divorce between the EU and the United Kingdom are going badly. Because it's a strange divorce. Nobody will move. It will remain 32 kilometers between Dover and Calais. Our future and our destiny are and remain intertwined. Britain will still live, but has, as it were, said that they want to move down to the basement, maybe live on the couch. I have been following trade negotiations in this House for 13 years. This is really exactly the same thing, but the opposite. Because in trade negotiations, everyone is a winner. It removes barriers to trade and borders that everyone benefits from, regardless of who gives in. But here we do the opposite. Here we negotiate what trade barriers and borders we should travel - a negotiation where everyone becomes a loser. The question is just how much. And we do not know, because the United Kingdom has no idea what trade barriers or borders it wants to impose. But to succeed, we must always have the same thing: a clear mandate and broad political support. The EU is a role model there. We have a clear mandate and the broadest overall support, but Britain needs to pull itself together. Because you do not even agree in the government on what you want to achieve, and even less does it seem clear that you have the parliament or the people with you. Pull yourself together!

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: - Madam President, citizens' rights and the Irish question are among the two main concerns. It is necessary to underline here, and it is a surprise, the weakness of the British government which does not seem to know what it wants, nor to take responsibility for the result of a referendum which it nevertheless wanted. This is the weakness of a disunited government, in which the irresponsible spoiled child Boris Johnson continues to crack down. The attitude of Mr Farage earlier, who spoke of Spain to avoid debate, is unspeakable. He cannot take responsibility for his electoral success, because he has plunged his people into disarray and into the unknown. The British people deserve better. As for you, Mr Barnier, Mr Chief Negotiator, I congratulate you on preserving the unity of the European Union and putting the interests of the citizens first, which should be the main concern of any politician. Continue down this path, because you really are, as they say in London, "the right man in the right place".

name: Carlos COELHO
text: - Madam President, on Brexit, three brief notes on clarity, on people and on speed. Clarity: we are late. Article 50 was launched more than six months ago and there is no real progress in the negotiations. This impasse does not benefit anyone. There is more time for media speeches than for making concrete proposals. We heard Theresa May in Florence, but we continue to ignore consequent concrete proposals. About people: there are five million citizens with a foreclosed future. Europeans living in the UK and British who chose another one of 27 countries. 400 thousand Portuguese live in an unacceptable limbo. There is an urgent need for the United Kingdom to commit to safeguarding the rights of resident European citizens. Violating Union law in a more or less disguised way and withdrawing rights would be intolerable. And about speed: that's why it's so important to decide and decide now. To preserve the rights of all European citizens and work towards a smooth transition. This implies the application of the acquis communautaire based on the four inseparable freedoms of movement. We need a good deal and the clock is ticking.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: - Madam President!As many have pointed out today, it is unfortunate that the fourth round of negotiations has not resulted in sufficient progress in terms of citizens' rights, the situation in Ireland and Northern Ireland and Britain's financial obligations within the EU.That is why it is good that we demand concrete progress in these areas.But at the same time: Why are we talking about the British as a united collective that made a well-informed choice when they voted in favor of Brexit?We know that is not the case.I, like my colleague Lavrilleux, for example, feel great sadness that the British are likely to leave.I also remember what Michel Barnier said when you started your work: 'Beware of hatred', you said."It will show up after a while."So let's keep a decent tone, while demanding results in the negotiations.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Madam President, Mr Barnier, six months after the enactment of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union, little progress has been made, but the confusion over the course of Brexit is great. The ambiguity in the European Union-UK relationship undermines its perspective and, above all, does not safeguard the interests of European citizens. 3.2 million European citizens currently live in the United Kingdom, of whom 63,000 are Greeks. It is our duty to provide them with security immediately, incorporating all the rights they enjoy, without substantially changing their position for them and their children. In the field of financial settlement, it is necessary to reach a compromise as soon as possible. There are countries like my homeland, Greece, which depend to a large extent on their economic development from funding from the Community budget. Commitments made by 28 Member States cannot be fulfilled by the 27 and the United Kingdom must fully comply with its budgetary commitments. Otherwise, the bill will be paid by the weakest and among them are the Greeks. Finally, in view of the Council Decision in November 2017 on the designation of the seats of the European bodies based in the United Kingdom, I would like to reiterate before the Plenary of the European Parliament, before the representatives of all the Member States, the request of Greece for the hosting of the headquarters of the European Medicines Agency in Athens. We have the infrastructure, we can provide the families of 900 employees with access to multilingual education, we can contribute to know-how. I call on you to give this opportunity to Greece, sending a strong message of equal opportunities in post-Brexit Europe.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam President, in Florence, Prime Minister May gave the best Remain speech never held. Ms May touched on a range of extremely important issues – terrorism, climate change, the refugee and migrant crisis, global free trade, organised crime and territorial aggression – issues so challenging, so dangerous and so complex that we can only solve them together. To put it bluntly, one could paraphrase Ms May’s speech like this: ‘you need now, more than ever, to work together – so I am leaving!’  Ms May was very concrete on what she does not want. She does not want a Norway model and she does not want a Canada model, but what does the British Government want? Nobody knows! All we get from Ms May is a desire, and I quote from the speech, for ‘a bold, new strategic, comprehensive framework that is unprecedented in breadth’. That sounds like something out of ‘Yes, Prime Minister’. Did Sir Humphrey write the Florence speech, one could ask?  How can we negotiate a workable Brexit agreement if the UK Government cannot state clearly what they want? Please, Prime Minister May: wake up, speak up! You owe it to your citizens. (Applause)

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! At the end of the debate, I would like to make it clear once again that this Parliament will today pass a resolution by a large majority, which is a logical consequence of the decision on Parliament's negotiating position of April this year. We are adopting this resolution with great unity because we want negotiations, because we are predictable and determined, and we have a clear position. This resolution takes sides - sides with the citizens, sides with the peace process in Ireland, sides with the taxpayers, sides with our legal, political and moral obligations. That must be the basis of negotiations, because we are committed to our common values, common law and common goals. All those shout today who do not want that, but who have always sided with the violation of the law, nationalism, extremism and mendacity as a political instrument of tactics and strategy. The majority of this Parliament stands on clear foundations. You know where you stand when you negotiate with us.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Madam President! I must admit that I fully sympathize with what I heard and in what form I heard - in this calm tone - from Mr Michel Barnier and also from Guy Verhofstadt. I must admit that I haven't heard Guy Verhofstadt in a long time without theatrical gestures, and that's what's very good. Two principles that you have mentioned and which convince me in particular: firstly, the former Member State of the European Union is not a Member State of the European Union, secondly, people are the most important, so we want to treat citizens of the United Kingdom in the European Union very kindly and normally on condition that there is reciprocity - and this approach also suits me very well. I would also like to draw your attention to the issue of university students. Well, the provisions so far provide that after Brexit we will not recognize diplomas automatically. I urge us to recognize British diplomas, and that university diplomas, degrees and titles obtained in the European Union should be recognized in Great Britain.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: – Madam President, some in the UK Government want to blame the EU for the lack of progress in negotiations, but of course it was the UK Government who, knowing the consequences, triggered Article 50 – and now, six months after triggering Article 50, the UK Government still doesn’t know what it wants. It is spending all its time negotiating, or rather fighting, with itself; it is an embarrassment to watch. It can’t agree amongst itself what it wants from the divorce settlement, from transitional arrangements or from a future relationship with the European Union. And as they squabble, companies in the UK go bust or look to relocate elsewhere, and people are losing their jobs. Day after day now, we hear bad economic news, and as they squabble things get worse and worse. It really is about time the UK Government pulled itself together: they should be clarifying their position and negotiating properly. They should be accepting the view of the Scottish and Welsh Governments that the UK needs to be in the single market and the customs union for the transitional period, and indeed permanently. For once, the British Government should put the country first, before the party.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Madam President! Mr Michel Barnier said that apart from financial regulation, the Irish issue, the rights of several million citizens are in fact the most important here, and they are the main aspect of the negotiations. We are about to adopt a resolution that some say is a hard one, but the more information reaches these millions of citizens, the more questions there are about their future. This also applies to my countrymen, Poles, many of whom live in Great Britain. This is a question of the right to stay, the conditions to be met, the question of social rights, including pensions, rules that apply to the movement of people after Brexit - these questions are related to the concern whether there will be equal treatment for citizens, many also ask about family reunification . Prime Minister May's recent declarations are promising. On the other hand, Great Britain is an important partner and we want to see it this way also after Brexit, because it is a partner in NATO, a neighbor in Europe, so mutual respect is also necessary in these negotiations, but the content of these negotiations is also important, the final result favorable for the Union European.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, neither this European Parliament nor the citizens of the 27 Member States voted on Brexit: a slim majority of British citizens did; and only then is the negotiating team set in motion - led by Mr Barnier, with the support of this European Parliament - to ensure the rights of European citizens, the integrity of the four freedoms - as interpreted by the jurisprudence of the Court of Justice - and for justice in the distribution of costs. This is the position of the European Union. But on the British side we only see confusion; and we have seen deportations; and we have seen the social, generational and territorial division, the fracture of British society itself. That is the result of a referendum in which reactionary nationalism and populist demagogy fueled by the far right, whose infamous speeches we have once again endured in this House, have gotten away with it. And those are the ghosts against which the European Union was born; Those are the enemies that the European Union faces and that we have a duty to defeat. And we are going to make sure that we will.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Madam President, let me start by saying that now is the time to work together and look for intrusions. The United Kingdom and the European Union must find a suitable way out of the European Union. Unfortunately, this motion for a resolution dictates to the United Kingdom how to move forward. Mr Verhofstadt, for example, refused further dialogue until the Prime Minister came up with a financial offer. But does Mr Verhofstadt not know that the first-place winner loses any negotiations? We all know that the livelihoods of many Britons in Europe, as well as EU citizens in the United Kingdom, are at stake. Even for the more than ninety thousand Slovaks living in the United Kingdom, it is necessary to ensure that their social rights are respected, including the possibility of living in British territory with whole families. Slovaks, along with other Eastern Europeans, have contributed to the living standards of the British and must not just be set aside. I am convinced that my British colleagues will be prudent and wise in their decisions, because any divorce is expensive, painful and leaves scars. Despite our departure, we should learn to get along as fraternal nations, and the partition of Czechoslovakia in 1993 could be an example.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, these negotiations certify that neither Brexit advocates nor the UK Government ever believed that the British decided to leave the European Union. Now you have to assume what has been decided and improvisation and melancholy appear. Therefore, first of all, we must persist in quickly negotiating the conditions of divorce, including the cost of the bill, prioritize the debate on citizenship rights and protect the peace work carried out by the European Union in Northern Ireland . To show, in short, the best of the Union; establish the best possible coexistence separately in the future; and, who knows, offer arguments to return to life together. A whole lesson about what the right to decide brings to the Union and its values. It clarifies to those who leave the real scope of its decision; it forces those of us who remain to insist on what unites us: a space of rights, freedoms and prosperity; a voluntary union, built from below, the real sum of all our diversity, capable of representing us as a global agent, which we would never think to impose with a bang, because it convinces. And, in such a scenario, our future - as Juncker has said - is the union, not Brexit.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Madam President, I have been listening to this debate with extreme attention. I am not a specialist in divorce issues, as I have been living with my spouse almost as long as the UK has been in the EU and we do not have any thoughts of breaking up. However, the key to a harmonised and hateless divorce lies on the basis that both sides recognise their mistakes and do not blame it all on the other side. In my opinion, there is space for improvement in that respect on both sides of the British Channel. Finally, I would ask the British Conservatives: please do not hire Boris Johnson as your defence lawyer, because he is so untypical of the British people: a man with no good manners.  (Applause)

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the process of the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union must be conducted in a civilized manner, commensurate with the prestige of both parties. For its part, the European Union must not show retaliation, because the citizens of Great Britain have decided to leave the European Union. But the UK government must not use as hostages the nationals of the other European Union countries living and working there, threatening to destroy the lives of themselves and their families. I would agree with Mr Verhofstadt that Belfast should break down the fences that separate some parts of the city. This must be done, because this situation is unacceptable. However, it is equally unacceptable to maintain the green line in Nicosia, the capital of Cyprus, part of which is illegally occupied by Turkey. The European Union - because it is also responsible for this unacceptable situation - must take steps to put pressure on Turkey to end this unacceptable situation, which diminishes the prestige of the civilized European Union.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I believe that the European Parliament must send a clear signal today in response to those citizens who live in insecurity. Whether it is 3.2 million nationals of the Member States living in the United Kingdom or, conversely, United Kingdom nationals living in the territory of the 1.2 million Member States. We say that a transitional period is possible, but it must be preceded by an agreement on all the fundamental issues, and the acquis communautaire will apply during this transitional period. Thus, the European Union is proving its ability to act and respond to fundamental problems, while the United Kingdom is not clear. I think this is also a clear signal to populist and separatist efforts in other Member States. In conclusion, I want to say that Brexit is a disappointment to me, the more we must try to make our relations as good as possible in the future so that we can work together, it is a commitment to those who voted against Brexit.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to emphasize from the outset that I support the resolution and congratulate the political groups that have taken on such a revolution. I come from a country that has concerns about the situation of its citizens living in the UK. The issue of the possible introduction by the United Kingdom of visas for citizens of my country after the date of Britain's withdrawal from the EU is a major issue for me and my country. Discrimination against European citizens, whatever their nationality, is unacceptable. Therefore, I congratulate that in the resolution we have this magic word: "reciprocity". We must ensure equal treatment of reciprocity. This must be the basic condition along with the payment in 28 of everything that has been spent from the budget of the European Union and not in 27. I congratulate the rapporteurs - the decision to leave the European Union has a cost and this cost must be borne by the one who assumed the decision, not only by those who, anyway, created reorganization problems. It is a pity, however, that the citizens who did not vote for Brexit also bear this cost. It would be very interesting for the UK to have an informed referendum after the Brexit negotiations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the Brexit debate highlights the fundamental elements of the European Union's functioning. The right of a Member State to leave the Union is non-negotiable. It is a sovereign right of a Member State to leave. The two-year negotiations aim to facilitate the exercise of this right and not to impede the right of exit. An attempt is being made here, on the part of the European Union, to take hostage a Member State which wishes to leave. An attempt is being made to break up this Member State, as Northern Ireland is given the right to remain a member of the Customs Union. The Court of Justice of the European Union shall also have the right to rule on the United Kingdom after its withdrawal. I think the European Union must focus on safeguarding the rights of Union citizens in the United Kingdom, including more than 63,000 of our fellow Greeks.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: Chief Brexit Negotiator. - Mr President, at the end of this dense, lively and long debate, my first words will be to thank the European Parliament for its numerous testimonies of support for the work which I have the honor to conduct with the confidence of President Juncker, Commission services, and in confidence with your own team, that of Guy Verhofstadt and all the members of the Brexit Steering Group of the European Parliament and the group chairs. We need this support and this confidence, and also this unity shown by the overwhelming majority of Parliament. At the end of this debate, during which I have listened to you all carefully and apologizing for not responding, as I usually do, to each of you, I would like to say a few words briefly. First, I would like to make it clear to many of those who have spoken, that there are two words that I cannot accept because they do not correspond to my state of mind or my attitude. These are the words of revenge and punishment. I have admired the United Kingdom for a very long time. I often even remember that in 1972, for my first vote as a young French citizen, I was then 21 years old, I campaigned in favor of the referendum organized in my country for the accession of the United Kingdom, of Ireland, Denmark and Norway. It was not easy for the young member of the Gaullist party that I was at the time, and I have never regretted the vote. I have great admiration for your country, ladies and gentlemen of the United Kingdom, and you will never, ever, find in my attitude the slightest spirit of revenge and the slightest intention of punishment. Never! (Applause) Mr. Farage, there is another word that I do not accept and that you have said again, which is ransom. There is no ransom, there is no exit bill. There is just the fact that when you decide to leave, we ask you to settle the accounts. No more no less! To pay for what you have agreed to! (Loud applause) I would add that this point is important if we want, as you yourself wished, to build in the future a different, but solid and lasting relationship in terms of trade, in terms of protection of security, counterterrorism and defense. We need trust between us for a lasting relationship in the future. The key to this trust is also that you objectively agree to settle the accounts. There is something that both of you said that I do not understand. It’s the idea that the European negotiator that I am or the European Union would like to drag things along or would want to hold you back, that it would play time. But, Ladies and Gentlemen, the referendum in the United Kingdom took place on June 23, 2016. We received the letter from Theresa May notifying this desire to withdraw on March 30, 2017. We have, due to the elections in the United Kingdom, waited until the end of June 2017 to start this negotiation. We are not playing for time. You took the time. We respect this time, but frankly I cannot accept this criticism. (Loud applause) We are even ready, and I am ready, to speed up and intensify the pace of the negotiations as much as we can. Ladies and gentlemen, there are a few points that I would like to be understood by telegraph or better understood. The UK has decided to leave the European Union. This is his sovereign choice. At the same time, according to what the British government says, he is leaving "the single market and the customs union" after 44 years of integration. I recommend that no one, really no one, underestimate the complexity, the legal, human, social, economic and financial difficulties of this decision. I also recommends that everyone who made this decision agree to accept the consequences. (Applause) Second point, we respect the sovereign choice of British citizens. We implement the withdrawal you have chosen. We want this withdrawal to be orderly, and for a lot of reasons I think it's better that you leave the European Union on March 30 with an agreement rather than without an agreement. It is in the common interest. We respect this choice, but we ask you to respect the European Union. We ask you to respect the fact that we will be intransigent on the integrity of the single market, respect for the operating rules and the decision-making autonomy of the European Union. Brexit cannot have consequences paid for by European Union taxpayers. Brexit cannot have the consequence of weakening the single market and the four freedoms that are intrinsically part of it. (Loud applause) Finally, we will have each other, and you ladies and gentlemen deputies as elected representatives of the peoples, to be accountable to the citizens, who are our priority, when it comes to their rights. We will be accountable to taxpayers. We will be accountable to businesses. We will also be accountable to those who have built this European Union for 60 years and of which we are the co-owners and co-responsible. I simply want the accounts that we are going to render at the end of these negotiations, ladies and gentlemen, to be fair and true. I will not come back to the various points of the negotiations which are pending. We have made progress, clarified a lot of points. I say that the general interest requires moving forward in stages. We have little time between now and October or November 2018 to come up with this Brexit treaty, that is, on divorce or orderly withdrawal, and the case appropriate, since this was requested by the British government, over a possible transitional period, the conditions of which were clearly framed by your resolution of last April and by the Council guidelines. It will be a short, structured period, during which we will maintain, because it is our raison d'être, the entire regulatory architecture of budgetary, legal conditions and the role of the Court of Justice. It is your request to have this short transition period, it is our right to say that it will be done under the conditions which are those of the single market. We are not surprised by this transition request, we planned it, we will discuss it when the time comes, and I will need a mandate to do so. I'm also just clarifying a legal point for Mr. Farage. The trade agreement you want cannot be signed with a member state of the Union. You have to be legally out, you have to be out, for us to sign this agreement. Ladies and gentlemen, throughout this ongoing negotiation, we will keep the hope that the constructive tone adopted by Theresa May in her speech in Florence will be maintained and consolidated, and that we will be able to make further progress from next week. . As far as I am concerned, in the responsibility entrusted to me, with your trust and support, throughout the months to come, I will ensure that the negotiations remain dignified, calm and firmly committed to the principles of the European Union. (Loud and prolonged applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place today.* * *

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I really ask for a moment's attention, it is an important speech.In Tunisia, exactly in the port of Sfax, the kidnapping of two European citizens is taking place, of two Italian citizens named Giacomo and Salvatore, two citizens who are detained on their fishing boat seized by the Tunisian government for 18 days: 18 days withoutfood, without electricity and Salvatore is now lacking medicines.I really ask, in the name of respect for fishermen, for work, for freedom, to help Salvatore and Giacomo to return to Europe, to return to Italy.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I will immediately notify the External Service so that all useful initiatives can be taken at least in relation to the supply of medicines to one of the two European citizens who are detained by Tunisia.I hope that their release can be reached as soon as possible.As soon as I leave the Chamber, I will call the External Service so that an initiative on the European side can be launched immediately.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – Negotiation efforts between the EU and the UK seem to be stagnating. It has become apparent, now more than ever, that there is a great need for clear political direction from the UK and for a sense of partnership between the two parties. To my mind, the most important aspect of the negotiations is the status of European citizens living in the UK – especially that of Romanian nationals – which must be clearly defined so as to avoid the risk of confusion with non-EU migrants. Moreover, the UK must honour its promise to continue its financial contributions to the EU budget until the end of this financial year (following rule n+3). I am delighted to see that, given the circumstances, the EU is speaking with one voice, highlighting the coordination and collaboration among all the leading EU players.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - EU and UK negotiators have not made sufficient progress in key areas, a necessary condition for starting discussions on the future bilateral relationship. We welcome the clarifications from British Prime Minister Theresa May in her recent speech in Florence, but we continue to call for concrete proposals to: fully guarantee the rights currently enjoyed by the 4.5 million EU and UK citizens , respect the financial commitments made by the UK with the EU, and resolve the border issue between Ireland and Northern Ireland, in line with the Good Friday agreement. In addition, in order to conclude the first phase of negotiation, it is necessary to guarantee respect for Community legislation until the moment the United Kingdom officially leaves the Union. The vote in this plenary session confirms the unity of Parliament with the other Community institutions.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: in writing. - The Brexit negotiations have been going on for more than six months, but there is still no real progress. The British Prime Minister’s speech in Florence has given some impetus to the negotiations, but there are still significant differences of opinion. This is especially true of the approximately 3 million EU citizens living in the UK. There are growing signs that the British authorities are already discriminating against EU citizens. That is why I support the Union's proposal that EU citizens living in the United Kingdom and British citizens living in the EU should have the same rights collectively. This includes family reunification as well as the maintenance of previously acquired rights. This solution would also significantly improve the situation of Hungarians living in the United Kingdom and working there. After all, the Orbán government is not doing anything for these people, it has left them alone. Not only does it restrict them in the exercise of their voting rights, but they also don’t care about their social security. For us, however, the cause of our compatriots in the United Kingdom is an important, defining European issue. We will only vote on the results of the Brexit negotiations if they clearly protect citizens' rights and guarantee the rights that our compatriots have already acquired.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - EU and UK negotiators have not made sufficient progress in key areas, a necessary condition for starting discussions on the future bilateral relationship. We welcome the clarifications from British Prime Minister Theresa May in her recent speech in Florence, but we continue to call for concrete proposals to: fully guarantee the rights currently enjoyed by the 4.5 million EU and UK citizens , respect the financial commitments made by the UK with the EU, and resolve the border issue between Ireland and Northern Ireland, in line with the Good Friday agreement. In addition, in order to conclude the first phase of negotiation, it is necessary to guarantee respect for Community legislation until the moment the United Kingdom officially leaves the Union. The vote in this plenary session confirms the unity of Parliament with the other Community institutions.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: written. - The Brexit negotiations have progressed, accompanied by conflicting messages and many issues remain open. The fact is that Britain can leave the Union without a real agreement to resign, because, under Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union (TFEU), mere notification is enough. It is therefore in the interests of all EU countries and citizens that a divorce agreement be reached. British Prime Minister May has said that it is better to leave without an agreement than with a bad agreement. The EU should strive to avoid an unconventional situation, as this would make it more difficult to foreign trade and the status of citizens. It is clear that Britain requires a comprehensive free trade agreement in addition to a severance agreement. It would therefore be best to move forward quickly in the negotiations and ensure that a free trade agreement that benefits all parties can emerge. In this way, it is possible to reach a resignation agreement on the basis of which Britain will be able to meet its financial obligations for a longer period of time. If the costs were to increase because Britain would not meet its obligations after March 2019, the consequences would be disproportionate for the taxpayers of all the remaining EU countries. It is essential to ensure that, after Brexit, the EU budget also shrinks in proportion to the British share of payments. Additional costs for EU net contributors such as Finland must not be incurred.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - In the EU's negotiations with the United Kingdom, the EP also has a decisive say, and it is also kept informed of the state of negotiations. This guarantees transparency and, ultimately, the approval of the treaty, which will guarantee all 3.2 million EU citizens living or working in the UK, all the rights and obligations they had before Brexit, after the UK left the EU.
