This also applies to the 1.2 million UK citizens living or working in an EU Member State. I appreciate the work of Commissioner Barnier, who very consistently took on the role of chief negotiator. Negotiating the contractual conditions under which the United Kingdom will leave the EU is not easy, because Brexit has serious human, social, economic and financial consequences. The issue of Ireland and Northern Ireland, where special circumstances need to be included in the withdrawal treaty, so that fixed borders are not established, the peace process is maintained and the Good Friday Agreement applies, must also be one of the main topics in the negotiations. The most difficult point in the negotiations seems to be the financial settlement, in which the EU wants the United Kingdom to repay all its commitments to which it made itself when approving the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020. State, which was Brexit.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - Another round of negotiations between the European Commission and Great Britain ended on September 28. Despite the fact that after the speech of British Prime Minister Theresa May in Florence, the new dynamics of the talks were felt and they were held in a constructive atmosphere, progress was still not considered sufficient. Britain agreed to give "direct effect" to the EU Exit Agreement. This gives more confidence and stability to EU citizens in the UK. However, divergences remain over the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice. It is also necessary to present a clear position of the United Kingdom on the full fulfillment of its financial obligations towards the EU. Also unsolved remains, inter alia, the issue of recognition of education. And this is especially important as it affects thousands of young people, both UK and EU citizens. Students who start their studies prior to UK departure need to be sure that they can complete the course on the same terms as they started and that they will still have access to student loans and other financial support under the same terms. In addition, students who start their studies must be sure that their qualifications will be recognized both in the EU and in the UK, and after completing the course, they will retain the same UK residence rights as they had before their departure date.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Dear colleagues, before proceeding to the votes, allow me to make a short personal statement. Some of you know that I am the leading candidate for the Austrian Greens in the snap elections on 15 October. This means that I will be leaving this Parliament. It also means that this is the last time I will chair the votes with you as your Vice-President. (Loud applause) I would like to thank you for these eight years in which I have been working with many of you in this Parliament, sharing this spirit of cooperation rather than confrontation that unites us, or at least the majority of us here, and also for the three years as one of your Vice-Presidents. They have been very good years for me, and I promise you I am taking this European spirit that I have experienced here with me to our national debates and to the Austrian parliament. I am also looking forward to working with you in the future in a different function, because we need strong national parliaments as well as a strong European Parliament. Thank you very much. (Applause)

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, I apologise to my colleagues, but my voting system seems to be breaking down. It is not often, as my colleagues can appreciate, that I vote in favour of something in this place, but it would be quite nice to be able to do so on occasion when I wish to. Could one of the technicians look at it in the break? It is very sticky and static, and it needs sorting out.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, although we saw some openings in the Prime Minister’s speech in Florence, many key issues remain to be solved. The most important among them is the question of the Irish border. I am from the Western Balkans myself and I know perfectly well that a hardening of the border will lead to tensions and nationalist sentiments. We cannot pretend that the whole solution to the problem is to promise not to have a physical border. In Bosnia there are no physical borders, but nationalism and tensions certainly do exist. In order to prevent it, you need to make sure that no new mental, cultural and religious borders are established, and that demands much clearer thinking than has been the case so far. Therefore, the message that we send here is very clear: the time for political games should be over. It is crucial for Prime Minister May to translate her commitments into tangible actions. We need to move forward before the tensions and conflicts arise. The citizens of Northern Ireland need clarity, action and responsible leaders.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, ‘we do not know’ I said in answer after answer at an event I spoke at about Brexit recently. It didn’t make for a very interesting or illuminating evening, but the crippling uncertainty is playing havoc with the British economy. Every sector that I speak to has their own Brexit problem: ground-breaking research that relies on cross-border data flows, imports and exports at our ports, or the freedom of movement of Newmarket’s race horses. Today’s debate shows what everyone knows. The talks are not going well, and that is hardly surprising when we have a cornered Prime Minister more worried about negotiating with her own cabinet than engaging constructively in the Brexit process.  As a remainer, I have no doubt that Britain will emerge from all of this weaker, poorer and more isolated. Today, this Parliament has sent another warning siren. So I say to the British government: with a bumpy landing ahead why, oh why, do you choose to deliberately fly through turbulence?  (Applause)

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Ms. President!There are about half a million Hungarians in the UK, mostly out of economic coercion.I would like to ask for their help with regard to the sixth paragraph of the report, which I voted for anyway, and which states that the United Kingdom must refrain from any administrative or other practice which, inter alia, hinders or discriminates against EU-27 nationals living in the United Kingdom.citizens of the Member States.I would like to ask our Hungarian compatriots, of course we all want the most to come home as soon as possible, but until this happens, inform us by e-mail, letter about what these practices are, discriminatory practices, what problems, what difficulties they have at work., or elsewhere, in the administration or elsewhere since the Brexit process.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, may I just thank you for your service to Parliament and wish you well as you go to fresher pastures. Briefly on Brexit: 557 Members supported this resolution. I think what it says very clearly is that this Parliament wants to see progress. I hope that the vote and the strength of the resolution will urge the UK side, in particular, to come forward with a much stronger and clear negotiating position, because every day there are new nuances to the Brexit story. There are problems and concerns about child protection laws around the border, about the supply of medicines to citizens, about health care and about all sectors of society. Therefore, we need progress on the withdrawal agreement before we can move forward to the next phase and I hope today’s vote will nudge those at the negotiating table to make that progress.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, the United Kingdom has been an important driver in the economic liberalization of Europe and in creating the preconditions for the establishment of a single market in the full sense of the word.Its leadership in removing superfluous regulation, removing barriers and opening our markets, and a clear advocacy of national sovereignty and the principle of subsidiarity will be lacking in this Community.But the British have clearly expressed their will to leave the European Union and it is now up to us to make this process as easy as possible for citizens and businesses on both sides of the Channel.I voted against this Resolution because it unnecessarily recommends further complicating this already complicated divorce.Parliament should not interfere too much in the Brexit negotiations, but leave it to the Commission and the Council.Otherwise, the negotiations will become even more complicated on our part as the European elections approach, and our future close relations with the United Kingdom must not fall victim to populism and politicking.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: - Madam President, Brexit is a prime example of where ethno-populists can lead a country, however strong it may be. Great Britain is now moving into uncharted waters. Unfortunately, insufficient progress has been made in the six months since the start of negotiations. This position was expressed by both the European Parliament and the Commission. Britain has not accepted the retention of the rights of European citizens living there. More than three million Europeans, many thousands of Greeks, live, study and work in the United Kingdom. They can not pay for Mr Cameron's tactics. Many of them have settled there, have started families, it is now their home. We can not change their lives. The British government cannot use them as a lever in the negotiations. He can not intimidate them by sending them, by mistake, deportation papers. European citizens living in England should continue to enjoy the same rights as under current European law. Nothing less can be accepted by the European Parliament.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Madam President, in a referendum in which much of British society was misled by one-sided and unproven allegations by the votes of just over one million citizens, a period of uncertainty and political turmoil began in Britain. Unfortunately, this is being transferred to the European Union. Nearly 5 million citizens will be directly affected by Britain's decision to leave the European Union. Here we are talking about nearly 3.6 million European citizens, of which 200 thousand Bulgarian citizens in the UK and over 1.2 million Britons in the European Union. I find the striking lack of results, more than six months after the announcement of Britain's departure from the Union, on the rights of all these citizens. I find irresponsible the speculation of some British politicians that Britain may leave the Union without respecting financial commitments made years before the referendum. The uncertainty arising from the exit decision must not be transposed to European producers and farmers. That is why I supported this resolution.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of the resolution because I believe that Parliament must forcefully pursue the negotiations, to ensure that the United Kingdom respects the terms and conditions for leaving the Union, a year now andhalf from the referendum.In fact, I believe that progress is currently not very evident.I believe that the European Union, on the other hand, cannot afford either uncertainty or insecurity.Europe must continue to act and guarantee the protection of European citizens who now live across the Channel: there are more than 600,000.Finally, I believe that I must emphasize that Great Britain must keep its financial commitments, whereas it has a significant trade deficit with the European Union.Differences and inconsistencies remain on this and other key points of the agreement, which must be addressed as soon as possible.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I think it is important that the European Parliament has adopted this resolution, even with great support, with 558 Members voting in favor. This is important because the EP will eventually comment on the final agreement between the European Union and the United Kingdom. It is therefore important information about the political agreement on the way forward in the negotiations. The resolution very rightly emphasizes the rights of EU citizens in the United Kingdom, and securing them is one of the main challenges we face as a Union. Undoubtedly, these tasks also include maintaining British participation in programs such as Erasmus + and Horizon 2020. It is in the interests of both EU and UK citizens. I also fully agree with the approach taken in the report with regard to Northern Ireland. The border on the island of Ireland needs to remain open after Brexit, and if that is the case, there is a possibility that Northern Ireland itself will be part of the customs union and the internal market.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – Madam President, there are more than 3 million EU citizens residing in the United Kingdom and more than one million citizens of the United Kingdom residing in the EU. They are all asking the same question: what will happen to me, to my family, to my job, to my business, to my studies? People are right to be worried about the future, because they do not really know what will happen come Brexit day.  Moving to another country is a major decision, usually based on the rights that they would have in that country. That is why maintaining the whole set of EU rules on citizens’ rights, with the full application of the four freedoms and without imposing unnecessary hardship on the citizens of the EU living in the United Kingdom and vice versa, is the main prerequisite for the success of these negotiations.  The work of this Chamber determines the fate of over 4 million citizens, and that is why we first need to defend people’s interests, and that is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, I echo the sentiments of colleagues wishing you the best in your future endeavours: you have always tried to chair with impartiality, and for that I thank you.  Article 8 of the Lisbon Treaty is all about neighbourliness and cooperation. That is the spirit in which the Brexit negotiations should be conducted, and a bit of give-and-take would be great, but it seems it is all give from Theresa May and all take from Michel Barnier.  This resolution is a shopping list: the EU’s goals on the Northern Ireland border but nothing on Gibraltar’s. No one wants a hard border, but effectively this place are the ones raising the possibility. Do we want reciprocal rights for EU citizens in the UK and vice versa? Of course we do, but please do not gold-plate it to your children and children’s children.  This sufficient progress test is nothing more than an unnecessary hurdle designed to throw a spanner in the works. This intransigence will not help Britain, it is true – but it will not help the EU either. Theresa May should fight fire with fire and act with boldness, not cowardice.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Madam President!I voted against and would like to point out that the British had left the European Union because they did not like the laws that govern the European Union.Consequently, if we insist that certain people who are under British rule apply European law, the effect will be exactly the opposite.Let me remind you that even a criminal like Lenin lived peacefully in London, although no one, neither Russia, nor Europe, nor Germany, nor France, demanded that Britain treat him fairly.Therefore, in my opinion, this matter should be left to the British, because any interference in it will result in the reluctance of the British towards the citizens of the European Union.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: - Madam President! The debate today gave a shocking impression of the lack of understanding of referendums as a democratic instrument found in this House. Perhaps because in the EU as a whole, throughout its history, it has done what it could to avoid referendums, and often regarded them as a decided evil that would only prevent the project. But in doing so, one has also brought oneself into an oppositional relationship with the European population. It is this contradiction that puts us today in a situation where the British no longer feel that they can be a member of this Union. The reason why the British are leaving the EU must not be found in London, but must be found in Brussels, in Frankfurt, in Strasbourg and in all the other European capitals, where for years a line has been drawn away from the European people, who have rightly a requirement to be heard and asked. We do not owe the British mockery and humiliation, but respect for holding referendums so that the people are asked.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm gur glacadh leis an moladh seo inniu, 557 ina fhábhar, 92 ina choinne agus 29 ag staonadh. Ba mhaith liom mo bhuíochas a chur in iúl do Guy Verhofstadt, Michel Barnier agus gach duine a chabhraigh linn cás na hÉireann a chur chun tosaigh sna pointí seo: go háirithe ag iarraidh na moltaí agus na socruithe a ghabhann le comhaontuithe Aoine an Chéasta a choimeád agus teorainn bhog a bheith againn in ionad teorainn chrua. Bíodh sin ráite, tá sé soiléir go bhfuil bac mór ann, is é sin mar a thug Michel Barnier air: ‘An Bille Imeachta’: Iarraim ar údarás na Ríochta Aontaithe teacht le moladh cinnte chun an bille seo a réiteach. Má éiríonn linn é sin a réiteach, níl aon dabht in aon chor ach gur féidir linn an spriocdháta a bhaint amach agus idirbheartaíocht a chríochnú in am.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, allow me to comment on my vote today, when I voted in favor of this report, but with one important aspect that I still lack a concrete expression of how the EU budget will be further financed.We still do not have agreed on the parameters by which we will cooperate with Great Britain, and therefore how Great Britain will participate and what it will specifically participate in in European policy.And I think that is important not only for drawing up the budget for next year, but above all for drawing up the budget after the departure of the United Kingdom.That is why I would like to call on the negotiators and the United Kingdom in particular to take this aspect into account and try to agree on it as soon as possible.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, the European Parliament has recognised that Theresa May’s Brexit has the potential to be devastating for the island of Ireland. The prospect that is envisaged by the Tories, and unfortunately endorsed by Unionist representatives in this House today, of a small island of 6.5 million people operating with one part inside the EU and another part outside would be catastrophic for the Irish economy north and south, for Irish agriculture north and south and, of course, for the Irish peace process. I welcome the fact that Parliament understands that all of Ireland needs to remain in the single market and the Customs Union. Of course, the easiest way for this to happen is for Britain to do so also, but if they do not do this they need to know that they have no mandate to drag the North of Ireland into economic, political and social upheaval. The Irish Government must now seize upon this report and lead the demand for special status for the North of Ireland in the EU in order to protect our entire island.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, Michael Gove has promised that, as a result of Brexit, the UK will be able to export more pig’s ears to China. The Tory Government has certainly made a pig’s ear of these negotiations and what is quite clear is that they have run out of ideas completely. The Tories continue, distracted by a power tug-of-war, to steer us towards a cliff edge, promising three decades of damage to the UK economy. Yet many persist in the deluded belief that we can cherry-pick. Parliament’s resolution is a much needed reality check. That is why I supported it. What is clear in my region, the West Midlands, is that no-deal means costs going up by 30% to 40% in dairy and meat and 10% in cars. That is why Labour is saying ‘no deal is no way’ – whereas we will deliver one that retains jobs and protects rights. David Davis, as you know, having not even delivered on his own job at the moment, is talking about his retirement whilst millions of people living in the EU and the UK have no idea what their future may be.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to add my appreciation to those who have already thanked you for your service in the chair. This resolution and, even more, the speeches that we have heard today bear very little relation to the progress in the talks. Britain has already said that it will not put up any physical border in Ireland. We have already said that we will look at the financial settlement in the spirit of wanting advantageous outcomes for our European allies, as well as for us. We have already said that all of the social, working, residence and healthcare rights of EU nationals in the UK will be guaranteed. These things have been formally stated. I understand that there are some colleagues here who love to have a go at us – this is not new, it is not a post—Brexit thing; it is an occasional occurrence in this House. What I think is strange – and will strike people in the UK as strange – is to have British MEPs, particularly in the S&D Group, lining up to say that everything is going to be catastrophic and that the economy is tanking when that bears no relation to people’s actual experience. I hope that after we have left we will remove the main cause of contention and will be able to enjoy a better relation than we have now.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a little over a year after the Brexit referendum, awareness of the role of the European Union has grown considerably. The Union has before it a window of time to take advantage of the opportunities offered by this stumbling block, however, provided that the state of uncertainty generated by unwanted cohabitation does not extend beyond measure. Acceptance of the British Prime Minister's request for a transitional period of limited duration must therefore be subject to the certainty of the duration of that period, the continuation of the entire acquis communautaire, the full jurisdiction of the Court of Justice of the Union and the conclusion of a real withdrawal agreement, which mainly addresses issues relating to the rights of European citizens in the United Kingdom and of the British in Europe, the fate of Ireland and the financial settlement obligations of the European Union. After the beautiful words of last September, Theresa May must follow the facts. Without an orderly withdrawal from the United Kingdom of the Union, no negotiations will have to be launched on the framework of the future relationship, and no transition phase can and should be granted.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Madam President! I would like to join in thanking my colleagues for cooperation with you. Citizens of the European Union settle in another Member State, taking advantage of the possibilities offered to them by Community law and assuming that they will be able to exercise this right throughout their lives. Therefore, any negotiations on the post-Brexit status of Union citizens in the United Kingdom or of Brits in the Union should be based on this right. Therefore, there can be no consent to any changes in their legal or factual position. London's new proposals do not comply with this law, as they allow limitations, for example, in the law to family reunification, and also introduce a new, not fully defined category of a settled person. The negotiating progress made in this regard is therefore far from sufficient. The prolonged talks increase the uncertainty among ordinary people, neither the citizens of the Union living in Great Britain, nor the British in the Union know what the future awaits them. This uncertainty prevents them from securing their rights and interests, therefore negotiators should reach an agreement as soon as possible within the framework of the treaty regulations and guaranteeing respect for acquired rights. We cannot agree to any restriction on them. For these reasons, I have supported the European Parliament resolution today with full responsibility.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this important report was supposed to incorporate the measures adopted by the ICCAT Commission ten years ago in the best possible way into European Union law: they are used for the conservation and management of tuna. Not only do we do it late, but we also do it badly. It was a good opportunity to protect fish species but also the income of our fishermen, especially those of artisanal and traditional fishing. First of all, transparency had to be increased in order to combat irregular and illegal fishing. The allocation of the quotas for tuna and swordfish had to follow transparent and objective criteria, including those of an environmental nature, while also paying attention to the social and economic aspects. The distribution of Total Allowable Catches (TACs) had to come with particular attention to traditional and artisanal fishing and to incentivize Union fishing vessels using selective fishing gear or fishing techniques with low environmental impact. Also for this reason, particular attention should have been paid to the discipline of by-catches or accidental, to meet the demands of artisanal fishing, which seeks to exploit a resource that has no longer been in crisis for some years, but whose abundance is bringing dozens to its knees. and dozens of companies. For these reasons, I could not support the report which, thus amended, actually represents a step backwards from the status quo.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Madam President, those who have lost the most with the ineffectiveness of the Commission and the Member States in the application of the ICCAT Convention are the artisanal fishermen who, traditionally, have been the main economic engine of coastal towns. In Spain, article 17 of the common fisheries policy is not fulfilled because the Popular Party uses the quota as a political weapon to confront the fishermen, the territories and, in addition, take away their right to the sea. The Popular Party leaves most of the bluefin tuna quota to large factories belonging to the Balfegó and Ricardo Fuentes group and, later, they fill their mouths with the homeland. Homeland is to defend the bread of artisanal fishermen. We have said it repeatedly: we are going to support everything that has to do with improving the lives of people who fight copper every day in the fight against the waves to support their families. We hope that this report does not remain a dead letter and that the Commission punishes and prosecutes those who legislate in favor of large corporations while impoverishing our people and destroying our common good.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Madam President! I voted against the document not because I am opposed to making wages equal for the same work, or to improving the material status of women or increasing pensions, which can be achieved without necessarily meeting the Barcelona targets. I voted against because the provisions and tendencies presented are in fact directed against femininity and women, reducing their role to one of the elements driving the economic machine and GDP. The proposals, apart from weakening family ties and discrediting motherhood, prejudge women. In addition, there are many other controversial provisions, for example the term reproductive health instead of the dignified term procreation. The best care for a child is provided by a loving mother, and no one and nothing can replace her. I remember exactly from the communist era, when, despite the psychophysical differences between men and women and their particular calling, Polish women were persuaded to get on tractors.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!Today in Poland we are celebrating the anniversary of the so-called black protest, i.e. women's protest against government proposals that threatened their autonomy and independence.For this reason, there will also be an anniversary protest today.I take this opportunity to send all organizers words of solidarity with their ideas and aspirations, but going back to the document we are talking about, it presents many aspects of inequality.Due to the lack of time, I would like to point out one, in my opinion, very crucial, namely in many countries, including Poland, the age difference in retirement applies.This is something that absolutely discriminates against women, causes them to receive less pensions in retirement, and is falsely presented as a privilege.This is a scandal.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Madam President, I am pleased that this report addresses key issues for feminism, such as the care economy and sex education. I regret that it does not materialize in decided sanctions against the culture of rape, which is dangerously spreading through the media and which is related to the objectification of women's bodies and, therefore, to the commodification of life . The care economy is not a decorative phrase: it is about a new way of producing, of understanding ourselves, of establishing the rules that govern our societies, where not only profit counts. Today, unfortunately, even our bellies become merchandise. For this reason, solidarity between us, women of the world, is more necessary than ever; also with our Muslim sisters, who, unfortunately, this report has left forgotten, even though they live with us, door to door, in Europe and deserve all the respect and recognition of the world.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, let me explain why I did not vote in favor of this report, even though I have long advocated the elimination of discrimination against women and the appreciation of women as mothers and their parental care.I am convinced that we will support the economic position of women by recognizing the value of motherhood and their parental care, by enabling a choice between parental and professional careers.Unfortunately, this report does not go in that direction.Unfortunately, it goes beyond what can be dictated to Member States and companies.For example, in that it proposes measures for companies that would have to monitor pay gaps.I also could not agree with the requirement to introduce CVs without stating the gender or, for example, for all economic models and tax policies to take into account the gender perspective.This report is also stereotypical in that it introduces sexual and reproductive health into women's economic empowerment.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Ms. President! I agreed with the essence of this report, which runs through it, namely that it is unfortunate that, to this day, we consider women to be almost solely responsible for everything that happens in the family, in the family home, in the household. Referring to some false biological difference, we say that women are able, fit and obliged solely to care for and raise children, care for elderly relatives, nursing, caring for a potentially disabled family member, and this causes unbearable and constant physical, mental and conscientious burdens. for women. It would be fundamental to change this approach, although I agree that the Union should not be binding on the Member States, but in education, the media and EU recommendations, it would be a good idea to take on these important responsibilities together as a partner, men and women. tasks.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President!Contrary to the declared intentions, the report on women's economic empowerment includes tools for the social degradation of women.Making the economic position of women dependent on the so-calledabortion rights - whatever they may be called reproductive or sexual rights - take it for granted that their employers urge women to choose between motherhood and work.Of course, this approach fits in with the cultural pressure on women to compete with men by giving up - partially or even completely - motherhood.Treating motherhood and the role of women in the family as indifferent or socially redundant private options is the highest harm that liberal consumerism does to women, children, families and society as a whole.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, timing is everything. I wanted to make a very brief comment on this report. I think in this House we talk a great deal about the invisibility of women on boards or in politics and how we want to empower young women as they go through the education process to become more visible, but I think very often we forget that there are a great deal of women in very invisible positions in low—paid work. I think we do not spend enough time talking about their empowerment and looking after their rights because they are invisible to many of us. So I think there is a challenge to women, when we are addressing this issue, to talk about all women across all sectors and not just the more visible parts of our society and our economy. That is why I think this is an important report. I supported it, but I think we need to widen the debate and be more inclusive.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Madam President, as draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would like to express my satisfaction with some elements of this report, such as the fact that it recognizes that the structural barriers that hinder the economic empowerment of women originate in multiple forms of inequality and discrimination. To overcome these barriers, the responses have to be comprehensive. It is necessary to combat segregation in the labor market, but also in education, training and care tasks. We must reduce the precariousness of women workers in so-called feminized sectors, such as domestic and care work. And we also need nursery schools and assistance services for dependent people, which are public, accessible, sufficient and of quality. We must fight against direct and indirect discrimination that exists in the labor market, guarantee that there is equal pay for the same job, combat atypical and precarious forms of employment contracts, which affect women above all, and guarantee a redistribution of labor care with, for example, equal and non-transferable paternity and maternity leave.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: - Madam President! I come from a country where our head of state, Her Majesty the Queen, is a woman, where the Speaker of Parliament, the Folketing, the absolute highest civilian position that can be achieved is a woman, my former party chairman Pia Kjærsgaard, where the absolute majority of parties in the Folketing have or have had female chairmen, and where one can therefore see throughout the political game that it is not quotas and regulations and political decisions that make women win, but their qualities, their abilities, their drive , their work. That is what we need to promote. Not a special pussenusse system, where we make quotas based on special political provisions. Not at all when we can see how, for example in Norway, where such a system was made 10 years ago, it has failed. It has not led to top positions in the business community there, but we can see in Denmark that it has in politics without quotas. Therefore, it is the way to go. The path of volunteering and respect for the individual. No quotas.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I supported this report, which promotes the crucial protection of women’s rights in the private and public sectors. Economic empowerment of women is not only important in a human rights context, but also for the EU’s prosperity at large and for its fair and economic growth.  When discriminatory practices have a negative impact on women due to their gender, they are hindered from reaching their full potential and from engaging with society in a meaningful way. Important tools for empowering women in the workplace include ensuring the work-life balance, wage mapping, gender quotas, gender equality plans, equal pay for equal work of equal value, collective agreements and social partners.  Eurostat findings show that the proportions of working women compared to working men in the EU in full—time work amounts to a full-time employment rate gap of 25.5%. Irish society has much to thank the EU for in terms of gender equality legislation, but there are still many improvements to be made in Ireland and across the EU.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Madam President, I have been in this House for three and a half years, and during that time I have often tried to point out that the EU needs to return to respecting Judeo-Christian values ​​and understanding of God and the natural roles and roles of men and women in life. . On the one hand, the approval of this report is Pyrrhic's victory for me, both of my amendments have passed and I am convinced that we must begin to give due weight to the unpaid work of men and women who care for elderly relatives or disabled in the family and their sacrifice goes unnoticed. On the other hand, although these proposals can help a lot of people and pass, I am very dissatisfied with this report, because it is one of the worst we have ever had here in recent times. They are pushing for the LGBTI agenda again, pushing us to approve quotas for listed companies so that there are more women, or simply pushing things like the Istanbul Convention, which many countries do not agree with. So I had to vote against.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Madam President! We are worried by the information that in recent years, in principle, no progress has been achieved in terms of discrimination against women. We should ask ourselves whether the instruments we are using are actually effective if women's wages are still on average 16% lower than those received by men, and pensions received by women are on average 40% lower than those received by men. that men get. Strong discrimination in the period of professional activity leads to a real deep pauperization of women in their old age. I agree with the rapporteur that the digital revolution that is currently taking place may be an opportunity to strengthen the economic position of women. However, it is necessary to take steps to encourage women not only to gain formal education in this area, but above all to retrain and improve their skills. We should also develop instruments aimed at supporting women who want to set up businesses in the area of ​​the digital economy. We are facing a unique opportunity to strengthen the economic position of women. That is why I supported the report in the final vote, especially uniting myself with Polish women who are fighting for their fundamental rights in the Polish streets today.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, in Russia, civil society is eliminated by law.Transparency International, for example, or the Memorial organization founded by Andrei Sakharov and more than a hundred other non-governmental organizations were forced by the Kremlin to end its activities.In Turkey, judges, teachers, businessmen, their families, journalists, were arrested on the grounds that they are Gulenists.Azerbaijan has shown how dozens of European politicians are being corrupted by Azerbaijan.False propaganda with George Soros has also begun to take place in European countries and is heading towards dictatorship, obviously because the effect is against civil society.In order not to be hypocritical, do we respect the values of the European Union or not?Yes or no?The question is simple.If so, then impose these values on all EU and non-EU countries and drastically penalize, including financially, those that do not respect them.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Madam President, when it comes to voting on these types of reports, the truth is that they are increasingly empty of content, but full of political hypocrisy, and that is what makes one feel a bit absurd in this Parliament. When we promote international trade between equals, which puts people and the environment before the profit of transnational companies, and when there are binding clauses in this regard, then we will be doing something for civil society in developing countries. In the meantime, I would like to call on my Spanish counterpart Jiménez Becerril, rapporteur for this report, to concern himself with Spanish civil society, a civil society that her party, the Popular Party, is repressing and confronting. Day 1 was Catalonia and today is Murcia. It is the Spanish civil society as a whole that is repressed and that suffers violence worthy of times gone by. They are turning the Government of Spain into a huge shame in the eyes of the whole world and of all the people who in Spain continue to be on the side of democracy and freedom.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, first of all congratulations on your new strife in your country. I hope you have good luck and I wish you all the best. Madam President, I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe that civil society plays a central role in building and strengthening democracy and in promoting good governance and civil society organizations are important players in aid for development. They carry out relevant activities in the social and environmental domain, safeguarding the interests of people with disabilities, vulnerable and marginalized people, social movements and indigenous peoples. The European Union is the largest donor to local civil society organizations in developing countries and has been a major player in protecting civil society actors and human rights defenders through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights and the European Democracy Fund. For all these reasons, Madam President, I believe that this resolution is, in my opinion, in fact, a fundamental instrument in the defense of individual rights and in the strengthening of democracy. Thank you very much. That is why I voted in favor.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, in my role as Vice-President, I look after dialogue with religious communities and non-confessional organisations and we talk a great deal about freedom of religion and belief. In the developing world, a vibrant civil society is very important in terms of protecting that freedom. It is something that we work on with the UN and we need to deepen the involvement of civil society in the developing world on this issue because it is a matter of life or death in many developing countries. The problem – and it has been addressed by this report – is that we are seeing, in some developing countries, a shrinking space, with little room for civil society to have its place. Therefore, as part of our development policy, we need to help these countries to respect the full range of human rights. We need to empower communities and individuals and we need to make this a priority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: - Madam President, what I wanted to say is quite simple. When you type certain keywords in Google, I will not quote them because they are very simple words, among the first search results appear the newspapers of Al-Qaida, the Front al-Nosra or the Islamic State . What do we find in these newspapers? It contains calls for murder and information on how to assassinate someone, build a bomb and encrypt their communications. If a single print journal were published and offered for sale at a bookseller with such content, the bookseller and publisher would obviously be doomed, and the journal would be banned. On the digital level, on the other hand, nothing is happening. There is total impunity for digital broadcasters. What we want is very simple. If we are to fight crime, all those who disseminate content inciting murder must be criminalized, prosecuted and punished. Because these publications are identical, in their paper form or in digital version. This is common sense, and if we don't do that, don't come and complain when the next attack happens!

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, I would like to say that the European institutions have experienced several cyber attacks in recent years.And I don't think they should underestimate cyber security for this reason.Special authorities have been set up in a number of countries, but I think that there is still a lack of cooperation between the various authorities in the Member States and an effort to really face these threats as the whole of the EU.Then there is the huge problem of cyberbullying.It is a problem that does not receive too much attention and to which both pupils and very often teachers or principals of different schools are exposed.And in addition to repression, I would like to say that I appreciate the prevention in this report, because I think that prevention, especially in the family, where we explain that some things may not be published or written on the internet, is very important.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!Security in cyberspace is becoming the number one problem today.It concerns national security, state security, economic security, but it is also slowly affecting political security.We have more and more reasonable suspicions that some states are interfering with the democratic electoral processes of other states.This is absolutely unacceptable, and therefore the family of the democratic states of the world should oppose all these threats, especially since the technologies we are talking about are technologies of the future.Therefore, actions are needed to establish international law on security in cyberspace and international cooperation for the effective implementation of new legal norms.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against cybercrime, I believe, must be one of the priorities of the European Union for the value it represents and above all for the sectors it involves: from the fight against child pornography, to the cybercrimes that affect companies , to the scams that are constantly and continuously increasing, a real great danger! And the use we make of technology for all our businesses and daily life makes the sector even more vulnerable. I believe that this provision can only take into account the need for the countries of the Union to do an absolutely unanimous work, in order to be able to use the fight against cybercrime especially on the front on which we are most exposed: terrorism. A terrorism that is increasingly technological, which aims to collect consent through the web, in an absolutely invasive way, which I believe must be fought in an absolutely hard and profound way. And only thanks to a work that must be a team, a network and cohesion across countries is it possible to achieve this result.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, thank you very much for your collegiality, and I wish you all the best in your future to come.  We have to strike a balance in enjoying the benefits of modern technologies without compromising on our security or privacy. Therefore, I fully agree with this report calling for the update of the European Union’s cybersecurity strategy. It is important to enhance cooperation at EU level in order to fight the current and newly emerging cybercrime trends. Member States should combine their efforts for a better information exchange through Eurojust, Europol or the European Union’s Agency for Network and Information Security.  Lastly, let’s not forget that every single one of us can make small steps to avoid becoming a victim of cybercrimes. We therefore urge the Commission to launch information and awareness—raising campaigns for citizens so that they know the risks and can develop a good digital hygiene.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, allow me a few sentences for the vote itself. I supported this report because I consider it important for EU countries to cooperate much more in those forms of crime that are cross-border in nature. Cybercrime objectively belongs to this. No state at the national level is able to solve these problems on its own. Here, the principle of cooperation between 28 countries is clearly in place and I support it. So I supported the report. There are a number of positive, concrete things in the report that will need to be addressed in the future. It is good that the European Cybercrime Center has been set up within Europol, but it will also be necessary to look at how active this center will be. Whether it will be just an office for the office or it will bring its results. The parts of the report that provide precautionary measures are important. I consider these to be particularly important and I hope that the report will be fulfilled.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: - Madam President!What worries me about this report is when it comes to "fake news" and "hate speech regulation".We are all against spreading fake news.We are also all against hateful statements.However, it is an enormous power to put in the hands of getting to decide what is false and true, to decide what is hate and not hate.By making the division where we criminalize one group but not the other group, we are heading down to a totalitarian state where we will basically put a few people to be judges of one of the most vital democratic rights,namely, the right to express oneself.I do not believe in such a system of state or European censorship.I believe that citizens - enlightened, wise and skilled at navigating between news - can themselves distinguish between the true and the false, the good and the bad.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report, which outlines the challenges and the legal gaps related to the threats posed by cybercrime. Cybercrime is one of the most pressing issues we face today. Across the EU it is increasing in intensity and is causing ever greater economic and social damage. Europol’s assessment of the threat posed by cybercrime is that it has affected the fundamental rights of individuals and that 80% of companies in Europe have experienced at least one cybersecurity incident. Children who are using the internet at an early age are particularly vulnerable to cybercrime. The proposals outlined by this report aim to address these challenges. They include improved responsibility and liability of service providers, and enhanced cooperation among police and judicial authorities, etcetera. To combat child exploitation online, an action plan has been proposed for the protection of children’s rights online and offline in cyberspace. I agree with this. To conclude, Madam President, may I wish you all the best for the future. I have always found you to be a very fine, honest and pleasant MEP.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I supported this report because truly cyberspace poses a very serious danger for the future.I am very pleased that the rapporteur is paying attention to him in her extensive report and that she has received such cross-cutting support across all political factions.I am also pleased that the EU sees this issue as serious and fundamental at a time when a special conference has been held in Estonia.I would choose two circumstances that I think are very important in that report.Firstly, the EU must be a leader, it must be at the forefront of expertise, because it is expertise that is a prerequisite for dealing with the threats associated with cyber attacks.And secondly, it is important that the systems we build are as resilient as possible so that they are integral.And thirdly, it is important to inform citizens of these threats, of course, so that they are prepared for possible attacks.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, in 2016 in Warsaw, NATO recognized cyberspace as one of the threats in which the alliance must defend itself, just as it does now in air, sea or land space. The WannaCry attack in May this year left more than 200 victims in 150 countries. Cyberspace has no rules and that is why we need to give the necessary tools, including financial ones, including access to all databases to those who fight cybercrime. At this point, the fight is totally uneven; Today's situation shows that the means of struggle are insufficient and unequal. If we don't give them these tools and we don't increase their funding, I repeat, and we don't give them everything they need, then we will have even more deaths because we know very well that cybercrime also finances terrorism and helps launder money. We can be one step ahead of crime, one step ahead of crime, because otherwise we will never solve anything.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report because  EU—ASEAN relations are comprehensive and cover a wide range of sectors, including trade and investment, development, economics and political affairs. I believe that this report comes at the right time, as this year we celebrate the 40th anniversary of our formal relations and the 50th anniversary of ASEAN. ASEAN is one of the world’s most dynamic and fastest growing regions and the potential for the EU to deepen its relations with the region should not be neglected. A good example is that the EU granted the Philippines GSP+ status, and I think that we should advocate the launching of negotiations for a regional EU—ASEAN FTA. Of course we have to address not only the successes, but also the challenges faced by the EU—ASEAN relationship. The EU will continue to place human rights at the centre of its relations with third countries, and ASEAN countries need to comply with human rights standards and promote gender equality and women’s empowerment.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!The region of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is today one of the most dynamically developing regions in the world, also in something that is very important, i.e. new technologies.This region is also very important to us when it comes to maintaining world security, therefore the relations of the European Union with the ASEAN countries should be crucial for us and just as important as relations with, for example, other Asian countries such as China, India or Japan.However, we must remember that within these relations we should develop not only economic and economic cooperation, but also activities for democracy and human rights, climate issues and environmental protection.These should be as important as economic and economic matters.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, the Union is ASEAN's second largest trading partner and the largest provider of direct investment. By 2020, the Union and the Member States have committed more than € 3 billion to reducing poverty and boosting the development of low-income countries. But this financial aid must be conditional on respect for human rights and the financing of civil society, the elimination of abusive arrests and dictatorships. For example, Amnesty calls laws in various countries, such as Malaysia, Thailand and others, draconian. In Malaysia, in November 2016, 15 activists were arrested for demanding electoral reform. Or, in Thailand, in August 2017, student Pai was sentenced to five years in prison for sharing the president's image on Facebook. Many other activists have been arrested and investigated for opposing torture and the dictatorial system. That is, a country where people are not free will never develop and in vain we put money into it.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, I would like to say that developing relations with ASEAN is a step in the right direction.However, it must be said on this occasion that the development of relations is not only economic, but must also be political.We need to have a relatively very open human rights dialogue with a number of ASEAN countries.I do not just mean the situation of the Rohingya now, but we need to talk openly with states such as Vietnam or Laos about what is happening in those states and how human rights are being suppressed here.Personally, I see a huge opportunity in ASEAN.After the United States began to withdraw more or less from this part, I think that Europe can invest quite well here.And it has a very good reputation here, so I believe that relations with these countries will continue to be strengthened.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, on Mr Bütikofer's report, I would like to say that I am very pleased to have pointed out how strategic the ASEAN countries are for us.Indeed, it is the third most important economic destination for our investment and I think it is very important to underline this here.For this reason too, I supported this report.I want to emphasize the role of this space, ie.ASEAN countries in the fight against terrorism.I think it is important to mention.And I would also like to conclude by underlining the fact that America is clearing this area, I consider it a mistake, this is a diplomatic opportunity for the European diplomatic service and for us.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Before adjourning the sitting I would like, on a personal note, to thank the interpreters for the great work they have been doing and continue to do in this Parliament, and also to thank all the departments of the Administration with whom I have really enjoyed working.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Moldova (2017/2848 (RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the last few years have been particularly intense for our relationship with Moldova. There are several reasons for this, including geography and the close ties between our people. But there is one reason in particular I would like to focus on, and that is the kind of relationship that we have proposed to Moldova. A partnership with the European Union is not about spheres of influence and geopolitics. We do not ask our partners to pick sides. They do not have to choose between us and other global powers – this is not how our partnership works. Our partnership is always about improving the life of our citizens, inside the European Union, and of course inside Moldova. It is a partnership for, not against. It is about the economy and trade. It is about democracy, human rights, the rule of law and the fight against corruption. It is with this attitude that we are heading towards our Eastern Partnership Summit next month. This is the spirit that led to the new association agenda that we adopted with Moldova last August, setting out the priorities for the implementation of the association agreement in the coming two years. And this is also the spirit that leads us to speak out when we see new challenges emerge for democracy in Moldova. This is what we did last July when a new electoral law was adopted. Commissioner Hahn and the Vice-President/High Representative said very clearly many times that the new legislation contradicts the recommendations of the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe, and the OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. Both these institutions had pointed towards the importance of broad political consensus on the reform, and of avoiding a system that would expose candidates to the influence of business interests. These suggestions have not been addressed by the new electoral law. Since then, the law has not yet been implemented. The effects of this law on multi-party democracy will depend on how it is implemented. From our side, I can assure you that we will continue to closely monitor developments, particularly on the definition of single-mandate constituencies. I know that you have discussed the electoral law within the framework of the decision on a macro-financial assistance programme for Moldova. This decision has been adopted in agreement with the European Parliament, and entered into force on 23 September 2017. Any payment, though, will depend on the respect by Moldova of political preconditions and by the implementation of a Memorandum of Understanding that we will sign with Moldova. These conditions will include reforms that are necessary to guarantee macro-financial stabilisation, together with the implementation of our Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement. Turning now to reform for business, a healthy economy requires transparency in the financial and public sector; it requires a strong fight against corruption and money laundering; it requires a positive business climate. These are the reforms we will be asking for, because these are the reforms that the people of Moldova expect. As you know, a massive banking fraud was recently unveiled in the country: a comprehensive investigation and the recovery of the diverted funds are also essential to the credibility of Moldova’s economic system. Last year, in 2016, we saw important reform in the energy sector, including on the use of renewable sources: it is now crucial to complete this reform process, with the swift adoption of the energy law. But a strong economy also needs to be supported by a strong and functioning democracy. For this reason, we will continue to monitor how Moldova implements recommendations of international partners regarding the new electoral law. A healthy democracy does not only depend on a good electoral law: it also needs a strong judicial system, a serious fight against corruption, and of course a free and open space for civil society organisations. These are the issues that matter to the people of Moldova, and so these are the issues we care about. Our budget support aims precisely at supporting good reform in these fields. For instance, we have a budget support programme to support reforms in the justice sector, and for the moment we will not transfer any funds related to this programme since there has not been sufficient progress to justify these payments. There are also other pending budget support payments that are linked to democracy, the rule of law and human rights. Turning to assistance now, this is how our partnership works. If you look at our package of assistance for 2017 to 2020, it has a strong focus on projects directly benefiting citizens, for instance on rural development, infrastructure and women’s empowerment. Our assistance aims at supporting the reforms that will move Moldova forward, particularly towards the goal of political association and economic integration with the European Union. The more Moldova does to address its citizens’ needs, the stronger our assistance and support.  When we discuss budget lines and reforms, it may sound like we are talking technicalities. But everything we do has a very concrete impact on the lives of many – in the European Union and in Moldova. It is a partnership for our people, with very practical benefits for both sides. Take the visa liberalisation that allows our citizens to travel freely between the European Union and Moldova, or the reforms that were adopted last year after our Council Conclusions on the Republic of Moldova of February 2016. The European Parliament has been very active in shaping our partnership and making sure that we always focus on what truly matters: helping Moldova become a stronger country with stronger democratic institutions and a stronger economy: a country that can truly address its citizens’ needs.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, in the pre-holiday session we discussed in this Parliament the macro-financial assistance provided to Moldova. We decided by vote to condition the sending of these funds on the observance of the recommendations of the Venice Commission by the Chisinau authorities. I remind you that this prestigious commission had stated very clearly that the transition to a mixed electoral system is not currently recommended for Moldova. What happened two weeks after our discussion and vote in Parliament, with which the Commission and the Council agreed in Chisinau, despising all these references, Parliament voted to amend the electoral law. Why did this happen? We have an explanation at hand because, publicly, President Dodon, a close associate of Putin, and the leader of the Democratic Party, a close associate of our European socialist colleagues, considered that Moldova's number one problem was the elimination of all parties except those on which they themselves lead. In these circumstances, I think it is reasonable to ask the Commission to strictly apply the precondition set and to suspend the transfer of macro-financial assistance. Moreover, I believe that strict monitoring of the implementation of the electoral law and the political evolution of Moldova by the Commission, the European External Action Service and the European Parliament is necessary. I think it would be good for five members of this Parliament to join this monitoring group.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I admit, I almost understand the frustrations of the EPP, and yet I will address in particular Mr McAllister, Mr Brok, who have a solid understanding of the complexity of the situation in the Republic of Moldova. I heard today in the speech of my Romanian colleague the same thesis, an alleged complicity between the Democratic Party and the pro-Russian president Dodon, and I invite you to discuss the facts. I will not discuss the economic part, you know better than me, the economic situation is in favor of the Republic of Moldova and this has been confirmed by the International Monetary Fund and the European Commission. First of all, the Government of the Republic of Moldova participated with military forces in the maneuvers organized by NATO in Ukraine this summer in response to the Zapad 2017 maneuvers. This was done with the opposition of President Dodon. The President of the Republic of Moldova, the pro-Russian Dodon, systematically opposed the two-time nomination of the Minister of Defense. The government of the Republic of Moldova asked the Russian troops to leave Transnistria and did so from the tribune of the United Nations in New York. What is even more important, these days, in the Republic of Moldova, the amendment of the Constitution is being discussed in order to introduce a special article on European integration, so that a future Dodon cannot divert the course of this country. Are these facts complicities with Russia or are they exactly the opposite? Speaking of electoral reform, Commissioner, let us be clear: do those who manipulate the subject of electoral reform forget or do not want to take into account the fact that this law is 100% copy / paste after the electoral law in Germany, is it a democratic law or not? Forget that over 80% of the recommendations of the Venice Commission have been incorporated, is this democratic or not? Forget that we can't judge the appropriateness of passing legislation? In a word, if we do not support Moldova today, we will give it to Russia for free and then we will says at the end "Do svidaniya, Moldova!", but in the hands of the EPP.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Mr Chairman!Commissioner!Since the annexation of Crimea, the choice of the Western option or the Russian option by the society and possibly the Moldovan authorities means the choice of completely different security rules, completely different values, completely different principles of democracy.I am glad that both NATO and the European Union recognize this.Moldova has become the area of a priority project of cooperation between both organizations in the field of cybersecurity.I applaud the security policy of the Moldovan government.I am monitoring progress in this area and I find it interesting, interesting and commendable.Unfortunately, I also see some disturbing signs in this country, one of which is still the media monopoly and the influence of the oligarchs.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, this is the third time in the last five months that we are discussing Moldova in this Chamber. As a standing rapporteur, it is not the kind of attention I would like to see for Moldova so repeatedly.  Let me start by addressing the Moldovan authorities very frankly: the main thing that I miss in Moldovan politics is a critical lack of a real consensus in the national political field. Do not expect Brussels to do it for you. Consensus must be built on a daily basis in Chișinău, Bălți and Comrat. The newly adopted election law was clearly a bulldozer-type move – not what we expect from an EU-associated partner. As a result, respectable international bodies – the Venice Commission and the OSCE – are ignored and bypassed. At home, smaller political parties feel unfairly pressed and even eliminated. Moldovan citizens are waiting for a different type of politics. People, including us in this House, want to see the unimpeded publication of the Kroll 2 investigation report. We all expect no further delay in the identification and bringing to justice of those persons or politicians who are hiding behind this unprecedented bank fraud scandal. At the same time, we continue to be concerned to see biased legal proceedings, such as in the case of Chișinău Mayor, Dorin Chirtoacă. We stress that only an independent and depoliticised judiciary can deliver justice and trust.  I will keep repeating that I see today many missed opportunities for Moldova. As a true friend, I am critical of idea of the European future of Moldova. However, the country will continue losing until the moment when its authorities finally come to the conclusion that building a national consensus in a European way is exactly what makes Moldova’s statehood stronger and consolidates its society.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, as a long-term member of the delegation for cooperation - I underline the word 'cooperation' - I can only welcome the EU-Moldova that the EU systematically contributes, not only financially, to Moldova's aid and development. Moldova has been a member of the Eastern Partnership since its inception, ie since 2009. And I am glad to hear the words that it is a partnership not against someone, but for cooperation. Unfortunately, I am forced to state that so far neither the EU nor the Moldovans themselves have met their expectations. Moldova still remains the poorest country in Europe, corruption is on the rise, the state is de facto led by oligarchs and civil society remains unheard of. We expected the necessary changes in the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organized crime from all previous governments. The internal organization of the state is certainly a matter for every state, but a rational person must ask himself whether the planned concentration of power is in the hands of a single person. I believe that we should evaluate the effectiveness and usefulness of the Eastern Partnership project for all involved. I want to emphasize that the gateway to the Balkans - Moldova - should not become a place of smoldering conflict or another Ukraine.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - It is true what colleagues have said about Moldova. We have spoken many times in this last period, but the situation is no better because of that, and I rightly wonder if it makes sense to send funds to Moldova for its development and assistance, when these funds are disappearing, when in fact the funds from the bank, which mean quite a scandal, they still don’t get a proper epilogue after all this time. The problem in Moldova is only getting worse and corruption is on the rise, and the situation with regard to media freedom and freedom of speech is not ideal and is deteriorating. Non-governmental sectors, non-governmental organizations also talk about mass violations of human rights and, in fact, about the policy of exclusion, about arrests, which of course have nothing to do with democracy and, of course, with a fair trial. And these are signals that the European Parliament must also act on. Also because of this situation, I am convinced that Parliament must also play its part, and I agree with my colleague Predo, who also suggests that the European Parliament be involved in this monitoring of the situation in Moldova, or that we review all these allegations with a special mission.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the international community should support this country on a basis of maintaining strict neutrality on their democratic process. The EUR 100 million euros in grants and loans to Moldova recently approved by the European Union have, of course, the usual strings attached, not least when you consider Parliament’s recent reports underlining your support, given their forthcoming parliamentary elections.  With respect to your comments, Commissioner, this naked ambition to attempt to influence Eastern European nations is just another part of the EU’s neo-colonialism or, as you prefer to call it, foreign policy. Surely the time has come, colleagues, for a different approach. Why not recognise the geographic and cultural dilemmas affecting such countries and, instead of the usual tug-of-war with Russia, use Moldova’s position as a conduit to attempt to build bridges.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: , on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I already knew that Europe could be economic war, because of the principle of competition, which involves war. I know now, and I see every day, that Europe is also political warfare waged in the name of human rights, the rule of law or democracy, with very ambivalent use and, depending on the country, evolving. This neither reinforces integration nor peace, but leads to a division of variable geometry, especially vis-à-vis the unilaterally designated enemy that would be Russia. Should there be Moldovan border controls between Ukraine and Transnistria? Should we set up a NATO information office? Do we need NGOs led by foreign funding to call Moldovan democracy into question at all times? And then let's talk about corruption: never has a system been as corrupt as this one. So what is your policy, Commissioner? Explain me!

name: David McALLISTER
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! In my opinion, the association agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Moldova places particular emphasis on three points: firstly, compliance with democratic principles and the rule of law; secondly, good governance; and thirdly, the observance of fundamental and human rights. Previous speakers have already emphasized: In this country, corruption in particular must be combated to the highest level and the country's judiciary reformed. These urgent reforms need to be pushed forward. I urge those responsible in Chișinău to follow all recommendations of the Venice Commission in the context of electoral reform. Commissioner, I want to make it clear at this point: the European Union is the largest donor of the Republic of Moldova. With this resolution, we as Parliament are making it clear that the ball is in the Moldovan playing field, and if there is no progress in the areas mentioned, this must also have consequences for our financial support. The European neighborhood policy is based on the principle of “more for more”. In contrast, this can also mean “less for less”, and all those responsible in Chișinău must be aware of this.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Skepticism is appropriate, I agree with you. Under so-called pro-European governments, the country has systematically slipped from one scandal to the next, and the people of Moldova don't really know whether this is the European Union's path. No, it's not him! We ourselves made ourselves a bit complicit because we were too nice and sometimes looked away. I think the situation got better today. The economy is starting to recover if you look at the International Monetary Fund, if you look at the World Bank you can read that too. Reforms are being made. Good thing, but not enough and not fast enough - I agree with this criticism. In particular, the reform of the judiciary and the fight against organized crime and corruption must show clear fruits. Nevertheless: The policy towards NGOs and the freedom of the media - we do not want to forget these rights. Suffrage reform is a sensitive issue in every country. Nobody can tell the government in Chișinău what kind of electoral system they want. But it should listen carefully to the Venice Commission when it comes to introducing and implementing the law. I think that is really in your best interest, even after what Mr McAllister said. Last sentence: I have a lot of confidence in the Commission and the External Action Service. We don't want to start questioning that by always preferring to travel ourselves and then dissolving the agency. We have not yet discussed in our group whether we like what you have proposed. I consider this particular point to be excessive and also not necessary. I trust Ms. Mogherini and her staff.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - The new Moldovan electoral law of 20 July implies a further undermining of exactly a democratic constitutional state. After all, this politically transparent legislation aims to banish or marginalize any potential opposition. That does not bode well for next year's autumn parliamentary elections. That brings me to a question: in this worrying situation, should the European Union simply proceed to provide EUR 100 million of macro-financial aid to Moldova in installments? Commission, how does this relate to the joint statement by the Council, the Commission and Parliament, which specifically calls for a rule of law assessment for precisely this kind of aid? I am not asking this without haste, because in the Netherlands there are numerous private foundations - I was also part of it myself, I was involved in Moldova - that want to have the heart in hand for Moldova, but that should be possible on the basis of a democratic constitutional state that functions and that is not the case.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: - Mr President, the association agreement with the Republic of Moldova concerns the citizens of the Republic of Moldova and I believe that, in the concerns of every European politician, this must be a priority, not the political games aimed at strengthening one party or another. Hello, Commissioner, your approach to financial assistance. Projects that directly target the well-being of citizens must continue, because only in this way can the European Union be relevant and bring well-being in this part of the world that is so controversial, so poor and so difficult to position in a security strategy. in this area. Otherwise, it would mean that the 100 million will probably come directly from Moscow in a few years, and Brussels will be irrelevant and it is a pity for what we have invested in support of Moldovan citizens, who are European citizens. Reforms continue. Economic growth is 4%. There are, of course, issues to be resolved, but these with the support of the European Union, and not otherwise, will bring prosperity to the Republic of Moldova.

name: Rebecca HARMS
