text: - Mister President! A word on electoral reform first: Well, I think that this reform, as society is polarized about it, should not be done a year before the next election. That is also the main criticism of the Venice Commission of all this preparation of those who are now governing Moldova. I believe that this electoral reform will not lead to politicians becoming more reliable and less corruption in the political elite. That would be better achieved - and the Venice Commission also said this - if the party funding were made transparent and if there were finally more and independent media in Moldova. Despite this criticism, I believe that it is very important that the European Union is reliable towards Moldova. We have a way of doing something through the implementation of the Association Agreement. However, we should not give our macro-financial support unconditionally. The citizens of Moldova in particular want us to tie our money to successes in the fight against corruption.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Mister President!The Republic of Moldova remains one of the poorest European countries and is being held hostage by the corruption of a few oligarchs.Between 2007 and 2015, the Union transferred € 782 million in financial aid and, according to President-in-Office Igor Dodon, at least half of that amount has disappeared.Now you can say: Yes and, the Lord is Moscow-oriented and therefore so politically motivated.However, under the pro-European governing coalition of the Alliance for European Integration, half a billion has perished and disappeared in the corruption swamp.A further approximation should therefore be considered.Further financial support for Moldova should be considered rationally in view of this wild corruption and should not arise from the political desire to evidently provoke Russia once again.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: - Mr President, at the last meeting here in Strasbourg, the President of the Commission presented in his speech the proposal that this autumn the Commission come up with a roadmap for the integration of Serbia and Montenegro. I regret that Moldova is not in this package. A few years ago he was making great efforts and progress. Unfortunately, lately, things have gone differently. There are many things that are not in order in Moldova: we are talking about the rule of law, about corruption, about many things that do not make Moldova a state that can be a candidate state. But at the same time, the European Union has a neighborhood policy that wants to bring peace to Europe's borders. All such partnership agreements or association agreements are made for this purpose. That is why I believe that we must continue this policy. It is true, in the case of such states, in my opinion, there is only one possibility: conditions, then the fulfillment of these conditions and then the money. I think this is the path we should follow.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – Mr President, today’s debate demonstrates that, notwithstanding the many challenges the EU is confronted with, the Republic of Moldova is and remains a top priority for the Union and for this House. While many domestic and external challenges are still present, my feeling is that finally Moldova is back on track.  Let me be very clear, the Filip government is delivering results. The state of crisis of 2015 has been replaced by steady progress on important reforms. The economic situation has stabilised with many indicators showing solid improvement. It is a fact! Political association and economic integration with the EU through the provisions of the Association Agreement and the DCFTA are proceeding at a stable pace. The next months will be crucial to confirming this positive trend. This is why all political forces must overcome the polarised political climate ahead of the electoral period and engage in constructive dialogue, taking into account the real needs and expectations of the citizens.  The EU and the European Parliament are looking forward to working with both the majority and the opposition to this end. As always, we stand ready to assist the Republic of Moldova through all the means at our disposal. Let me be very clear, and I have this advice from my colleagues from the EPP Group: we should work together, not bash ourselves!

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, Moldova has received over € 300,000,000 from the European Union over the last three years for judicial, administrative and infrastructure reforms. Why? Because we want Moldova to join the European family. But Dodon and Plahotniuc continue their project to take Moldova off the European road. We opposed the uninominal vote in Moldova, for example, as recommended by the Venice Commission, because it only served Putin's oligarchs and friends and did not benefit the population, whose vote would have been corrected and counted incorrectly. They ignored him, they ignored us in our decision and the Venice Commission and they voted the uninominal vote. Moldova lives on European money, not on Plahotniuc's money, not on Dodon's money and not on Russia's money. Moldova must stop hypocrisy, the political class in Moldova must stop hypocrisy and must be sanctioned by conditioning financial support on respect for democratic principles and not to steal money from the European Union.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - I would like to draw your attention to the importance that Moldova plays in foreign policy.Moldova is a litmus test for the EU's external relations mechanisms.It is a poor and not very well-run country that needs help with both sustainable development and good governance.It is a country of frozen conflicts - the Transnistrian problem is as painful as the Northern Cyprus problem.In Moldova, the desire of the country's citizens to get closer to Europe intersects and Russia's reluctance to let go of its control.And the situation is further complicated by a weak local government embroiled in internal conflicts, whose activities have recently called into question its compatibility with democratic principles.Europe should send a clear message that rapprochement with Europe and the opening up of markets and support are only possible in exchange for democratic, law enforcement and market reforms.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yes to a European Moldova, yes to a Moldova in the Europe of nations, in partnership with Russia. Today you want to make Moldova Ukraine. This is a great scenario that no one wants. Moldova is an independent and sovereign country, and you are not Romanians who will ignore this historical fact. Moldova is a great nation, even though its population is only three million. Today, the European Union wants to initiate reforms for Moldova, instead of Moldova. It has thus planned to devote 2.8 million euros to administrative reform and territorial reform. I believe in respecting the sovereignty of nations. Moldova is an independent state, a state situated between east and west, a state from which one must, of course, seek approval for its participation. Today, it is true that Moldova has refused, along with its President, Mr. Dodon, to participate in NATO commitments. I personally believe in respecting the sovereignty of this state.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues! In many elections, the Moldovan population opted for Western European politics. Second: At their own request, they received an association and free trade agreement, which they ratified, and it says that this must be developed, including the internal development towards the rule of law against corruption. What is important is that the country itself should have progress for its citizens, because the rule of law and anti-corruption are a condition for further investment and jobs. I do not know, colleague, what should be wrong with that. This is an agreement that should be there. We have to realize that we have to support Moldova so that it can defend its independence against its neighbor who wants to destroy this independence! That's where the aggression lies when, for example, one refers to the Transnistrian question. And one last remark: you shouldn't do that with a franchise that is prone to manipulation. If you can win constituencies and that does not count towards the overall result and then you can get mandates again from the lists, then you can get 80% of the mandates with 50% of the votes and so on. This is a method of voting that is incorrect, and for this reason it is a wrong bet.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - Mr Chairman!Commissioner!Ladies and gentlemen!Three hundred and thirty-five million euros over three years, the Union transferred to Moldova.It seems like a lot of money.Of course, we require this money to be put to good use.On the other hand, there is a geopolitical match going on in Moldova at the moment between us, the West, the Union, and Russia.It must also be taken into account that there is a pro-European government and a pro-Russian president.It takes special diplomacy and wisdom to support the pro-European forces in this country and also to show the society of this country to what extent this country can become part of the Russian sphere of influence with all its geopolitical consequences.I am in favor of this help from the Union being as large as possible and that it should move Moldova towards Europe, only towards political Europe, because Moldova is in Europe.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, I would say to the Commissioner that Moldova has certainly reached a crossroads. This is a warning, but it could yet become an incentive for hope and progress. Political and social stability have been seriously undermined and, as has been pointed out, the lack of national consensus about the European road is a warning signal. We have been critical of the latest electoral law which, as the Venice Commission has warned, could favour the influence of oligarchs and disadvantage minorities and women. But, to be fair, this is not about the laws as such: it is about the possible misuse of a law in the short-term interests of political and economic groups. The truth is that Moldova represents a warning of the long-term, devastating impact of foreign-imposed frozen conflict that the international community has not been willing or able to address. Therefore, we should support the request for the Moldovan Government to include the withdrawal of Russian troops on the General Assembly’s agenda, because this promise, which should have been fulfilled 15 years ago, in 2002, is still unfulfilled. We certainly remain committed to supporting Moldova, but we have to remind the Moldovan authorities that granting micro-financial assistance has to be conditional on their meeting European and democratic standards for civil society.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! There is nothing to suggest that the European Union should abandon the adopted strategy of explicit support for Moldova's freedom and European aspirations. One of the UKIP deputies spoke here about an abuse by the European Union, about neo-colonialism, about political neutrality. Well, there is no political neutrality in this world: either Moldova will be part of the European family or it will be in the sphere of Russian influence. However, the help cannot be naive and unconditional, so this realistic voice is absolutely worthy of support. We must expect the fight against corruption, the healing of the judiciary, genuine political freedom and media pluralism, not only for European expectations but also for Moldova's interests. Moldova, which does not heal itself, will condemn itself to be present in the Russian sphere of influence. If she heals herself, she will be able to share a common fate with the peoples of Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: Question "blue card".- Only to ask if in the electoral law there are provisions to help the many Moldovans living abroad - in Italy there are 135,000 - putting them in a position to participate in the vote.I ask, therefore, if this can be a further element of discussion.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- Absolutely, that is, such expectations should be considered.Expectations of genuine freedom, competition and freedom of choice should be even more weighed up, so absolutely such expectations are worth supporting.However, the strategic direction is important - whether we support Moldova's European aspirations with good will or not.I am in favor of the first solution.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Mr Chairman! Just before the Eastern Partnership Summit, we would like to see a completely different debate on Moldova, and that is less than a year after the entry into force of the association agreement with the free trade area. We also know that visa traffic has good results, but it is difficult not to raise this topic, because agreements are mutual obligations. When we have problems with fighting corruption, with the appropriation of public funds, when we have problems with the justice system, also these signals about changes in the democratic system in Moldova itself. I would like to remind you that on May 22, the parliamentary association committee welcomed, inter alia, the National Action Plan until 2019, which was adopted by Moldova. Now it should be filled with content, in particular when it comes to the procedure in legislation. Transnistria, of course, is a permanent problem, which has a huge impact on the internal situation in Moldova, we cannot ignore it, and this is perhaps one of the elements that justifies what is happening in Moldova a bit, but on the other hand, it is difficult to accept other matters. I think that this statement by the Commissioner that civil society should be supported is a good direction, Commissioner. It is always the case that when we try to straighten the state and its governance a little, we should not punish civil society and it seems to me that it is extremely important. I am also pleased to say that we accept this joint declaration by the Speakers of the Parliaments of Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine, which refers to the Eastern Partnership Summit. This is also a good signal, coming from national parliaments after all.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! This morning there was a stormy debate on the state of the Brexit negotiations. Great Britain leaves the Union. On the other hand, as recently triumphantly announced by the head of the Juncker Commission, the EU is hoping to accept other countries. Moldova is also waiting in the EU vestibule. The country signed a partnership and cooperation agreement with the European Union 23 years ago. Three years ago he signed an association agreement. However, it is still far from meeting the EU criteria. The European Union is opposed to the changes to Moldova's electoral law. It demands an effective fight against corruption, and also threatens the Venice Commission. In hard pursuit of ideological standards, some people seem to overlook the fact that Moldova, with the population of 3.5 million, is one of the poorest European countries, and that Russia is taking advantage of its internal problems. If we fix ourselves in the EU's rhetoric, it may soon turn out that this country will terminate the association agreement and find itself in the EU, but in the Eurasian one.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to repeat that we have been standing behind Moldova’s pro-European ambitions and have had high hopes for its involvement in our joint projects. Yet now I am very concerned about the deterioration of the rule of law and democratic standards in the Republic of Moldova. We have seen the  intimidation and harassment of pro—European political opposition and the disregarding of the recommendations of the Venice Commission to change the electoral system. It is clear that the changes in the electoral law directly undermine democratic standards in the country. The recent internal political developments in Moldova are nowhere near the positive momentum we witnessed three years ago. The implementation of the Association Agenda is lagging behind and it is clear that it needs to become a priority of the political leadership. I would like to appeal to the High Representative and the Commission to make use of our external policy instruments in order to bring the country back to democratic standards. We in the European Parliament stand ready to support Moldova on its European path and its reform process. This can happen, however, only once we see real commitment to a pro—European path and respect for democratic values from the leaders of the country.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. The real stakes of our relationship with the Republic of Moldova are the following: one - the reforms that the citizens of the Republic of Moldova are waiting for, and two - the increase of the support of the citizens of the Republic of Moldova for the European course of the Republic of Moldova. The Republic of Moldova needs profound judicial reforms, the fight against corruption, public administration and many other areas. People are waiting for these reforms, and we must use all the tools at our disposal to accelerate the pace of reforms. We must not be afraid to apply conditionalities for the financial support we apply to the Republic of Moldova. On the contrary, conditionality is what the citizens of the Republic of Moldova expect. Citizens of the Republic of Moldova no longer want to give blank checks. Only by being firm in supporting these reforms will we have the support of the citizens. We have to be honest. The parliamentary majority in Chisinau changed the electoral legislation despite the opinion of the Venice Commission and the alarm signals sounded by the European Commission and lost, as such, our confidence. Satisfying ourselves with mimicking the reform process means being naive and losing the support of the citizens of the Republic of Moldova for the European integration process. As general rapporteur for the budget of the European Union, I have proposed since the beginning of the year several funds for the eastern neighborhood, including the Republic of Moldova, but this money should be used where it is needed.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I have listened very carefully to this debate and I personally believe that - at least for me - two conclusions follow, including for the representatives of the Commission.Firstly, in my opinion, it must be made clear to the Moldovan authorities that the reform of the electoral law that has been adopted is unacceptable to us.I think it is necessary to be unequivocal in this, to have a clear position and to criticize the state authorities clearly.On the other hand, we should in no way limit financial assistance to Moldova.If we clear the area and withdraw from Moldova, Russia will occupy that area geopolitically.Russia is waiting for our aid to the former Soviet satellites to be curtailed, reduced, and Russia itself filled this space with power.So please, Commissioner, let us support the civil society sector in Moldova financially, let us help the Moldovans further, bearing in mind that the fight with Russia for this territory is still ongoing.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: - Mr President, I believe that those requesting the suspension of the financial agreement and financial assistance to the Republic of Moldova want to see this country taken to the Eurasian Union, where Mr Dodon wants to take it - Mr Dodon, who is doing everything possible to be included inthe negative, dark side of the short history of the Republic of Moldova.The citizens of the Republic of Moldova want a European path and we must think that next year, in 2018, there will be parliamentary elections.Now is the time to support the European course of the Republic of Moldova more than ever.Ladies and gentlemen, this is an important moment and we must not miss it.At the same time, I ask you, Commissioner, to ask the European Commission, the European Parliament and other institutions, when they talk about Moldova, to use the correct term Republic of Moldova, because Moldova is also a part of Romania.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, it is absolutely right that the citizens of Moldova want European integration. Unfortunately, the political situation in Moldova is getting very complicated and embarrassing. We are witnessing continuing confrontation and, indeed, political deadlock between pro-Western and pro-Eastern forces in the country. In this context, I urge all political leaders and parties in Moldova to engage in constructive dialogue in order to ensure democracy, the rule of law and political stability there. I strongly believe that politicians in Moldova should focus their efforts on important issues for the future of the country and implement crucial political and economic reforms in order to provide better living standards for all Moldovans. The EU has the capacity to play the essential role of facilitator, on the one hand for political dialogue among the country’s political factions and, on the other, for the implementation of sorely needed reforms.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union and Moldova: are we a player or just a payer? While the Moldovan Parliament adopted a reform of the electoral system, passing to a system heavily criticized also by the Venice Commission, for the enormous advantages for the ruling party, the ink was still fresh on our decision to grant macro-financial assistance. And this is just the tip of the iceberg. The recent amendments to the new law on NGOs, if adopted, would seriously undermine the activity of civil society, often the only bulwark in the country against rampant corruption. While on the colossal billion dollar bank fraud, after three years all is still silent. As a former election observer in the country, my wish and that of many is to one day see Moldova, together with us in the family of the European Union. But our benevolence must not be mistaken for stupidity. I believe it is appropriate, if the Moldovan government does not promptly retrace its steps, to reassess the granting of macro-financial assistance to direct it instead to projects and programs in full support of civil society.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the case of Moldova is another example of the wrong foreign policy pursued by the European Union. Although the European Union has provided huge sums of money to Moldova since 2005, this money has not been used to develop sectors that would provide jobs, such as industry and agriculture, but to open some markets of interest to the European Union. This has enabled the forces of the country's internal establishment and corruption to exploit this money, to misuse it, to create an economic vacuum of one billion dollars in three banks of the country and in general to collapse the economy. of the country. The catastrophe of the country took its toll on the measures taken against Russia by the countries of the European Union, because Russia is the main supplier of gas to Moldova and the largest importer of the country's products. On this basis, I believe that if the European Union does not reconsider its position, it will lose this small ally.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: - Mr President, this debate on the Republic of Moldova is welcome. Of all the Eastern Partnership countries, the Republic of Moldova is perhaps the most successful example. The European direction has been maintained, despite much pressure from the east, and I am obviously referring to Russia. However, there is information and worrying evidence about the state of democracy, enticements, threats and pressure on some parliamentarians or local elected officials to change their political choice in relation to the change of electoral legislation. The European Commission must take all possible steps, as firmly and decisively as possible, to ensure that Moldova's commitments are respected and that democracy and the rule of law work, perhaps even reflecting on the establishment of a structure within the European Commission to monitor , especially in the judicial field. And, of course, if all these steps do not work, we can also talk about financial sanctions, although I am afraid that they will affect more ordinary citizens and less those who lead the Republic of Moldova today.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr President, like Ukraine, Moldova is torn between the European Union and Russia. Our duty is to do everything to ensure that it recognizes itself in European values, and the help we give it must contribute to this. The electoral law, democracy and the independence of the judiciary are obviously part of these values. The single party is not in our conception of democracy, but we must also promote the economic development of Moldova, which has interesting mineral resources, and fight against poverty. In my opinion, it is from this progress that there will be an awareness of the Moldovan people. If we are not to interfere directly in the governance of Moldova, we must bring these values ​​to the people and we would be well inspired, it seems to me, to ensure that part of this aid is devoted to media pluralism. In any case, Moldova can in no case become a new Crimea.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, three years ago the Union and Moldova signed an Association Agreement, including the Free Trade Agreement, and Moldova became the first partner country to benefit from the visa waiver regime. The aim was to support the country for political, social and economic reform, in order to strengthen democratization and good governance, energy security and economic and social development. Instead, $ 1 billion disappeared from the three largest banking institutions in two days. The country's population has shrunk by 10% in a country with 2.9 million remaining citizens, with 600,000 living permanently abroad and 350,000 coming and going in neighboring countries to survive. The country has been plunged into an energy and agricultural crisis by the effects of Union sanctions on Russia. It therefore makes sense for Moldovan citizens to turn to Russia. The Union should have realized that money does not buy the national mindset. Such policies are doomed to fail.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I will have a different approach. I think we have to start from the main goal. Our main goal is for the Republic of Moldova to continue on the road to the European Union. Obviously we need to have two aids from the European Union: one, the financial one - and I don't agree with what my EPP colleagues have said, we can't punish a people - and the other is to focus on how we can provide them an advice to pro-European forces to be able to respond and to have good results next year. We cannot be stuck in the fact that the Parliament of the Republic of Moldova voted to amend the law. President Dodon's public speech, critical of the European Union and NATO, shows that he is already preparing for the upcoming elections. What do we do? We need to talk to the pro-European forces to unite, to have a speech, to have a strategy so as to avoid another mandate for Dodon. I think that this should be the strategy, Commissioner, not simply to suspend funding and assistance to the Republic of Moldova because it is strategic: the Republic of Moldova is important for the whole region, not just for the citizens of the Republic of Moldova.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange and I thank the speakers for their contributions. From this debate I conclude that we share the opinion that it is important to continue supporting the Republic of Moldova with its reform agenda. Secondly, I understand your concerns in relation to the rule of law and democracy. Let me assure you that the European Union will consider thoroughly any decision on future assistance and that these decisions will be consistent with messages transmitted as part of our political dialogue. At the same time, I would like to repeat our position about the partnership. The partnership with the European Union is not about spheres of influence and geopolitics. We do not ask our partners to pick sides – they do not have to choose between us and other global powers. This is not how our partnership works. Our partnership is about improving the lives of our citizens inside the European Union, and of citizens in Moldova. It is a partnership for, not against. It is about the economy and trade. It is about democracy, human rights, the rule of law and, of course, the fight against corruption. It is with this attitude that we are heading towards our Eastern Partnership Summit next month. Thank you for your attention and for this fruitful discussion.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place in a future part-session.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - We were surprised at the amount of the budget allocated to Moldova (1 billion euros over 10 years, or 100 million per year), in a country with 3 million inhabitants ... We were surprised at such an amount then even as our Member States are in dire need of this budget, and even as the EU is imposing, here and there, an austerity policy ... The Commission's answer to our written question, given by Mr Hahn on the 6th September 2017 was a first line of thought: "prior to the granting of aid, account will be taken of satisfactory compliance with a vast set of political conditions (...)", that is to say, allow me a political translation: "if you want this money, accept our intrusion into your sovereignty"! For example, Christos Stylianides insisted, during this session, on the reform of justice, a particularly regal sector. Moreover, certain interventions by my colleagues constitute a second track: that of an ever more irrational fight against Russia. We are in favor of a Moldova in a Europe of nations without interference in its sovereignty, as we explained during the vote in July.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question on the eradication of the practice of child marriage, addressed to the Commission by Vilija Blinkevičiūtė, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (O – 000064/2017 - B8–0328/2017) (2017/2663 (RSP)).

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Author. - In developing countries, one in three girls marries before the age of 18 and one in nine marries before the age of 15. Both boys and girls suffer from child marriage, but girls, who make up 82 percent. married children are at greatest risk. And this problem is relevant not only in third countries, but also in Europe. Under Article 3 of the Treaty on European Union, the EU promotes the protection of the rights of the child, but early and forced marriages of children are a violation of these rights. One of the goals of the United Nations for sustainable development is to eliminate all harmful practices, including early and forced marriages of children. In addition, the elimination of early and forced marriages of children is included as one of the EU's priorities in the Joint Staff Working Document "Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment: Changing the Lives of Girls and Women in EU External Relations (2016-2020)", 2015-2020. 2019 The EU Action Plan on Human Rights and the Action Plan on Gender Equality, which emphasizes the need to ensure that women and girls can fully enjoy all human rights and fundamental freedoms. The EU has recently decided to sign the Istanbul Convention, which considers forced marriage to be a form of violence against women and calls for the measures set out therein to be extended to boys and men, as they may also be victims of forced marriage. The Convention requires the coercion of a child to marry and the lure of the child to another country in order to compel the marriage to be considered a crime. Early and forced marriages are highly detrimental to the overall realization of and access to the rights of girls and women, as well as to the health of girls, including the high risk of complications of pregnancy, often resulting in death, and HIV infection. Premature marriages put girls at risk of becoming victims of sexual abuse, domestic violence, and even honor killings. We must also appreciate the fact that there are very different officially registered ones the number of cases and potential victims requesting assistance, which shows that many marriages of children can take place without the attention of the authorities. It is therefore essential that social workers, teachers and other staff who deal directly with potential victims are provided with specific training and guides that explain how to identify victims and initiate assistance procedures for them. I would also like to remind you that Parliament condemns the renewal and extension of the non-funding rule for abortion support organizations and its impact on global health care for women and girls and their rights. And here I want to call once again on the EU and the Member States to fill the funding gap that has already opened up in the field of sexual and reproductive health with national and EU development funds. So the questions are for the Commissioner: how does the Commission assess the impact of projects and campaigns to combat child marriage and the level of funding allocated to this purpose in all the European Union's external actions? Does the Commission take account of child marriage rates in its cooperation agreements and does it set specific benchmarks to eradicate this phenomenon? What steps are being taken to ensure the protection of the rights and health of all children in the Member States of the European Union, including sexual and reproductive health and rights, in the event of child marriage and to apply harmonized legal standards, including the European Union's intention to ratify the Istanbul Convention? Finally, how do the Commission and the Member States deal with the issue of child marriage, especially with regard to refugee minors and asylum seekers? Thank you and we look forward to hearing from you, Commissioner.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the Commission’s position is absolutely clear. We cannot accept or tolerate any kind of violence, including forced marriage. But it is a complex problem which cannot be solved at one stroke. As for question 1, we are participating in comprehensive programmes to put an end to harmful practices such as child marriage. Their impact can only be measured in the long term over generations. For example, in 2016 the EU contributed EUR 6 million to the UNICEF United Nations Population Fund Global Programme to Accelerate Action to End Child Marriage. This programme works at local, national and regional level and targets the communities of 12 countries. The objective is to improve access to services, strengthen enforcement mechanisms, increase girls’ empowerment and challenge social norms, so that girls can fully enjoy their childhood and grow up to control their own destiny. In 2019, when this programme comes to an end, we shall evaluate its quantitative impact using the quantitative indicators. The same applies to other ongoing projects to address child marriage which we are supporting in Tanzania, Niger, Mali, Malawi, Lesotho and Sudan. Beyond this targeted support, the EU also contributes to programmes dedicated to social protection, access to education, violence against children, and access to justice and health, including sexual and reproductive health and rights. They also contribute to a reduction in child marriage. As for question 2, accession to the Istanbul Convention is a priority for the Commission. The criminalisation of forced marriage based on the definition of the Istanbul Convention will remain a matter of Member State competence. However, many victims of forced marriage, especially underaged, may fall victim to other serious forms of gender-based crime, such as rape. This offence is criminalised in all EU Member States. The Victims’ Rights Directive provides for targeted and integrated support for victims with specific needs, such as victims of sexual violence, victims of gender—based violence and victims of violence in close relationships, including trauma support and counselling or shelter for victims in need of a safe place. The EU’s accession to the Istanbul Convention would further strengthen the Union’s framework on protection of and support to victims of forced marriage and other crimes covered by the Convention. For instance, the Istanbul Convention will require the EU to ensure that resident status is granted to victims of gender-based violence, which could be independent from that of the spouse, and that victims may obtain the suspension of expulsion. The Convention requires that gender-based violence against women be recognised as a form of persecution under the Geneva Convention and that the obligation of non—refoulement is applied to women victims in need of protection where they might be subject to torture or inhuman treatment or punishment. As regards sexual and reproductive health, the Istanbul Convention provides for a prohibition of forced abortion and sterilisation, for instance, abortion without full and informed consent. It does, however, not contain provisions regarding rights to safe abortion or as to whether abortion in unsafe conditions constitutes violence against women. On 25 November 2016 the Commission launched a year of focused actions to combat violence against women. The focused actions, which involve local, national and EU-level initiatives, aim to mobilise, connect and support all relevant stakeholders in combating the problem and to ensure the dissemination of good practices across the EU.  Let me now answer question 3. Married minors are also considered vulnerable under the EU asylum acquis and therefore benefit from special rights and procedural guarantees. It will often be the case that the law or practice of the responsible Member State does not recognise an adult spouse as being responsible for a minor spouse. Therefore, if the minor spouse travels only with the adult spouse and is not accompanied by her parents or tutor, the married minor would often be considered unaccompanied and thus in need of special guarantees. Moreover, non—consensual child marriages are prohibited by international law. The authorities of the Member State of arrival have an obligation to verify if the minor has consented to the marriage. If this is not the case, the child must be offered protection. This issue is to be distinguished from the separate matter of whether the legal effects of the marriage undertaken in the country of origin or prior to arrival in the EU can or cannot be recognised according to the national law of the Member State responsible.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, today we give a voice to the 750 million girls forced to marry around the world. Let’s say together: enough is enough! Child marriage is child abuse. Girls are exposed to rape, domestic and even honour violence. It can be devastating for their health, with serious risks concerning pregnancy and infections.  Child marriage is a crime recognised under the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women. Once again, I call on all Member States to ratify and enforce the Convention, to combat impunity and protect girls. Many girls seeking asylum arrive in Europe married – in Sweden alone there are132. Authorities must consider the best interests of the child. A child is first of all a child, and we cannot have parallel communities in Europe where child marriage is tolerated. There is no tradition and no culture that can justify child abuse.  Girls forced to marry are forced out of school. Desperate parents give away daughters to older men to save them from poverty. But on the contrary, early marriage condemns girls to poverty and discrimination. Education is the best chance for girls to be empowered. No child should be deprived of their childhood.  Civil society plays a key role. The Girls not Brides global partnership, UNICEF, ombudsmen and many others in civil society deserve more support. President Trump’s global gag rules will affect projects for thousands and of girls who are victims of child marriage. Europe should step in and provide resources.  I call on the High Representative on the Commission to do more in all EU external action to eliminate child marriage by helping countries to adopt and to enforce legislation. We need to combat stereotypes, change mentalities, work with family and community leaders and break the vicious circle of submission and violence.  Mr President, in conclusion, as author of the European People’s Party Group resolution and co-Chair of the Intergroup on Children’s Rights, I call for your support. This Parliament should join forces and send a clear message – we are committed to a zero-tolerance policy on child marriage. It is time to act.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, on many occasions we have used this House, this European Parliament, to debate and to put on the table all the issues related to gender equality, women's rights and also the rights of children and girls. For this reason, I believe that bringing this debate here today is something important and essential. I have an eight-year-old niece: she plays, goes to school, she is a happy, independent girl and she is a girl who is living her age. And she shouldn't say this, but she is a lucky girl to be born where she was born, because she was born in a country, in a family where gender equality is an essential issue. We cannot allow from this side of history that there are girls who do not have that opportunity to enjoy their childhood because they are forced to marry, to contract these marriages that we are talking about today. There is data that puts us on the table as a stark reality: in developing countries, one in three girls marries before turning eighteen and one in nine before turning fifteen. The cooperation and development policy of the European Union regarding these developing countries must have the gender perspective within its essence and be able to enable girls born in other countries to have the same opportunities and the same rights as European girls.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! “Did you come here to make the covenant with your bride after careful consideration and of your own free will?” This question is at the beginning of every Christian wedding in Europe. It's an important question: by choice? Unfortunately, this cannot be taken for granted worldwide. 700 million women worldwide are forcibly married, more than 250 million of them were under 15 years old at the time of the so-called marriage. Every year, 15 million girls around the world are married before they are of legal age - this corresponds to a child marriage every two seconds. And that's not a cultural peculiarity, it's not a trivial offense. No, anyone who forcibly marries children is abusing them. Anyone who abuses children is committing a crime. Europe is determined to fight child marriage worldwide - so it is written. It becomes far less clear when we go to the national level. Most Member States have now banned child marriages, but few take effective action against marriages already concluded abroad. These have increased significantly with the current refugee crisis. My passionate appeal is: zero tolerance against child marriages, even if they were concluded abroad! The well-being of the girls must be our goal, their future must be all of our help. Where we snatch them from the hands of their tormentors, we must catch them gently in careful hands. That - and only that - should be our common goal today: No to child marriage! They are girls, not brides.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Jourová, child marriage is a global problem that occurs in different countries, cultures, religions and ethnicities. It denies girls their right to health, education, living safely and choosing who to marry and, if so, when and how. Without economic independence, girls drop out of education and are trapped, along with their families and communities, in a cycle of poverty. In more than 20 countries around the world, a girl is more likely to cross the threshold of the conjugal bedroom than that of her high school class. To combat the phenomenon of girl-brides we need a holistic and comprehensive approach, which is adjusted to local contexts and the particularities of each community. We need true coordination of various sectors, including education, health, justice and economic development. Ending child marriage requires targeting the most affected countries with significant and well-targeted investments, both from international donors and governments. We must also cut development aid to those countries that refuse to limit the minimum age of marriage to 18. Although we should not forget what happens in Europe due to the lack of legal harmonization: in Spain, in my country, the minimum age to marry is still 16 years. But the most important thing is to empower girls. We must work directly with them so that they can acquire skills and knowledge, so that they see the possibilities they have to choose from with real cases, so that they understand and exercise their rights and create their authentic support networks. These reforms would be simple and effective and would show that the European Union not only speaks about values, but that it really reinforces them, all over the world.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, a modern slave market is evolving in front of us. The victims, however, do not wear torn and dirty clothes, but wedding dresses and suits. What does the study tell us? If current trends continue until 2030, it is estimated that 150 million child brides will be married before the age of 18. That is why we demand the immediate implementation of the Istanbul Convention, which condemns forced marriages. And I call on the Commission, first, to regulate pan-European the criminalization of forcing children into marriage as well as their deliberate transfer to another country for that marriage. Secondly, to ensure that every unaccompanied refugee child has a legal representative, who will guarantee his respect and his rights.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! Child and forced marriage is an abuse and a symptom of sick norms that exist in our societies. It can not be accepted. Children have an inviolable right to be children. Girls and boys around the world must be allowed to develop at their own pace into safe and strong individuals. Only in this way do we ensure sustainable development and living space for everyone. It's disappointing to look at the numbers: 37,000 underage girls are getting married every day. There are 14 million child and forced marriages every year. If we are to meet the enormous challenges facing the world, we must strengthen women's rights. Women must be given economic self-determination and the right to their own bodies. For every prevented child marriage, the risk of children dying in a cot decreases and that difficult births lead to illness and infant death. It is the EU's duty to combat the phenomenon of child and forced marriage on all fronts. Member States must ensure that the authorities have sufficient knowledge to recognize the phenomenon and resources and legal support to deal with the situation. The message is clear: We do not accept child and forced marriage.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, kind Commissioner, thanks also to the support of various associations in the area, we raised the issue of early marriages within the European Union in the FEMM committee, proposing the presentation of a question with a request for an answer oral with relative resolution. Here, why this urgency? Because every year millions of girls travel from Member States to their parents' homelands to enter into an unwanted and unwanted marriage, granted by their parents to adult men. Millions of girls who every year see their dream of living free and fulfilling professionally vanish. Just last month an Italian journalistic investigation denounced the annual disappearance of thousands of girls between thirteen and seventeen years of age, sent to Bangladesh, Pakistan and other countries, to marry a distant relative much older than them. But these girls were born and raised in Europe, they attended European schools and culture, they are in all respects European. Unfortunately, there is a lack of reliable data and it is for this reason that today we strongly ask the Commission to become aware of the seriousness of the problem, at the same time inviting the Member States to monitor the risky situations present within them and to increase the penalties against these real and own rapes perpetrated on minors.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: , on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, children are our future and, as such, must be protected. Child marriage is a violation of their rights. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child states in its article 3 that "in all decisions taken by an authority, the best interests of the child must be a primary consideration". Marrying a child therefore clearly goes against their best interests, which are to build themselves up and to benefit, as far as possible, from the protection of a family environment until they come of age. In addition to the violation of this basic right, the wasted future life of these children, there are an estimated 70,000 deaths a year due to pregnancy or childbirth and a staggering death rate among the children of these children. It is essential to remember that child marriage functions as a social and ancestral norm in these countries, often in the process of development. But what to do after this observation? As you specify in your text, it is a good thing to fight against this phenomenon in collaboration with third countries, provided that we do not go beyond the framework of cooperation and that we do not invest in it. 'interventionism. You admit that with the migration crisis, the number of already married children in Europe is increasing, and yet you persist in your crazy immigration and reception policy.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, there is no doubt that child marriage, especially of children in pre-adolescence or early adolescence, is, for the sake of Western culture, to be rejected and condemned. Forced marriage is abhorrent at any age, especially when it comes to minors. Fortunately, as far as I know, the legal framework in all the countries of the Union is to a large extent sufficient, and our societies, with few exceptions of certain social groups, do not accept such practices. Unfortunately, however, with the dramatic increase in illegal immigration and the influx into Europe of population groups from countries with completely different cultures and morals, this phenomenon tends to take on alarming proportions. To address such practices we need to take concrete action. The legal framework should be completed where there are gaps and penalties should be made more severe for offenders. But there will only be a real solution if we make it clear to those who come to Europe legally to settle in as many countries as they wish to receive them that, regardless of their traditions and "customs" in their countries of origin, they must values ​​and principles of European culture, otherwise they can not remain on our continent.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! We are talking about child marriages here today, but we really should be talking about marriages with children: adult men, sometimes mature men with girls under the age of 15. In the European criminal codes, the intercourse of an adult with a child under 15 is classified as pedophilia. Considering the fact that in the countries where they occur, these marriages are socially accepted, because such is the custom, tradition, and the fact that they also occur in Europe, we are dealing with a powerful legal and cultural conflict, and the victims of lack of reaction and the decisions are made by girls and young women. These problems are addressed by the Istanbul Convention, which clearly states that forced marriages and marriages with children are a form of violence and requires the signatories of the convention to recognize forcing children to marry as a criminal act. The convention also states that violence may not be justified by tradition or religion. In the event of a conflict of these values, habits that are based on the idea of ​​women's inferiority and that justify violence should be eradicated. This is what Art. 12 of the Convention and today, when we are talking about marriages with children, it is worth recalling this message of the Convention, because in this Chamber there are members who oppose this Convention and are against the content of Art. 12. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- For example, many girls in Germany are forced to marry, this is a very serious problem.We hear about it all the time.But what does the Istanbul Convention actually have to do with it?And our country - and it is thanks to you, unfortunately Agnieszka - has ratified it.I was against.But, you know, Hungary, Slovakia, Czech Republic, Lithuania, Latvia - the countries that have not ratified the Istanbul Convention - are not countries where this problem occurs.We would have saved many of these girls if their families were not under such pressure from the Muslim environment.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- This is not a question, it is, as I understand it, a comment.How does what does the Istanbul Convention have to do with it?The Istanbul Convention is an international document, and for the signatory states of this document the content of the Convention becomes national law.Even if there was uncertainty at the national law level as to how to resolve conflicts of values in law, the convention does resolve these conflicts.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I was wondering if it is really true that we are having a debate on child marriage in the middle of the 21st century. Something, in fact, is very wrong in this world. Childhood should be a time of joy and tranquility. It has already been said that child marriage destroys millions of lives for girls and girls. It denies them the right to make decisions about their well-being and sexual health, in due course. It robs them of their right to education. It condemns them to a life without prospects. These girls and girls are exposed to violence, abuse, disease and early death. They become pregnant when they are girls. Many die of childbirth. Others are mothers when they should be learning or playing. They are wives when they should be children. They are marked by the violation of someone old enough to be their father. There is no single solution. There is a need for a collective effort. Ending child marriage requires work at all levels. In this respect, the European Union has an increased responsibility with regard to its foreign policy. It implies an action on our part that solves and kills this problem at its source. Ending child marriage requires greater investment that is clearly targeted, education, community intervention, tougher legislation and those who fail to comply cannot receive European funding. The fight against child marriage has no ideology. It has a face, or rather, millions of faces.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman!Commissioner!Child marriage is one of the most shameful forms of sexual slavery to which young girls fall victim.Unfortunately, due to the intensification of the migration crisis, this pedophile practice has spread to the countries of the European Union.Unfortunately, in this case as well as in others, political correctness prevails over the fundamental Christian values that shaped Europe and which, after all, do not allow for the shameful treatment of girls.Let us be clear about it: these practices stem from the immigrant circles of the European Union.This is hard on the statistics.We cannot allow ourselves to relativize and turn a blind eye.So I would like to ask the Commissioner: is the committee going to launch an infringement procedure against countries where these pedophile practices are tolerated?

name: Charles GOERENS
text: - Mr President, when we speak to representatives of countries which, unfortunately, still tolerate forced marriage for young girls, we are often entitled to the following answer: "this practice is deeply rooted in our culture and in our traditions". This discussion and the vote on your resolution should help put an end to this appalling situation which, unfortunately, still disregards the most basic human rights of young girls. We cannot, of course, lay down the law in the countries which still tolerate these practices, but we can mobilize means likely to influence their policy: in our contacts with their leaders, in the framework of the political dialogue with these countries. , in strengthening the multilateral system, and in particular at the United Nations level, and within the framework of agreements between the European Union and third countries. There is no point in putting a mention in the preamble of a treaty if you can't double down on it. Clearly, I would like us to take advantage of the future agreement with the ACP countries, for example, to make the abolition of child and girl marriage an element of conditionality. You do not respect this principle enshrined in the Istanbul Convention, then you will no longer get help.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: - Mr President, the forced marriages of underage women, outside and inside the Union, are one of the most lacerating expressions of patriarchal societies, and we must tackle them with global and coordinated strategies where gender policy is included across the board. To this end, the European Union must include in its cooperation agreements specific measures to combat these practices. But, at the same time, we cannot fall into simplicity: we cannot speak of the empowerment of women, when we fuel conflicts through a foreign policy marked by our own economic interests. If, for example, countries in the third world are destabilized to obtain cheap raw materials, it is difficult to guarantee peace and social and economic development that help to break down the barriers of equality. That is why we insist that development policy must be coherent and adequately financed, while at the same time promoting a foreign policy of peace.

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Mr President, the luring and forcing of a child into a marriage is a disgusting crime, and one that UKIP deplores. Helpless and vulnerable children are often exploited in this way during school holidays. Such criminal activity is a threat to our society and its values and is a hindrance to integration, wherever it is perpetrated. It is an absolute violation of the human rights of many of our young girls and boys. Today, more than 250 million women worldwide are believed to have entered into a marriage before the age of 15. We strongly believe that those involved in such a dreadful crime must be prosecuted. In addition, there should be a refusal of permanent leave to remain, or the withdrawal of British citizenship, for any adult who has procured such a marriage for themselves or for children. It is shocking, in the 21st century, to recognise that forced marriage became a criminal act in the United Kingdom as recently as 2014. This monstrous crime needs to be tackled immediately and by all parties, and the law should apply equally irrespective of race, faith or ethnic origin.

name: André ELISSEN
text: - Today we are talking about child marriage, a phenomenon that unfortunately still exists and even occurs in our civilized Europe. Not infrequently these marriages take place in Afghan, Somali, Iranian, Syrian and Pakistani communities. This is not surprising when one considers the legitimacy of many of these marriages. This legitimacy stems from Islam. In certain European countries it is still possible to have a marriage contracted with a minor recognized abroad. This is crazy for words. It is up to the nation states to make it impossible to recognize these kinds of barbaric practices. It is pure child abuse. It is the duty of everyone to strongly condemn this. We do not need expensive paid studies, no Commission that is kicked open doors and overpaid bobsleigh nourishes. We need strong policy from the nation states. We want less Islam and a halt to immigration from Islamic countries.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, Alexander Solzhenitsyn once wrote that no creature in the world suffers as much as a Russian woman. I still have before my eyes a Russian woman in a wadded coat tamping the sleepers of railway tracks. Solzhenitsyn looked no further than Solovki and Magadan. He has not seen millions of African and Asian women suffering from primitive masculine violence, hungry, insulted and humiliated. They are circumcised and married in childhood. These are the living creatures who suffer the most. I once made a film about women in Afghanistan. One of the heroines was a woman who had 13 children. After the 13th child, the doctor told her husband: "Your wife will not survive another pregnancy." She became pregnant again and died. Her husband gave birth to her. She was first pregnant when she was 15 years old. Today, there are over 700 million women in the world who were married as children. Every year, 15 million girls are forced into marriage before the age of 18. 60% of child brides in developing countries are illiterate because they are denied the right to education. Islamophobia stretching across Europe emphasizes that child marriages are inherent in the Islamic faith. I dare say that is not true. Huge numbers of child marriages are in non-Muslim countries, in India, Brazil and Ethiopia. Violence against child brides is a post-confessional problem.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, there are sixty million child brides in the world and it has been calculated that in developing countries one out of three girls marries before the age of eighteen; one in nine, even before the age of fifteen and uneducated girls are three times more likely to marry earlier. The probability of death due to sexual intercourse that takes place before puberty is very high - also the colleagues have pointed out - and mortality during births is naturally high. These are numbers that speak of a real emergency, President and Commissioner. An emergency with respect to which we cannot really turn the other way, and it is good to tell ourselves clearly that these forced early childhood marriages are legalization and cover for those who continue to practice pedophilia, for those who continue to be guilty of a crime particularly aberrant, particularly hateful and with respect to which I believe we must have absolutely no tolerance. And this means doing concrete things, it certainly means going in the direction we wanted through this resolution which is an important thing, because fighting these practices simply means defending fundamental human rights.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Mr President, I consider the compulsion of teenage girls to marry to be an absolutely unacceptable manifestation in European culture in 2017. But it is also morally shameful that the authors of the resolution and the questions tabled are giving us such a cruel event as child marriage. to promote further cruelty, and that is killing innocent children in women's wombs. Solving one trauma using unnecessary and brutal so-called "Treatment" is simply a guide to inducing other mental illnesses, and it is not appropriate for it to sound in this room. The title of the topic - Termination of marriages of minors - is misleading. I would expect us to talk about how to help children born from these marriages and thus improve the lives of the next generation, but I did not find any offered solution there. This name is a fake ad. Forced marriages take place in closed communities where European law is not respected. Then I ask, where are the judges, the police and the state administration? These girls need to be able to protect. But we want to replace one guilt with another by taking the unborn life. This will not help them, on the contrary, it will damage them even more. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, I see that the members of the European Conservatives and Reformists Group and my colleague Mr Škripek are saying that there is nothing to do and that it is behind closed doors, but there is a legal instrument. It is called the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women, which also criminalises child and early marriage. Why did you all vote against it? This is the instrument – or do you only care if this practice is done in your Member State or not? (Applause) It is a global phenomenon affecting millions of girls, and with access to the Istanbul Convention we have more legal tools and more comprehensive means to deal with it in the world.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: blue-card answer. – There are many errors being used as an answer to this problem. We say that this is something which is being pushed forward. It is not a real solution to suggest so-called sexual and reproductive rights and yet more money for abortions. This is not a solution. You mention the Istanbul Convention, but this is again a legally flawed document which is not yet accepted by many countries, so we cannot rely on it.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that today it is a question of placing ourselves, as the title of a beautiful book by Elena Gianini Belotti states, "on the side of the girls". I think that the discussion we had in the last plenary, strongly calling for the ratification of the Istanbul Convention throughout the European Union, by all the Member States, gives us an important tool and indication precisely because it recognizes violence against women in many forms, including violence against girls. Girls who are prevented by these early marriages from fully pursuing a path of self-determination, a path of self-awareness and whose health is undermined - as has already been said very well by the colleagues who have preceded me - by forced, forced and not chosen sexual relations and by not chosen pregnancies. I think this is an urgency for this House and I hope that the Commission intends to act strongly in the direction of safeguarding the rights of girls.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Ms Forenza, I do apologise to you but I would take this opportunity to remind the Members that we are behind schedule, the time has been allocated and has to be respected. I will follow that up but let us also pay some respect to those who have asked for catch-the-eye time and possibly for blue cards. We want to have a debate, so from now on I will be even stricter than I have been up to now.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Mr President! Children should not give birth to children. And children should not get married. At the same time, we live in a world where 27 girls a minute get married, usually against their will. Child marriage carries an extremely serious risk of mortality for girls, especially with regard to complications in connection with pregnancy and the fact that these children give birth to children. The UN aims to eradicate child marriage in the world before 2030, this when the number only increases, here we as a welfare state have a responsibility to vigorously do our best to stop and prevent children from getting married. We must not turn a blind eye to this oppression, we must stand up for the rights of the children and fight hard. In Sweden, we hear reports that say that as many as 70,000 young people are at risk of getting married. We also know that due to the large-scale immigration that has taken place to Europe, many of the children who come are married to older men, many times the marriages took place just before coming to Europe because it was thought that it would lead to greater chances of getting asylum, my question then is how to do in these cases to ensure the best interests of the children, do we really dare to investigate the children's situation or do we close our eyes because we are cowards and think we are violating someone's culture or tradition. But let me then remind you that this is nothing but a terrible oppression. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) under Rule 162 (8).

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- I wanted to ask if Sweden needs the Istanbul Convention to fight the scourge of forced marriage of girls.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: answer ("blue card").- Yes, we have ratified the Istanbul Convention in Sweden and I think it is actually important that all Member States do so.As I said, it may not just be up to the Istanbul Convention to fight this.At the national level, we must dare to speak out, because we often close our eyes and look between the fingers because we are so afraid of offending someone.So we probably have to work from many angles when it comes to this.

name: Georg MAYER
text: - Mister President! The year 2017 is Anno Domini in Europe, dear colleagues, and what do we have to talk about in this House? We need to talk about the fact that children are being forced into marriage to adult men. Where is the root of this evil? You can see how the left side has to twist in order not to address the root. The root of this cruel practice lies in the unbridled immigration that you advocate, unrestrained immigration from Muslim states, where Sharia law allows girls to be married off at nine years of age. This legal practice contradicts every applicable European law since the invention by the Romans, when they more or less invented the law. So the problem lies in uncontrolled immigration. And this house repeatedly deals excessively with gender measures that completely bypass the problem. On the other hand, child marriage is tolerated here. Well, we can't do that.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to subscribe and share the perplexity that Mrs Liliana Rodrigues noted, but the truth is that every year, 28 girls are forced to marry every minute. This means 15 million a year and, if we do nothing, 150 million in the next decade. It is estimated that there are already 700 million women and 150 million men in the world who were forced to marry before they came of age. Figures like these reinforce the sense of urgency in the fight against this reality, a fight that necessarily involves the Union's foreign policy. Countries like Nigeria, Mozambique or India are examples where this reality still persists, but we also need it in our territory to act. There is an urgent need to ensure that we have the most appropriate means to eradicate this phenomenon within doors. It is even more intolerable that forced marriages exist within the European Union. Recently, this Parliament approved the Union's accession to the Council of Europe Convention for the Prevention and Combat of Violence against Women and urged Member States in need to do so, as Anna Maria Corazza Bildt recalled. In short, Mr President, we must make this fight a priority, in order to rescue these children from forced marriages and ensure that, in the future, many more are not fettered. A priority for everyone, in the Member States and the rest of the world.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, this resolution will not be enough without a strong political signal. The figures, we know them, the legal instruments for the protection of children exist, so why always face this terrible reality? Child marriages are still forced. Always! It is on the notion of consent that I would like to stress because it is the big loser in our debates. At what point can we say that a marriage is freely consented by a terrified girl? When does the first sexual relationship take place when the same girl has to prove her fertility and virginity? Do these unequal circumstances not demonstrate the staggering constraint? Silence cannot constitute consent. Therefore, Commissioner, I ask you to initiate a European initiative on the notion of consent of girls and women in general, in order to put an end to national disparities and the lack of protection of European legislation. Finally, I would like to tell my colleagues opposite that one in three underage child marriages occurs in developed countries.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: - Mister President!Between 2011 and 2020, 140 million child marriages are expected worldwide.In these marriages, young people lose their right to self-determination, sometimes their freedom and their future are taken away.They end up dependent, which leads to the fact that they often become pregnant very early, this leads to dropouts from school and even more so to dropping out of training.That means they end up in dependency - dependency on their husbands and, as a consequence, maybe also on the state.Cultures in which something like this occurs - we have to be clear about that - do not suit us - if they want to live it in Europe.We must therefore ensure that such marriages are not recognized in Europe and that people who come here and want to practice child marriage have no business here.We should be very clear about this.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I also thank the colleagues who brought this important issue of child marriage to the Chamber. I also thank the associations that work every day in the area to stop this phenomenon. We said it: millions of girls are forced to marry, therefore in full violation of human rights. We can act as Europe, as a Parliament, taking this phenomenon into consideration in cooperation agreements, because it is not ethical that we do business with countries that do not respect human rights. However, we must not forget that the issue of child brides also concerns us in the European Union more and more and not only the developing countries. We have already mentioned it: I am referring, for example, to cases of school dropout, where European girls suddenly disappear and, if all goes well, remain in Italy or even go outside the European borders. We must stop this flow: we need a strong regulatory initiative at European and national level to stop this phenomenon.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is imperative to fight against child marriage, but we still have to be logical. This proposal reminds us that these children often drop out of school. Surprisingly, she suggests focusing on education. But if these children have been forced to leave school, it is not through educational means that we will stop the phenomenon. The proposal indicates that child marriage is not the preserve of third countries. We are affected! But she herself makes the link with immigration, linking the migration crisis and child marriages contracted abroad. It just goes to show that mobility is not always liberating! At no time does she raise the issue of integration. However, this is what is asked of the populations who practice such practices. Let them assimilate our mores. This integration cannot succeed with the current flow. Incapable of calling into question the unconditional and unlimited reception of migrants, the proposal goes so far as to encourage the development of customs in third countries through education. How to cure the disease at the root? Perhaps we should start by not importing this evil on our soil.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Commissioner, the debate clearly shows that the problem has two positions. Child marriages in third countries and child marriages at European Union level. At that first position, ie. child marriages in third countries, we need to put significant pressure on our partners to accept the Istanbul Convention. But the issue of child marriage as a principle of human rights violations should be much more included in our European diplomacy. In dealing with our partners, we should not just address the issue of freedom of expression, the death penalty or other forms of human rights violations. But we should also address this right, ie. the woman's right to self-determination and the right of an adult woman to decide freely whether or not to marry. It is about our diplomacy in negotiating with our partners, in providing financial assistance to third countries to include this as one of the conditions for us to provide some economic assistance to these countries. The second thing is child marriage in the EU. It has already been said here, their number is increasing with the arrival of other migrants in the EU. And here, personally, I am sorry that the resolution that we are voting on tomorrow merely states in paragraph 14 that child marriages in the EU need to be properly monitored. I would expect a much harsher condemnation, I would expect that the result will be the European initiative already mentioned here, which will clearly ban any tolerance of child marriage in the EU and criminalize child marriage in Europe. In Europe, we can solve this.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, many things have been said, which is why I will limit my remarks to the difference in legal treatment, by taking a few examples. In 2016, a court in Bavaria approved the marriage of a 21-year-old Syrian to his 14-year-old cousin. The court ruled that this marriage was valid because it was concluded in accordance with Syrian law. At the end of 2015, according to the same principle, the Netherlands recognized the marriages of minors when they had been registered in the country of origin. In Germany too, the federal government presented a bill to the Council of Ministers a few months ago which bans the marriage of minors, with the minimum legal age rising from 16 to 18 years. In France, both spouses must be 18 years old, but a marriage with a minor can be authorized for serious reasons such as, for example, a pregnancy. The important thing is to try to move towards harmonization. By voting on this resolution, we will try to apply uniform legal standards on European territory with regard to child marriage and, if possible, its prohibition, as the United Nations special rapporteur on the subject reminds us.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
