text: - Mr President, I wholeheartedly support the end of child marriages.In Europe, it is no longer possible to turn a blind eye to child marriage on the basis of multicultural values.Those who come to Europe must be required to respect human rights in the same way as Europeans themselves.Preventing child marriages is not just humanitarian.It is an effective way to promote the long-term development of developing countries and to curb the influx of refugees in a sustainable way.The education of girls is one of the few factors that studies have found to be an effective investment in the fight against poverty over generations.Child marriages, low education and rapid population growth are interlinked.The EU has an opportunity to show great leadership here, and this opportunity should not be missed.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleagues, we now come to catch the eye. Even if I am very generous I will not be able to provide speaking time to more than half of those colleagues who have applied to speak because the list is very long. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - President! We have talked several times about the alarmingly high number of child marriages, yet it cannot be said enough that curbing the phenomenon is not only important for human rights reasons. After all, we must add that these are mainly the children of families living in poverty in developing countries, who thus drop out of school, making it even more difficult for themselves and their families to rise up socially and reduce poverty. Child marriages are very common in countries with huge populations, India, Bangladesh or even in central Africa, where population growth is also high, and these countries are in many cases also source countries for migration to Europe. It is an astonishing figure that by 2030, 950 million people will be affected by child marriage, which is twice the population of the Union. Traditions and customs cannot explain the maintenance of the phenomenon. If the world is to tackle the problems of overpopulation, global warming and migration, it must end the practice of child marriage.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, early and forced marriages, and in particular the phenomenon of child brides, represent a global scourge, perhaps still underestimated and therefore not adequately countered on a legal and socio-cultural level. There are millions of young women in the world who have contracted marriage even before the age of 14 and these marriages, early and forced, constitute an extremely harmful phenomenon, which involves a serious violation of the rights of girls, often subjected to violence and abuse, in each case deprived of the right to childhood but also of dignity, hope and the possibility of choosing one's own future. As the European Union, we have the responsibility to intervene: we must ensure that respect for the dignity and rights of minors, as well as always being affirmed on European territory, are the necessary conditions for starting cooperation agreements with those developing countries in which this practice persists, to encourage and initiate a process of reform, in the sign of respect for the rights of young women and girls.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the phenomenon of child brides is constantly increasing and, according to Save the Children, is one of the main barriers preventing girls from accessing services and opportunities. Every seven seconds in the world, a girl under the age of 15 gets married, often with a much older man. All these girls are neither physically nor psychologically ready, they cannot face a marriage, much less a pregnancy. Unfortunately, the legal commitment to protect it by penalizing child marriage encounters considerable obstacles due to the prevailing political culture, the compliance of religious extremists and the persistence of gender prejudices. The international community has pledged to put an end to the practice of child marriages by 2030: but if the number of child brides in the world continues to grow at the current rate, by that date we will have 950 million young married women. The work to be done is on the dissemination of legislation that prevents the possibility of contracting a marriage with minors and Europe must do its part.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, child marriages are a violation of the human rights of children, of young girls, and are a form of gender-based violence. This debate provides an opportunity for elected representatives to hear from the Commission about the effectiveness of EU measures, whether it is in Europe or in developing countries. For example, the right-wing ruling party in Turkey recently considered a proposal to free convicted rapists provided that they marry their victims. To truly confront the reality, we must take a holistic view, empowering women and girls through education, ensuring that systems that subject girls to child marriages are eroded through women’s leadership from the grassroots community upwards and that girls themselves are enabled and empowered to speak up in every way they can.  I am proud to be part of a European Union that takes action to advance the rights of women and girls around the world and I look forward to hearing from the Commission about their work on this.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, I am glad that we are having this debate because it gives us the opportunity to reiterate, loud and clear, that child marriage is a violation of human rights and should be criminalised as such. Girls are the most targeted group in this vile practice. This scourge only furthers gender discrimination and, in practical terms, it means legalising domestic sexual violence. The EU stands with women and girls and is committed to eradicating child marriage, with initiatives such as the Daphne programme, but we can do more. We need to push all countries to introduce a minimum age for marriage and to ensure better access to sexual and reproductive health services. Ending child marriage would be a major milestone on the path towards the empowerment of women, and thus it should remain a priority of the European Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr President, child marriages are incompatible with what Europe is today - an advanced civilization that relies on the rule of law.Our legal system puts this form of violence against the most vulnerable members of society beyond what is allowed, and all citizens of the Member States of the Union, regardless of their cultural or religious heritage, should respect it.The problem arises when members of various minorities are automatically classified into vulnerable groups, so some things, which are not allowed to anyone else, are still allowed.One of these things is child marriage, which is the dominant practice of minority communities in Europe.This is another question that shows the need for better integration policy and consistent law enforcement in Europe.The law must be the same for everyone because otherwise we will go back to some ugly times that European nations do not remember with particular nostalgia.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleagues, just by way of explanation, I have seen some colleagues asking for catch-the-eye after the catch-the-eye debate has started. I am not in a position to take those requests. By the way, this does not concern you, Ms Vautmans. I am just saying it as a general remark: looking at you does not mean it is about you! But seriously, I cannot take those requests, not least because we are behind schedule and the list is very long. So, my apologies, but the moment catch-the-eye starts we cannot even put your name on the list to give you the floor.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: 750 million girls worldwide, child marriage.15 million girls every year.That number is pretty awful.It happens in developing countries and, colleagues, I have visited them.Being pregnant in childbirth, babies dying, young girls suffering from fistulas and then being rejected.I have also seen them carried away.Child brides, conceived, dying in childbirth.That is what is still happening today and we must focus on that in developing countries.As colleague Goerens said: with education, with training, with political pressure on the political leaders there.But we must also dare to look into our own heart.We must also, as Mr Tarabella said, look at what is happening here in Europe.Where do we recognize these child marriages?How can we protect children here so that they are not married off?Let's go for zero tolerance together.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, in developing countries, one in three girls marries before the age of 18 and one in nine before the age of 15. The problem of child marriage affects both girls and boys, but girls, who make up 82% of married children, are most at risk. However, the problem does not only concern third countries, but also Europe. I apologize for using strong words, but I consider child marriages to be a completely unacceptable perversion. For example, the German authorities registered 1,500 married children last year. This is completely unacceptable, after all, it is not possible for us in the EU to accept child marriages that go completely against European law. Children belong to schools and not to hotplates, and this is a principle from which it is not possible to deviate in the EU. This practice must end if we are still to consider ourselves a place with a certain moral and civilizational dimension. And this debate should prepare very concrete measures to prevent it within the EU for the future, and I firmly believe that this will be the case, Commissioner.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, I think the problem has been very well described by many colleagues and I will not repeat anything. But we must take action, Commissioner, financially, politically and legally. I think you still have a long way to go and you have to make that effort. I want to close with the following so as not to waste too much time: the approach we heard from the opposite seats to increase these marriages in the European Union is also wrong. It's a real problem, but we look at it globally. We cannot have a different view of what is happening in Africa, in Asia and a different view of what is perhaps happening in the European Union. We must deal with the problem in the same way. Take more urgent action in the European Union, but do not burden immigration. There is immigration, but we have better ways of tackling the problem within the European Union.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this very interesting and very alarming debate. On 30 June this year a great step was taken as the Convention, the Istanbul Convention which has been mentioned here many times in the discussion, was signed on behalf of the EU. The decision on the conclusion is currently being negotiated in the Council, and I can assure you that the Commission is working very closely with the Estonian Presidency to achieve progress towards ratification.  I can assure you that I will use every possible moment and opportunity to discuss with those States which have not yet ratified, to do so. On behalf of the Commission I can say that we are very grateful for the considerable support for accession expressed by Parliament on many occasions.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 4 October 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: written. - All children have the right to a happy childhood. It is intolerable that in the 21st century, minors, especially girls, continue to be forced to marry people, in most cases much older men, who do not respect their childhood, their innocence, and force them to take a brutal leap into adulthood, they are raped, pregnant, and many die because their bodies are not yet ready. In developing countries, one in three girls marries before the age of eighteen and one in nine before the age of fifteen. Child marriage affects both girls and boys, but girls are most at risk, accounting for 82% of married minors. This problem also affects Europe. Child, early and forced marriage constitutes a violation of the rights of children recognized in the EU Treaties. The EU must meet the goals of the 2030 sustainable development program to combat child marriage, cooperate with UN Women, UNICEF and UNFPA, and design cooperation and development policies that take into account the defense of children's rights.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - All children have the right to a happy childhood. It is intolerable that in the 21st century, minors, especially girls, continue to be forced to marry people, in most cases much older men, who do not respect their childhood, their innocence, and force them to take a brutal leap into adulthood, they are raped, pregnant, and many die because their bodies are not yet ready. In developing countries, one in three girls marries before the age of eighteen and one in nine before the age of fifteen. Child marriage affects both girls and boys, but girls are most at risk, accounting for 82% of married minors. This problem also affects Europe. Child, early and forced marriage constitutes a violation of the rights of children recognized in the EU Treaties. The EU must meet the goals of the 2030 sustainable development program to combat child marriage, cooperate with UN Women, UNICEF and UNFPA, and design cooperation and development policies that take into account the defense of children's rights.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up. - In addition to all the issues related to this sensitive topic, mentioned in the oral question, I would like to draw your attention first of all to the fact that, with the recent migration crisis, new cases of child marriages abroad have arisen, sometimes involving children with under the age of 14, which is absolutely outrageous. Secondly, I would like to point out that, at both national and Union level and at international level, very few statistics are available to demonstrate the magnitude of the problem of child marriage, early marriage and forced marriage (CEFM). Given that this practice is present not only in third countries but also in some Member States of the European Union, I believe that there is a need for adequate and harmonized monitoring of all such marriages in the EU, but also for the collection of disaggregated data. depending on gender, in order to better assess the extent of this problem.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: written. - I would like to welcome this parliamentary question as it promotes European initiatives aimed at eradicating child marriages and ensuring universal rights for children. At the same time, I would like to recall that this complex issue cannot be dealt with effectively without taking into account various cultural, economic and political constraints. For example, according to the non-governmental association Child not brides, seven out of ten countries with the highest rates of child marriage are considered fragile states. Simultaneously, humanitarian crises, conflicts and environmental catastrophes are known to exacerbate the conditions of poverty and insecurity that favor child marriages, which is also reflected in migration crises, including the one that has affected Europe in recent years. All of these factors must be taken into consideration when approaching an effective strategy that goes beyond reassuring statements. Finally, I would like to welcome the decision to explicitly mention boys (not just girls) in the question, which shows a genuine commitment to gender equality.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: in writing. - The fact that in the public arena in developing countries there is such a phenomenon as juvenile marriage shows that we are not moving forward, but moving back into the abyss of intellectual ignorance. Underage girls and the offspring of (of such marriages) pay the price for that mental abomination that prompts people to marry girls who have not, or have just reached, puberty. It is a mental slide backwards that has very serious consequences. A little girl cannot bear the demands of married life, either mentally or physically. It is therefore a crime that only the law can stop. Due to migration from the affected countries and the large number of refugees, Europe is also affected by this problem. The treaties require the EU to promote children's rights. The question then arises spontaneously: how does the Commission deal with this issue? At the same time, I would like to point out that I do not agree to any concessions in favor of abortion (hidden under the banner of sexual and reproductive rights). My support for the resolution, therefore, has nothing to do with those paragraphs to which I strongly oppose.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: in writing.- Every year, 15 million girls under the age of 18 commit forced marriages, so we could say that 28 girls per minute and 1 girl per second fall victim to this form of violence against women.Roma women across Europe are victims of complex, multiple discrimination not only because of their gender but also because of their ethnicity as a result of widespread anti-Gypsyism.That is why it is particularly important that we address this issue as a priority in the EU's Roma 2020-2030 strategy.Within the framework of the “Woman has a chance” program launched in 2012, the Hungarian government provides HUF 1.5 billion in vocational training support to enable as many Roma women as possible to enter the labor market.We propose similar targeted measures for other governments.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: written.- With this resolution, we are sending a clear signal against the marriage of children.I fully support the fight against child marriage.However, I would like to warn against mixing up different topics.Therefore, I reject the proposal on sexual and reproductive health and related rights and services, including safe and legal abortion.I also reject the idea that the European Union should provide funds for the funding gap of the “Global Gag Rule” in the area of reproductive and sexual rights.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - All children have the right to a happy childhood. It is intolerable that in the 21st century, minors, especially girls, continue to be forced to marry people, in most cases much older men, who do not respect their childhood, their innocence, and force them to take a brutal leap into adulthood, they are raped, pregnant, and many die because their bodies are not yet ready. In developing countries, one in three girls marries before the age of eighteen and one in nine before the age of fifteen. Child marriage affects both girls and boys, but girls are most at risk, accounting for 82% of married minors. This problem also affects Europe. Child, early and forced marriage constitutes a violation of the rights of children recognized in the EU Treaties. The EU must meet the goals of the 2030 sustainable development program to combat child marriage, cooperate with UN Women, UNICEF and UNFPA, and design cooperation and development policies that take into account the defense of children's rights.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – In recent years child marriage has gained increasing prominence on international and national development agendas. Each year, 15 million girls are married before the age of 18. Child marriage is a crime recognised under the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women, which we must end in order to achieve a fairer future for all. Child brides face enormous challenges as a result of being married as children. Child marriage is a complex issue: poverty, lack of education or different cultural practices. Ending child marriage requires work across all sectors and at all levels. We must take a holistic approach to empower young girls through education, to ensure that systems that subject girls to child marriages are eroded through women’s leadership from the grassroots community upwards and that girls themselves are enabled and empowered to speak up in every way they can. Today, we have a unique opportunity to act on this momentum and accelerate our efforts to help change the lives of girls and young women all over the world.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. - Early and forced marriages of children are a violation of the rights of the child and violence against women and girls. In developing countries, one in three girls marries before the age of 18 and one in nine before the age of 15. In low- and middle-income countries, complications during pregnancy and childbirth are the leading cause of death among girls aged 15-19. Early and forced marriages are associated with high maternal mortality rates and usually also means the end of a girl's education. This practice must be stopped and must be a priority of the EU's external action in the field of women's rights and the promotion of human rights. It is also important to note that the problem occurs not only in third countries but also in the EU. The budget must provide funding for child marriage prevention programs, support third countries in eliminating such practices and raise awareness through various campaigns. There are also particular concerns about ensuring the protection of children among refugees and asylum seekers - host countries must ensure full access to education for child refugees and provide assistance to victims of child or forced marriage. I also believe that the EU has an obligation to find funding for the gap created by the US by re-establishing the so-called general law of silence in the field of sexual and reproductive health.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: written. - All boys and girls have the right to a happy childhood. It is intolerable that in the 21st century, minors, especially girls, continue to be forced to marry much older men, who do not respect their childhood and force them to take a brutal leap into adult life, rape them, leave them pregnant and many die because their bodies are not yet ready. In developing countries, one in three girls marries before the age of eighteen and one in nine before the age of fifteen. Child marriage affects both girls and boys, but girls are most at risk, accounting for 82% of married minors. This problem also affects Europe. Forced child marriage constitutes a violation of the rights of boys and girls recognized in the EU Treaties. The EU must meet the objectives of the 2030 sustainable development program to combat child marriage, cooperate with UN Women, UNICEF and UNFPA, and design cooperation and development policies that take into account the defense of children's rights.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the EU-Egypt partnership priorities for 2017—2020 (2017/2874(RSP)).

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, last July, High Representative Mogherini and the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Sameh Shoukry, chaired the European Union-Egypt Association Council, in the presence of Commissioner Hahn. It was on that occasion that our new Partnership Priorities were adopted. This was the first Association Council with Egypt in seven years, so the first since the beginning of the revolts in the Arab world. It is precisely in these times of transition that our cooperation becomes more important. It is important for the people of Egypt and their aspiration to security, democracy and economic growth. It is essential for the region – from Libya to Syria – and it is essential for Europe, because we are neighbours and we share many of the same challenges. So we are glad that we have managed to reopen such an important channel for dialogue with Egypt. This does not mean that the European Union and Egypt agree on all files. But precisely when you disagree on something, engagement becomes essential. There is no other way to address any outstanding issue, in the interest of the Egyptian people and of the whole region.  Our partnership with Egypt will be structured around four main tracks. Firstly, support to the Egyptian government’s socio-economic reform agenda. In this field, there has been much concrete progress in the last year: the Egyptian authorities adopted an economic reform plan supported by the International Monetary Fund, aimed at bringing back macroeconomic stability and inclusive growth. This is an important step, and we are eager to support the plan, including through our bilateral assistance programme. We are also keen to support Egypt’s efforts to address the social and economic impact of these reforms, particularly on the most vulnerable parts of the population.  The second track of our partnership is building stronger cooperation on common challenges, such as counterterrorism and migration. Terrorism poses a fundamental threat to Egypt’s stability and security. Time and again, we have stood on the side of the Egyptian people when they were hit by a new attack. It is not just ‘moral’ solidarity; we are ready for more concrete cooperation in this field, and the Partnership Priorities are giving us the opportunity to explore new forms of common engagement. Let me add that, whenever we discuss counterterrorism with our Egyptian counterparts, we always insist that repressive measures are never enough to address this issue. Terrorism needs to be tackled in full respect of international human rights standards and fundamental freedoms. On migration, Egypt has made an important contribution in hosting refugees, not least Syrian refugees. It has also significantly reduced irregular migration flows, through the implementation of the Valletta Action Plan and the Khartoum process. A better and more humane management of migration flows is in the interest first and foremost of migrants, but also of countries of origin, transit and destination. So we are currently working with our Egyptian counterparts to launch a high-level migration dialogue. The third track relates to closer dialogue and cooperation on foreign policy and regional issues. Egypt currently seats on both the UN Security Council and the African Union Political and Security Council. Beyond that, it is an essential partner to address other crises in our region, starting with the conflict between Israel and Palestine. We share an interest in working together more, including on the conflicts in Libya and Syria, as well as to address tensions in the Gulf. Last, but definitely not least, there is a strong political track in our partnership, which includes governance, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms. The European Union’s position on this is very clear and we reiterate it constantly in our dialogue with our Egyptian counterparts: sustainable security and stability can only be achieved when human rights – those guaranteed by the 2014 Constitution and flowing from Egypt’s international commitments – are fully implemented. If we want to help improve the situation of human rights in Egypt or to preserve the space for civil society, we have no alternative to engaging with them. It is in this spirit that the European Union Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, visited Egypt in February, to enhance dialogue on human rights with the Egyptian authorities. We continue to pass this message both in public and in private, in all our contacts both at bilateral level and in multilateral fora. This is what we did, for instance, on the possible consequences of the new NGO law. On NGOs, in particular, there is something we should not forget. The European Union is the biggest donor in Egypt. Total ongoing European Union financial assistance commitments to Egypt amount to over EUR 1.3 billion in grants. If Member State and European Financial Institutions’ grants, loans and debt-swaps are included, the figure rises to EUR 11 billion. A relevant part of this bilateral assistance relies on civil society organisations as implementing partners. Our partnership needs a strong and lively civil society, and this is something our Egyptian friends should also keep in mind.  The four tracks of our partnership are closely linked to one another. Sustainable security is linked to sustainable development, which is linked to human rights and to regional stability. This is the approach we have adopted with our Partnership Priorities, and this is the proof that only through engagement can we can address our common interests for the people of Egypt, for Europe and for our entire region.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: , on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, the partnership between the Union and Egypt is important for the stability and prosperity of both shores of the Mediterranean. We have common interests, we also have to face common challenges like the fight against terrorism, human trafficking, migration and instability in our southern neighborhood. On all these fronts, we need more joint action. This is why our group welcomes the holding of the seventh EU-Egypt Association Council on 25 July. This has given additional impetus to this partnership, and we share the general direction of the priorities that have been agreed. I am particularly pleased to see that the section devoted to the principles of cooperation refers to the deepening of political dialogue on democracy and human rights and the need for collaboration with civil society organizations for the implementation of this partnership. Both dimensions are very important, since we know that much remains to be done in terms of respect for human rights and participation of civil society in Egypt. Moreover, when we talk to our Egyptian interlocutors, they are the first to recognize it. And I find it essential to continue working with them to promote human rights and to favor a constructive approach that will allow us to achieve better results on the ground. Thus, a fact-finding mission of the PPE Group, in which our colleagues Elmar Brok and Mariya Gabriel participated, was dispatched to Egypt in November 2016, and one of the main messages communicated to our partners is that the Union will support all measures aimed at the adoption of international human rights standards in Egypt. This is certainly a long-term job that must be constantly supported in order to promote true democratic transition in Egypt.In this regard, the monitoring and evaluation mechanism that will be put in place within the framework of the partnership will play a key role, and it will be necessary to ensure that it is sufficiently endowed to enable us to achieve these objectives.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Egypt is a key partner for the EU and we welcome the first EU-Egypt Association Council after the revolution and the adoption of the partnership priorities for the period 2017-2020. Egypt is undergoing a difficult period, but its path towards stability and sustainability is so important. Egypt is confronted with a challenging internal situation following the revolution and faces terrorism that continues to strike the country, with all its consequences on people, on tourism and on the economy. We know there are many shortcomings, and yet we know and acknowledge the progress already made in certain areas, including the new parliament; but equally, we have to take note of the many areas where EU-Egypt cooperation is of fundamental importance. I mentioned terrorism. There is no doubt that to defeat terrorism we need a close cooperation with all partners, including Egypt. In this regard, I welcome the efforts of the President el-Sisi to reform Islam and to prevent radicalisation, as well as the strong effort to protect Christians, which has recently prevented attacks being launched against the Christian communities. But let me also add the importance of cooperating with Egypt on migration and for regional stability. We praise in particular the efforts of Egypt to play its very important broker’s role in Palestinian reconciliation. Just today we have taken note of the successful talks between the two sides and the fact that the two sides have decided to build up the national consensus government of Palestine. It’s an example of what Europe can do.  (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Thank you, colleague. My apologies on behalf of those of us who are sitting here. You really had two minutes but there was a mistake in the papers. I give you our apologies.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - From a European perspective, it is certainly worthwhile to familiarize yourself with the social media in Egypt. After all, a heated debate has been raging in these social media for months about the results of President Sisi's rule and his prospects for re-election in April 2018. This debate is broadly positive for the Egyptian head of state: a broad re-election in April 2018 is in the pipeline. off. However, even among the sympathizers of President Sisi there is undeniably great disappointment about the country's downright dramatic socio-economic situation (bread riots for example). Which brings me to the major role the Egyptian military plays in the national economy. I would like to know from the Council and the Commission, if necessary in writing, how they deal with this military "business empire" within the framework of the partnership priorities between the EU and Egypt 2017-2020, which clearly speak about "strengthening the role of the private sector ". I hope that the Commission will take note and that I will receive a written answer: the role of the military in the Egyptian economy. Consider this compatible with strengthening the private sector. In the official document on the Joint Partnership Priorities I read on page 7 that the EU and Egypt continue to work together in the fight against extremism, discrimination, including Islamophobia and xenophobia. On the basis of Egyptian reality, two words should not be missing here: contra Christophobia and contra anti-Semitism.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I hope these words are conveyed to the High Representative, Commissioner. The circumstances that Egyptians live under and the EU’s relation to this crucial country merit a serious and critical assessment. Considering the increased focus on security, managing migration and now the EU-Egypt partnership, it is shocking and disappointing that the EPP and S&D Groups have blocked this debate for three years and, even now, colleagues have ensured that this House does not express itself in a resolution this month. I consider this to be a cop-out. The human rights situation in Egypt cannot only be relevant for us when it hits home, however terrible the brutal murder of Giulio Regeni might be, and I too echo the ongoing calls for justice in that case. But countless Egyptians face grave injustices and violations of their rights, and we must address their fate too. They face systematic torture, enforced disappearances and extrajudicial killings, and all of this is happening with impunity. Civilians are still tried by military courts and we have now seen 22 cases of death sentences. Very restrictive NGO laws make the work of civil society, including EU-based organisations, nearly impossible. Journalists and bloggers are harassed – and I want to highlight particularly the ongoing imprisonment of Alaa Abd El-Fattah – and they cannot work freely, and that is unacceptable. Add to that the recent wave of arrests of gay people and the intimidation of LGBT people. That is also unacceptable.  No short-term cooperation in the field of anti-terrorism or ‘migration management’ can compensate for these gross violations, nor can they justify the EU’s ongoing silence. Egyptians deserve better and need better. We know what a boiling point can be reached if the needs of young people are not addressed. There cannot be a partnership without respect for human rights.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, everything that has been said about the strategy that needs to be established between the European Union and Egypt as a historic partner is true: cultural relations and neighborhood relations. The fundamental role of Egypt in relation to the issue of Syria, Libya or even Palestine is also true. But I would like to resume what was said by the colleague right now. It is that between partners there can be no taboo issues, namely the issue of human rights in both senses: either with regard to the violation of human rights in Egypt, or with regard to the violation of human rights in the European Union. Therefore, I would like to affirm here, very strongly, that there can be no clauses in this agreement that are only on paper. It is our responsibility that everything written in the agreement is complied with and the issue of human rights cannot be a minor issue. You have to be at the level of trade issues, you have to be at the level of economic interests, or better, you have to be above them, because otherwise you will always be a poor victim. I therefore ask the Commissioner to take into account that, in order to have a partnership and to be friends, we have to talk about human rights and, I say it again, in both directions.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! The partnership agreement obliges the EU and Egypt to respect and promote human rights on the basis of international standards. The reality in Egypt is different: civil society activists are being spied on, threatened and imprisoned, human rights organizations report torture, arbitrary arrests, the disappearance of detainees, unfair trials, and discrimination against minorities and women. Last year, following the murder of Giuglio Regeni, we passed a resolution here that clearly condemns the catastrophic human rights situation in Egypt. You, Commissioner Cañete, mentioned that you campaigned for this NGO law. But with what result? The latest partnership agreement is a wasted opportunity. The EU should have pushed harder for concrete improvements in the human rights situation. For example, she should have taken a clear position against this NGO law, which has now been passed. This restrictive law directly threatens the work of human rights organizations. The EU has failed to speak plainly to Egypt. Obviously, economic interests have priority. This can also be seen in the fact that numerous EU member states even export weapons to Egypt, in contradiction to the decision of the EU Foreign Ministers' Council of August 2013. I think that with this Egypt policy the EU and its member states are making their human rights policy there complicit.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Egypt and the European Union are committed to promoting democracy, fundamental freedoms, human rights as constitutional rights of all their citizens. Written words of the EU-Egypt 2017-2020 partnership, words that are paradoxical, bitterly surreal, thinking that in the territory of our partner, anyone who wants to investigate about 378 cases of forced disappearances, is brutally silenced, as evidenced by the recent case of the lawyer of the Regeni family, Ibrahim Metwaly Hegazy, locked up in the maximum security prison of Tora. All his clothes were removed and his body was subjected to electric shocks; he is in isolation with no electricity and the cell is full of garbage. This was said by the Egyptian Commission for Rights and Freedom, at whose headquarters the Egyptian authority will probably also put the seals today. Strengthening cooperation with Egypt is an aspiration we share but we cannot close our eyes, nor silence our voice in the face of the shameful silence on the kidnapping, torture and death of Giulio Regeni, an Italian boy, a European citizen. We are not and will not be accomplices of a utilitarian hypocrisy and today, as always, we are clamoring for truth and justice for Giulio Regeni.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, certainly the importance of this partnership agreement cannot be ignored by those who care, like us, the problem of the security of the Mediterranean, the problem of immigration, but also and perhaps above all, the serious problem of terrorism. Cairo's security collaboration is needed more than ever now that, after the defeat in Iraq and Syria, ISIS is shifting the operational axis of the Caliphate towards North Africa and the Sahel, that is, very close to Europe and in particular to my country, Italy: but it's not that I don't also see the gravity of the human rights situation. If we, as the European Union, want to be reliable and credible friends and partners of this country which I continue to regard as a friend, we must speak very clearly about some facts of exceptional gravity, such as those, repeatedly and rightly, mentioned by colleagues, like the truly emblematic case of Giulio Regeni, a boy sent from a European university - and it is also strange that the European Union did not want to deepen the role of this university and these teachers, what real assignments they had given to this young researcher, definitely in good faith. I would like to know what concrete actions the High Representative Mogherini has taken to defend the memory, the honor and above all the requests, also from a moral point of view, of two Italian parents who still have the right to know the end that made their son.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the European Union's partnership with Egypt is part of the revised European Neighborhood Policy and is summed up in addressing common challenges, promoting common interests and ensuring long-term stability in both Mediterranean regions. Egypt is a strategic partner of the European Union and therefore cooperates with it on other serious issues, such as ensuring stability in the Eastern Mediterranean region, promoting issues of common interest, tackling terrorism, tackling migration and finally the promotion of democracy. Egypt is committed to constitutionally guaranteeing the fundamental freedoms and human rights of its citizens and protecting the rights of migrants and marginalized people. He also collaborates on energy issues. In fact, the discovery of the super-giant ZOR deposit in the EEZ of Egypt will contribute to the promotion of cooperation between these two parties. Finally, I point out that Egypt 's tripartite cooperation with Greece and Cyprus will contribute to stability in the region and to the promotion of common foreign policy goals.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleagues, from now on and in future, the moment you exceed the time and continue speaking I shall see that as a mark of disrespect to your colleagues, so next time I will cut you off exactly to the second, regardless of the colleague concerned or the political group.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Egypt, because of its size, because of its strategic situation, because of its influence in the region and in the Arab world, because it is a member of the United Nations Security Council, is called to be a partner outstanding position of the European Union, both in its bilateral agenda and in the face of global problems. The Association Council meeting was held in July, and we believe this is positive news. He was suspended for seven years. We understand that in seven years a lot has happened in the Middle East, in Europe and in the world. That is why we have to adapt our cooperation agenda to the new configuration of threats, contribute to the stabilization of the region - obviously, it will not be possible until there is progress on the problem of Syria -, overcome the differences in the Council of Cooperation of the Gulf and, obviously, fight against terrorism. It is clear that cooperation in the field of security and energy efficiency and the fight against climate change, both competences of Commissioner Arias Cañete, are also very important. Here the importance of the new cooperation, the aid of the European Union, which has to be situated in the area of ​​the revised neighborhood policy, and we must also advance in the areas proposed by the European External Action Service has been underlined: economic and social development and modernization, trade and investment and, of course, not last and therefore least, in the field of respect for human rights. I want to remember what happened when the Muslim Brotherhood came to power democratically and I want to remember, Mr. President, in the face of some insinuations, that I resigned as head of the observation mission for the last presidential elections in Egypt.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Mr President, the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, has defined Egypt as a key partner for our common foreign policy, and my group also thinks the same: there are so many and so serious the scenarios that are open in the region, that collaboration , cooperation with Egypt appears as an imperative need for the cause of peace and stability. It is true that this association cannot be established at any price. I share many of the objectives set out in this Association Agreement and, stating them in reverse, I will start with human rights. Egypt has to change that course: it cannot continue with prisons full of opponents, harshly repressing civil society. The European Union cannot consent to it. In terms of security, Egypt has to continue to key more effectively to support for terror, to financial support for terror. In foreign policy, Egypt must be in a position to regain leadership in solving the conflict between Israel and Palestine. Its role in this matter is key, and Egypt must walk and must define itself as a democracy without nuances, but it is far from it. That is why, although I once again welcome the resumption of the talks, it seems to me very important that the European Union makes it clear that, if it goes against the rights of Egyptian citizens, we are not going to shut up.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Sir.Chairman!Egypt is, overall, a core ally of Europe, not just a core ally of the region, but also a benevolent and constructive power that normally works with us in Europe for our common interests.This is true when it comes to resisting terrorism, to our common security, to creating stability in a region that has a direct impact on our peace, security and stability here in Europe.This is also the case with the broader policy towards North Africa and the Middle East, most recently exemplified by the Egyptian efforts to make the Palestinian territories talk better together and perhaps to form a joint government again, which in the long run willbe the only way in which a realistic peace agreement can be reached between Israel and Palestine.We do not know what it will bring yet, but we know that without Egypt and the Arab allies we will get nowhere.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Mr. President, Egypt is a pole of stability in a Mediterranean on the brink of collapse. Tunisia is recovering from the so-called Arab Spring, Libya is a phantom state, Algeria is preparing for a transition fraught with threats. Commissioner, you talk about security and development, and you add human rights. Beware of human rights that go against security and development because in the end you will have neither security, nor development, nor human rights. Also, it is irresponsible to want to destabilize Egypt, in the name of human rights, while its government fights as best it can against the fundamentalism of the Muslim Brotherhood. We are, like many Muslim countries, at war against Islamist totalitarianism. It must be clear to us. In this war, men like Marshal Al-Sisi, General Haftar or Bashar El-Assad are ramparts for European countries, and those who want to destabilize them are accomplices of terrorism and enemies of Europe.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too am convinced of the strategic importance of Egypt's role in the Mediterranean chessboard and I believe that at the basis of the dialogue there is a common commitment also on the values ​​of democracy and respect for human rights, as well as signed in the preamble of the Association Council document. This is why I ask myself how it is possible today to talk about cooperation, trade, investments, immigration and terrorism in constant Egypt's heavy violations of this preamble, through repressive policies on human rights. Cases such as those of Ibrahim Metwaly, a lawyer committed on the rights front and involved in the sad story of Giulio Regeni, for which he strongly fought to obtain truth, detained in inhumane conditions or like that of his colleagues Ahmad Amasha Hanan and Badr el -Din. These are cases, like so many others, which are there to demonstrate that we have a duty to intervene, also using the tools that the partnership offers to ensure that they are released and Egypt changes register on human rights. Commissioner, I understand political realism but when it makes a clean sweep of moral principles, the problem arises and forcefully. We must be aware that the coherence and credibility of European foreign policy are also measured by how we deal with these problems.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, this House has shown extraordinary patience with Egypt, which is considered a key partner by many in the House. But I believe it is time we made up our mind. Can we stand by a partner where nearly 400 activists and dissidents have disappeared off the radar since August 2016? Where students like Giulio Regeni are murdered in cold blood? Where 22 people are arrested for waving rainbow flags, and where rockets are bought from North Korea? I share the concerns outlined by the High Representative over the economy and the ticking time bomb of youth unemployment, but we cannot let Egypt be the sole decider in our partnership, excluding any cooperation on the rule of law and fundamental rights. I have two questions to the Commissioner. Firstly, our total ongoing assistance to Egypt is worth EUR 11 billion. What are we doing to leverage this? Secondly, what measures have been taken to follow up on the resolution adopted last year following Regeni’s murder to stop companies from exploiting technology that contributes to human rights violations in Egypt?

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let's talk about partnership between the EU and Egypt: but what partnership can there be with a country that daily tramples on fundamental rights and without truth about the torture and barbaric killing of a young European researcher, Giulio Regeni: today there are 20 months that we ask for truth without getting it. The Egyptian authorities never cooperated effectively in the investigation. And this is indeed a battle for Julius but also for many others and others who find the same fate in Egypt. The forced disappearances, the serious intimidation of the lawyers who assist Giulio's family in Egypt continue, not least the arrest of Ibrahim Metwaly, and the attempt to close the offices of the Egyptian Commission for Human Rights and Freedoms. Giulio's parents were in this Parliament a year ago and asked for specific things, remaining unheard: stop sending weapons and espionage material, not consider Egypt a safe country, stop repatriation. Here, the lack of solidarity on the part of other European countries that have quietly continued to trade, including arms, with Egypt is scandalous and Tusk, when he meets al-Sisi in New York, speaks only of collaborating to stop migrants. If the EU turns a blind eye to respect for human rights, it has ceased to exist.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, our priorities and aspirations in our partnership with Egypt must also serve our peoples on both sides of the Mediterranean. Development on the one hand, but also human rights, social justice and decent living. Economic development and technical assistance from the European Union, but at the same time requirements for human rights and the rule of law. These go hand in hand in a balanced way. Indeed, Egypt has made substantial progress in many areas, including human rights, but at the same time, there are unanswered questions that need to be answered. But two challenges are high on our agenda: terrorism and energy security. I close, then, with one sentence: the stability of the el-Sisi government is the foundation of our common interests.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, we agree without any doubt on the opening of channels of communication with Egypt and we expect the same to happen with other countries in the region. Above all, however, we think that any economic or other relationship should offer the Egyptian people themselves, with more weight on vulnerable groups. In particular, we stand against the demands of the young people of Egypt for real democracy and freedom. Thorough research on basic human rights is therefore needed. To fight in the country any brutal behavior towards vulnerable groups.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as some colleagues have already said earlier, I think it is absurd to discuss Egypt and cooperation with Egypt in this Chamber without focusing on the constant violation of human rights.The family of Regeni, the parents of Giulio Reggiani, just a year ago, as my colleague Schlein recalled, asked the European Parliament to take a position on Egypt, on its continuous silence on the murder of Giulio Regni and on the tortures thatsuffered in Egypt.Continuing to consider Egypt as a safe country, continuing to ignore it, just to ensure that Egypt continues to prevent migrants from arriving in Europe is a crime, a crime that history will not forgive the European Union, just as the silence on the violation of human rights in Libya and on what Israel continues to do will not forgive her.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: – Mr President, like my colleagues, I am very worried about the situation for human rights defenders and human rights activists. I have met numerous women’s rights activists who are subject to extreme persecution at the moment.  But today I want to raise the specific situation of LGBTI persons being persecuted. I am sure you have seen the reports of this increasing persecution: of 33 or more youths being detained, of sexual assault in detention and of violence. It is also a question of when the authorities perpetrate this kind of violence. Public violence and hate speech against LGBTI people in Egypt are rampant and increasing, and we have reports on that. The EU must act against these human rights abuses. To say that we are passing on the message, Mr Commissioner, is just not enough: you don’t pass on the message about human rights – you demand that human rights be respected! We need a different kind of partnership.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Before I give the floor to the Commissioner I would like to express my appreciation for one thing across the political spectrum today, namely the emphasis on respect for human rights and on the clause in international agreements. I would appreciate it if we remembered this debate, because sometimes some of us deviate from that central principal. I note this with much appreciation, but we need to apply it across the board, with all international agreements. (End of catch-the-eye procedure)

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I think this has been a very useful exchange and I thank the honourable Members for their contributions. Many of you have addressed the different problems relating to human rights. Human rights are an integral part of our partnership priorities and we address the situation not only through bilateral dialogue, silent diplomacy and formal demands, but also through public statements, including in multilateral forums such as the Human Rights Council in Geneva. The European Union, in its position for the EU-Egypt Association Council, has raised clear concerns regarding the blocking of websites and the ongoing pressure on human rights organisations and defenders. It calls on Egypt to comply with its commitments to promote freedom of expression, association and assembly, as well as the freedom of the press, as guaranteed by the 2014 Constitution and according to its international obligations. This position was also expressed in the recent European Union statement at the Human Rights Council, under item 4. Some of you referred to the case of the Egyptian lawyer Ibrahim Metwaly. This is a case that the European Union is following very closely, and one we have raised with our Egyptian counterparts at a high level both in Cairo and in Brussels. We have stressed the need to allow human rights defenders to carry on their work, including cooperation with the United Nations human rights agencies and mechanisms, without intimidation or harassment, in line with Egypt’s international obligations and with the guarantees enshrined in the Egyptian Constitution for democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms. This message, as well as the need to shed light on the circumstances of the death of Giulio Regeni, was clearly expressed in our statement to the Association Council, and in the recent European Union statement at the Human Rights Council in Geneva. You can count on us to continue to insist on this in our contacts with our Egyptian counterparts at all levels. Some of you also referred to the LGBTI situation. The present position is that the arrest of an increasing number of people after the concert of rock band Mashrou’ Leila in Cairo and sentences of one to six years in prison for so-called ‘practices of debauchery’ are not in line with Egypt’s commitments to promote freedom of expression as guaranteed by the 2014 Constitution, nor with Egypt’s international obligations. Freedom of expression is essential in a democratic society, and we call on Egypt to take active measures to promote it and to abide by its national and international commitments in that regard. The European Union wishes to reaffirm its commitment to freedom of expression, and to the quality and dignity of all human beings, irrespective of their sexual orientation and gender identity. Finally, regarding the situation of Ibrahim Halawa, his acquittal is welcome news and a relief for his family, for Ireland and for the European Union. The Commission was particularly pleased to hear that Ibrahim was finally acquitted after four years in pre-trial detention. This is a case that the European Union has been following very closely and one we have actively raised with the Egyptian authorities, in coordination with and support of the Irish Government’s efforts. Nonetheless we remain concerned about the use of a mass trial in which 442 defendants received heavy prison sentences: this is not in line with Egypt’s human rights obligations. The European Union looks forward to the appeals and expects Egypt to uphold its national and international commitments to due process and fair trials. To conclude this debate, I think that we all agree on the importance of our partnership with Egypt, even if there are different views on how to take it forward. As I have stressed before, we now need to approach it in a coherent and comprehensive way in order to make the best out of it in the interests of Egyptians and Europeans. We will continue to look at how best to achieve progress on the four tracks of our partnership, and to use all the instruments available to us to foster a system of stability, growth and social and economic development in the country. We count, too, on Parliament’s support to contribute to the success of this partnership and its concrete impact on our people.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on – the oral question to the Council on the 2017 UN Climate Change Conference in Bonn, Germany (COP23) by Adina-Ioana Vălean, Peter Liese, Gilles Pargneaux, Julie Girling, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Estefanía Torres Martínez, Marco Affronte, Mireille D’Ornano and Piernicola Pedicini, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O—000068/2017 – B8—0329/2017) (2017/2620(RSP)), and – the oral question to the Commission on the 2017 UN Climate Change Conference in Bonn, Germany (COP23) by Adina-Ioana Vălean, Peter Liese, Gilles Pargneaux, Julie Girling, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Estefanía Torres Martínez, Marco Affronte and Piernicola Pedicini, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O—000069/2017 – B8—0330/2017) (2017/2620(RSP)).

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: author. – Mr President, it has been almost two years since the birth of the Paris Agreement and almost exactly one year since its entry into force on 4 November 2016. 195 parties have signed up to the Agreement to date and 166 of these have already deposited with the UN their instruments of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession to what one might qualify as the most significant multilateral international agreement of the decade. Undoubtedly, climate change is one of the most important challenges for humankind. Those of us who believe in the science explaining climate change keep on stressing this fact and the associated disastrous consequences for both our present and our future. But we should also act on our beliefs. The Paris Agreement was a major step, but a lot more needs to be done to ensure that this agreement will deliver on its intentions. We all know in this House from our work on European legislation that if it is hard to agree on a common set of policy design and the numbers, it is even harder to implement them in a meaningful way. And this is where we are with the Paris Agreement. For the past year, preparatory work has started that will go on well into 2018 laying down the foundation for the implementation of the accord. We are one month away from the start of the 23rd climate conference in Bonn, which will be a milestone in the technical work on the implementing rules for the agreement. We expect quite importantly that there will be some clarification on the structure of the 2018 facilitative dialogue. This will be a key opportunity to take stock of progress made towards the agreement’s mitigation goals and to inform the preparation and revision, by 2020, of the parties’ 2030 nationally determined contributions. The regrettable decision by the President of the United States to withdraw his country from the Paris Agreement will have numerous implications but, most worryingly, it has an immediate impact on climate financing, which is one of the cornerstones for international climate action. The suspension of US contributions to the Green Climate Fund will open up substantially a hole which we have all been working hard to fill. These are very pertinent issues that we look forward to discussing today with both the Council and the Commission, who will both be sitting at the negotiation table in Bonn in 4 weeks’ time. As every year, in line with our commitment to the international climate process, the European Parliament will attend the Bonn conference and follow the discussion and decisions made there, and through its privileged contacts with parliamentarians from around the world will support the EU position. Tomorrow we will be adopting our resolution on the topic, which sets out the vision, concerns, expectations and aspirations of our institution. This will also constitute our mandate for the Bonn conference. I am looking forward to a fruitful exchange with all of you this afternoon, as well as much cooperation between our institutions in the run-up to and during the climate negotiations in November.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me highlight at the outset that by the United Nations Climate Change Conference taking place in November this year in Bonn, known as COP 23, all Member States should have finalised their ratification procedures for the Paris Agreement.  By this step we confirm our credibility and our responsibility. The EU and its Member States have reaffirmed clearly their commitment to continued climate action in line with the objectives of the Paris Agreement. Despite the political changeover in the US, we are encouraged by good news from other countries moving forward on climate action. The international community, including non-state actors, remains committed to implementation of the Paris Agreement. This was also demonstrated during the Hamburg G20 summit held on 7 and 8 July and the recent Montreal Ministerial Meeting on climate action that took place in September.  The upcoming conference in Bonn will be an important occasion to demonstrate the collective determination of the international community on climate action. The EU and its Member States have expectations for broad-ranging progress at COP 23 and we are working closely with our international partners to ensure it is a success.  Firstly, COP 23 must establish a solid foundation for the completion of the Paris work programme by COP 24 next year in Katowice, Poland. This should include making substantial progress on the work programme with a view to finalising it next year and to preparing for the implementation of all provisions of the Paris Agreement, comprising mitigation, adaptation, means of implementation, support and the transparency framework. It is important that we achieve clarity on the process for next year, so that all parties and external stakeholders are reassured that we will deliver on our task. We expect an agreement on the 2018 facilitative dialogue at COP 23. The dialogue will be the key political moment at COP 24 and the first opportunity after Paris to take stock of our collective efforts towards achieving the objectives of the Paris Agreement. It will help inform the preparation of subsequent nationally determined contributions or NDCs. Therefore the EU considers that COP 23 should result in a clear proposal on how the 2018 facilitative dialogue should be prepared, outlining the work for next year.  In this respect non-party stakeholder contributions will be key in terms of presenting policy options, approaches and technologies with high potential, experiences and lessons learned. They also bring concrete opportunities to overcome barriers in NDC implementation and international cooperation, such as partnerships through the Global Climate Action agenda. With regard to the transparency framework, it is important to have comparable and robust methodologies to track progress and make sure that the chosen policy instruments have the desired impact in terms of reducing emissions or increasing resilience. COP 23 should result in significant progress on the details of the modalities, procedures and guidelines of the framework. Further action by all parties, individually and collectively, will be required to reorient and make finance flows consistent with a pathway towards low greenhouse gas emissions and climate resilient development. The EU and its Member States are the world’s biggest climate finance donor. In 2015 it provided, together with the European Investment Bank, EUR 17.6 billion for climate finance to third countries. The EU will continue to support climate action in partner countries and is fully committed to the implementation of the 2020 climate finance roadmap. We remain committed to scaling the mobilisation of climate finance as part of a global effort to assist developing countries to implement their low-carbon sustainable development, and in particular their NDCs. Domestic implementation, climate policies and measures to achieve intended nationally determined contributions and their full integration into national policies are of crucial importance. At this stage the Council and Parliament are the key actors currently working on completion of the EU’s own legislative and regulatory package that is necessary to deliver our Paris target of reducing economy-wide emissions by at least 40% by 2030. That remains the most ambitious pledge under the Agreement. This is an important sign of leadership as the success of Paris will ultimately depend on concrete action on the ground.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, President Juncker stressed in his recent State of the Union address that he wants Europe to be the leader when it comes to the fight against climate change. He added that, set against the collapse of ambition in the United States, Europe must ensure we make our planet great again because it is the shared heritage of all humanity. Recently, the European Union, Canada and China convened a Ministerial Meeting on Climate Action. This was the first ministerial meeting of its kind, bringing together three major economies in a leadership role and gathering ministers from more than 30 countries, including both major economies and also some of the most vulnerable countries, to discuss how to advance global action on climate change. For the UN Climate Change Conference in Bonn (COP23) the European Union envisages three broad areas of deliverables. Firstly, there should be substantial progress on developing the detailed modalities, procedures and guidelines of the Paris Agreement with a view to concluding them by 2018. Secondly, we need to find political agreement on the design of the ‘Facilitative Dialogue’ that will take place in 2018. This is a clear deliverable expected by COP23 from the Moroccan and Fijian Presidencies, as was mandated by the decision in Marrakech. Thirdly, the European Union attaches great importance to the Global Climate Action Agenda to expand multi—stakeholder action and further build momentum. Let me elaborate further on the first deliverable. The Paris Agreement achieved comprehensive coverage of mitigation, adaptation and means of implementation by treating these and other issues in a balanced and tailored way. The delicate balance set in Paris now needs to be made operational through detailed modalities, procedures and guidelines. Priority areas to advance are the work programme that includes the Paris transparency framework and the five-yearly global stocktake. The transparency framework will make it possible to track progress made on all parties’ commitments, for both adaptation and mitigation as well as support, according to common agreed rules and methodology, and to compare and aggregate results in terms of emission reductions and assess progress towards the global goal on adaptation. The global stocktake is one of the fundamental features of the Paris Agreement and it is the key element of a wider ambition cycle that will inform and incentivise processes progressively to enhance ambitious action, both domestically and collectively. At European Union level, the proposal for the 2030 legislative framework provides for a review in 2024, and every five years thereafter, of the overall functioning of the legislation, in order to take account of evolving national circumstances and to be informed by the results of the global stocktake under the Paris Agreement. Coming back to the second deliverable, the 2018 Facilitative Dialogue is intended to take stock of the collective efforts of parties in relation to progress towards the long-term emissions reduction goal and inform the preparation of further or updated nationally determined contributions (NDCs). The European Union sees the 2018 Facilitative Dialogue as an important milestone in promoting subsequent discussions about ambition. Parties will have to consider and explain what the outcomes of the 2018 Facilitative Dialogue imply for them individually in terms of their domestic processes. In the context of the insufficient global ambition currently on the table, the Commission supports the European Union’s active participation in the dialogue as a first important opportunity to take stock of the collective efforts of parties and to demonstrate how we have been preparing for the implementation of our NDC. Looking ahead, and to facilitate the preparation of long-term strategies, the Commission is preparing an in-depth analysis of the economic, social and environmental impacts of pathways coherent with the long-term temperature goals of the Paris Agreement in order to stimulate the political debate in the European Parliament and the Council and with stakeholders. Let me give you some further comments on climate finance. The Commission participated closely with many Member States in the development of the donors’ 2020 USD 100 billion road map. We remain committed to the collective goal of mobilising, from a variety of sources, USD 100 billion a year in climate finance by 2020 for climate action in developing countries, and continuing significantly to increase adaptation finance. However, neither the European Union nor any other party acting alone can be expected to fill the gap left by the United States. We need to work collectively and look for innovative solutions and scalability. In that respect the COP21+2 Climate Summit convened by the French Government, the United Nations and the World Bank in Paris on 12 December will usefully complement the COP23 Conference and should help us work better together to redirect public and private investments towards the clean energy transition. Lastly, looking beyond the amount of finance mobilised, we must also consider the important role of technical cooperation for the implementation of the Paris Agreement and of NDCs. In that respect, we are mobilising technical support from across Europe to share our experience and help partner countries develop and implement climate policies and measures.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Let us now listen to the statements of the political groups.At this stage, "blue card" questions are not allowed.

name: Peter LIESE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen! I think the most important signal that the conference in Bonn must send out is that we continue to push the process forward - even after Donald Trump's announcement. The rest of the world sticks together, climate protection remains an important task, and we are very happy that many in the USA have recognized this too. It is sad that, in view of the floods and hurricanes, the President and his advisors have not yet started thinking. Of course, you can never attribute a single extreme weather event to climate change, but it is clear from science that such events would increase if we acted like Trump and not like the rest of the world. Therefore, I think it is good that we are making this very clear in our resolution: the process must go on, and we are pleased that states and others in the USA are continuing to participate. The EPP approved the resolution in committee because it contains many very important points. Above all, it was important to us that the amendments tabled by the Industry Committee were taken into account, that we also think about the competitiveness of industry and that extreme motions were rejected, and fortunately they were not tabled again in plenary. I think we have a balanced resolution overall. We would like to improve it a bit with our two amendments, but I believe that we will in any case vote tomorrow. I would like to thank our Chair, Adina Văleano, everyone who helped bring about this result, and I look forward to a strong signal to the US and the rest of the world when we vote tomorrow in plenary.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: , on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the Paris Agreement is irreversible and non-negotiable. This is the message we send to the President of the United States in our joint resolution on COP 23. The announcement of this withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement has finally galvanized the 194 other signatories of COP 21. and, since June 1, heads of state and government around the world have consistently reaffirmed their commitment to keep the global temperature rise between 2.4 degrees and 6.6 degrees by 2050. Mr. Commissioner, the European Union is, in our view, the new leader that the world needs to effectively fight climate change. This is why we encourage you to address at COP 23 in Bonn the following seven priorities: The creation of innovative financing to fight against climate change, with the setting of a floor price for the tonne of carbon and the reform of the system European carbon trading; The establishment of a true circular economy and the revitalization of renewable energies; The removal of subsidies allocated to the fossil fuel sector, which will ultimately lead to the abandonment of fossil fuels; Intensifying efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions produced by the transport and agricultural sectors to achieve the targets set for 2020 and 2030; Realization of the financial commitment of developed countries to provide $ 100 billion per year to developing countries by 2020; The promotion of universal access to sustainable energy in developing countries, in particular in Africa, which has an incredible potential in renewable energies, for the moment untapped; The impact of climate change on migration and the international recognition of climate refugee status. Yes sir Commissioner, you are discussing, we are discussing in Bonn, these seven priorities, COP23 will be a success.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Mr Chairman!Commissioner!The Paris Agreement was a groundbreaking document based on two key elements: flexible formulation of own commitments adjusted to economic opportunities and resignation from the postulate of decarbonisation.Unfortunately, in today's resolution, this compromise is no longer seen as necessary to strike a balance between the will to act ambitiously and the real opportunities.The conference in Bonn and the climate summit in Katowice are a great opportunity to work out solutions that will allow the parties to the Paris Agreement to maintain the feeling that together and at a reasonable pace we are going towards a common goal.The most important thing is to actually improve the comfort of our lives and future generations, and not to choke European industry.I hope the Commissioner was kind to listen to my speech.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and the Council for their statements. It is two years, and unfortunately a record number of hurricanes, floods and heat waves, since Paris, and while Marrakech last year was a sort of post-Paris party (though unfortunately under some dark clouds due to the newly elected US President, Donald Trump), the real work will start now again in Bonn, because it is really very important that we clarify the structure of the facilitative dialogue in 2018.
