This facilitative dialogue should provide us with a clear picture of where we stand, because Paris was a huge success, but we knew even  while we were still applauding there that it was not enough; that it was not enough to stay within the 1.5 degrees or even the 2 degrees. The facilitative dialogue can therefore lead only to one conclusion: that we have to do more, that we are falling short at the moment. That is why we should not allow the US to renegotiate the commitments that it made in Paris. That is crucial, absolutely. But it also means how crucially important it is that we do our work on both the emission trading system, on the effort sharing, and on the energy package. We seriously have to deliver on Paris, and not only that: we also have to work on proper implementation. It is wonderful news that our economy is growing again, really good news, but at the same time we see that even in our Member States CO2 emissions are growing again. They are growing instead of decreasing – and that is something that we should really work on. It is great that we applauded Paris, but we cannot applaud without delivering on the promises that we made there.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, as you know, COP21 was the conference of decisions. From her was born the Paris agreement. COP22 was said to be one of solutions, but rather it was one of paradoxes. Now I will tell you what COP23 should be: either it is the one about economic commitments, or we will definitely be late. We urge this Parliament today to support the efforts of developing countries in the transition to low-carbon societies, so that they are more sustainable and safer. But we must also urge ourselves to stop making policies at the service of the markets and start making them at the service of the people. Because, do we really believe that the energy transition and the trade policy of the European Union are compatible, especially with the fight against climate change? It is not. We have said it many times: as long as there is no change in the economic growth model, there will be no way to alleviate the environmental deterioration of the planet. We need a profound change in our production system. Energy transition, yes, but we also need changes in the global agri-food system. The battle for the climate is political and faces two different views of the world. In this COP23, we hope that the vision of the world of women, especially of farmers and indigenous women, will gain prominence, and that the vision of energy lobbies and multinationals will lose all power, who speak, many times, through our governments.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the truth is that we are even a little tired of talking about climate change in this House. COP 23 is important, our resolution is well done and it is equally important for all the reasons that our colleagues have already said. And then we read precisely in these days the figures that in 2016, as in previous years, the Member States of the European Union have donated to fossil fuels: € 112 billion in funding. 112 billion that are nailed a little to the past and do not allow us to move forward towards change. We don't even know if this figure is correct because there is no transparency on these funds or subsidies; therefore, it could even be a partial figure and the amount could be even greater. But we know that 44% of these funds go for example to the transport sector. This has allowed and allows Sergio Marchionne of FCA to say that electric cars are double-edged weapons and that it is preferable to improve petrol engines instead. Obviously, electric cars are not the only solution, we too know it well, but if Marchionne can afford to say this it is precisely because the market is altered by the subsidies that are given through public money. The European Union puts four billion into it directly, to which are added those that the European Investment Bank and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development put in it: if they seem few to you, know that, in just one year, there are five times what we give, in the period from 2014 to 2020, to welcome migrants. So, what exactly are we talking about when we talk about fighting climate change?

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the climate and energy package was imposed by the EU with the objective of achieving by 2020 a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions compared to 1990 levels. Since then, climate-obsessive politicians have set various objectives towards establishing targets that would involve the final deindustrialisation of Europe. We in UKIP disagree with the climate change alarmism which is the cause of the EU's current damaging and counterproductive energy policy. However, the Commission continues to impose never-ending objectives for emissions reductions which invest vast amounts of money into activities that will have little or no effect on climate. Realistically, we can expect global CO2 emissions to keep rising for several decades. The massive exit of EU industry and investment is not only damaging our economies, but by its relocation to countries with lower environmental standards it actually increases CO2 emissions. After Brexit the EU will be in charge of its own destiny and we in Britain will be able to formulate our own energy policy. The British people are looking forward to cheaper, reliable and affordable energy.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to briefly disturb your feel-good atmosphere with a few figures: China is responsible for a little more than 28% of the CO2 emissions in this world. The USA is responsible for around 16% of the CO2 emissions in the world. India stands for over 6%, Russia for around 4.5%. Together, these four countries account for 55% of the world's CO2 emissions. China has announced that it will not reduce its CO2 emissions until 2030. The US - as you all complain here - has already announced that it will withdraw from the climate agreement. India has ongoing plans for 370 new coal-fired power plants. 370 new coal-fired power plants, ladies and gentlemen, you will not be able to save that much CO2 in the entire European Union in the coming decades! Russia has not yet ratified and has announced it for 2020. We'll see. What am I telling you? When Mr Juncker says that the EU should take the lead, he probably means that the EU is a featherweight when it comes to climate protection. These are dwarfs who want to achieve something together. Ladies and gentlemen, dear climate alarmists, orient yourself towards what is feasible! The world's climate will not be saved in the European Union, it will not be saved by the European Union, and you are making a fool of yourself with your demands in front of the world in Bonn.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - President!In December 2015, this Parliament celebrated the outcome of the Paris meeting by launching a new era in the field of climate protection.Why?Because there are allegedly legally accountable commitments.I turned to the Commission.I asked how will President Obama’s commitment to the U.S. leadership be held accountable in the future?Mr Cañete was fully reassured that it was mandatory for the US to do this.A new era began when President Trump removed the world’s second-largest polluter from the Paris Agreement.Of course, the European Union must live up to its responsibilities, take the lead, but it is completely absurd what President Juncker is saying that the European Union will take the place of the United States and make commitments instead, while we are only responsible for ten percent of emissions.This would completely destroy European industry.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We have listened to all the political groups.From now on it is possible to use the "blue card" questions.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Mr President, the aim of the COP23 conference in Bonn is to advance the talks on the guidelines for the implementation of the Paris Agreement. We have good news from many countries, 166 countries have submitted their ratification documents and the agreement is, in our opinion, a great success of the Paris Conference, in particular because of these voluntary commitments by many countries. However, we are faced with many challenges that are not necessarily reflected in the negotiations. The position of the United States is important, we have already heard declarations about leaving the agreement, staying and renegotiating. For the whole agreement, it would be good for the United States to stay in agreement and fulfill its provisions, so the worst situation is such a state of uncertainty. In many countries, too, and this has also been said in this House, decisions are being made that are contrary to the Paris Agreement. On the other hand, the data on greenhouse gas emissions for the last year are pleasing, according to which global emissions only slightly increased, which may indicate that perhaps we are somewhere close to the peak of emissions, these emissions will soon begin to decline. As Parliament, we will be taking part in the Bonn conference with the support of a mandate, which Parliament will adopt tomorrow in the form of a resolution. The five-year action plans and periodic assessments of progress in reducing emissions will also be an important element.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: - Għalija, il-konferenza tat-tibdil fil-klima f’Bonn hija pass importanti favur progress fuq tibdil fil-klima. Il-Gvernijiet, iva, huma importanti, imma nemmen li dan huwa ż-żmien għall-ibliet, għan-negozji u għaċ-ċittadini tagāna, biex ikunu huma li jmexxu t-triq 'il quddiem. I have learned that there is an impulse policy in this way, and we are looking for more people. If this approach is to be taken into account in the case of a fil-climate, the milling method will be used as a last resort, and the system will be replaced by the following policies, flok nibqgħu nitkellmu dwar spejjeż biss, ejja nibdew nitkellmu dwar benefiċċji, u benefiċċji hemm ħafna. Fejn flok noqogħdu niffukaw fuq x’jista ’jiġri għada, ejja nibdew niffukaw fuq x’inhu jiġri llum madwarna. U dan kollu huwa dwar il-ħtieġa li nagħmlu l-ħajja taċ-ċittadini tagāna ferm aħjar. Li naġixxu fuq it-tibdil fil-klima jfisser li pereżempju nibdew innaqqsu l-attakki ta 'ażma li jsofru minnhom it-tfal, li nsalvaw membri tal-familji tagħna minn mard respiratorju, li nüdid l-ammonti ta' snin stess, li nnaqqsu, iva, il-kontijiet tal-enerġija tagāna, li ntejbu l-kwalità tal-ħajja tagāna u niduidu n-numru ta 'impjiegi fil-komunitajiet tagāna. COP23, nemmen, li se toffrilna opportunità, li jekk irridu, immexxu d-diskussjoni dwar il-klima fejn waħda li ssolvi l-problemi u tidentifika l-opportunitajiet. In this case, it is well-known that the human rights are very effective and that they are well-known.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Mr President, the inaction shown so far has resulted in catastrophic hurricanes, the aggravation of energy poverty, the further deforestation of forests, the irreparable pollution of the seas, and the continuing destruction of our planet. Also, because we did not block the uncontrolled action of the multinationals, we were led, among other things, to the big scandal with the pollutants in the automotive industry. It is no longer possible to remain in the announcements without making binding decisions for effective action. The Paris Agreement achieved an important framework for tackling climate change. However, unfortunately, the 22nd Climate Conference in Marrakesh did not make the progress we expected for immediate action. The 23rd Bonn Conference must not be another pointless repetition of declarations and crocodile tears over the state of the environment and the aggravation of environmental problems. In view of this Conference, we call on the Commission, regardless of the Trump administration's intention to withdraw the US, to work with China and other countries, to support developing countries and to develop a comprehensive action plan to end the reckless use of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and promoting renewable energy sources.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, it is great that we are again talking here about climate action, and I want to stress that word ‘action’, because the Commission also said that Europe wants to be the leader in climate action, did it not? So then, maybe it is time to act as well, and that is going to be the key. Up to now Europe has just had plans on the table there are insufficient to meet the Paris goals. We all know that. We have to do more. So, Commission, when you are reading Parliament’s resolution, please also note that we are demanding for next year a low emission strategy for 2050, because we need this long-term planning. After the facilitative dialogue next year, we need new NDCs in Europe where we are increasing our action. Only then will we be the leading continent on climate action which we claim to be. But it is not only about numbers and targets. This is about our future economy, and I say this to our nationalist friends on the right who are always very proud of what we can achieve as a country but then suddenly when it is about climate action, suddenly they say we are little, we are small, it does not matter what we do. Come on, stay on and be consistent! This is about our future economy. If we take the lead, the jobs will be here. If we do not take the lead, we will suffer from climate change and will have to import the technologies from all those regions that you so much fear. So be clever and take action now!

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: –Mr President, having listened to the last speaker I can say I disagree with every single word he says. This ludicrous myth of man-made global warming is going to impact on agriculture. Farmers apparently are going to have to improve the world weather by emitting fewer greenhouse gases. There are two of them that we it emit where we find ourselves in total contradiction to EU dogma. The first is CO2. We emit CO2 by tractor use, exhausts and engines running. If we are seriously going to reduce that on farms, we’re going to have to reduce our tractor usage and that means we must go to no-till agriculture, which means using glyphosate and adopting GM crops. You hate those two things more than you actually hate CO2. Then of course we've got the other juxtaposition on nitrous oxide. We produce nitrous oxide by growing leguminous crops. Yet we are told by the EU ‘you must grow more leguminous crops’ because they will substitute for all the GM soya beans coming in from South America. I could go on, Mr President, but I'm out of time.  (Applause)

name: Olaf STUGER
text: - Wonderful speech from my predecessor. I always want to start these debates by saying that the question is whether humans have anything to do with climate change. In any case, the scientists disagree on this. What bothers me very much is that there is very little room in the social debate to discuss this at all. There is a Dutch documentary maker, Marijn Poels, who has made a documentary in which it becomes very clear that when you are only a little negative about it or you wonder whether people have anything to do with it, zero on it. is petitioned and immediately dismissed as a pariah. Whether humans have an influence on it or not, Al Gore believes that humans have an influence on the climate. That doesn't stop him from flying around the world with a private plane all year round. And what he also has a lot of influence on is his own financial climate. I checked: if you want to book Al Gore, for example as a speaker for part of the day, you will have lost 200,000 euros. Yes, I say 200,000. Then you have to book ten rooms in a five-star hotel for his entourage. And then of course you also have to pay for that private flight. So, I am sure of that. What I also know for sure is that the energy bill of Dutch households has increased by 200 euros in the past four years. So that is again old-fashioned, proverbial, the sjaak, Chairman. And that is outright theft.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, efforts to combat global warming and the human interventions that cause it have not had the desired results. Many countries have remained in simple commitments, not accompanied by practical applications, while some others do not join the Paris Agreement due to economic and political interests. But the effects of global warming on climate, oceans, health and agriculture are undeniable and tend to be irreversible. Whether we are talking about global warming or supercooling, the fact is that the earth has reached the limit of absorption of hazardous pollutants, gases, liquids and solids. This fact is of course used as a field of confrontation between scientists and politicians, especially former communists of the existing socialism who dressed in the cloak of green ecologists, and I consider that environmental protection is a serious matter to be entrusted to either them or the European Parliament.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Europe must exercise leadership in achieving the objectives that we set ourselves at COP21 and, in this sense, today 20% of the Union budget is allocated to actions to combat climate change. We are in the process of updating the emissions trading market and establishing a circular economy that minimizes waste and optimizes raw materials, and we must do more. It will be of little use if we have an agreement if, in the end, it is not fulfilled or if the main actors do not end up getting involved, favoring a situation of outsourcing of the European industry that ends up maintaining the same number of emissions and, therefore, not There is no progress in the environmental part, and on the other hand, rebound, we have a serious negative impact on the social and economic part in Europe. Therefore, we want to ask the Commission and the Council to ensure that in compliance with the Paris Agreement, a constructive dialogue is held to achieve the objectives that we have set for ourselves between all parties and that the necessary resources arrive to achieve the objective. a combined US $ 100 billion per year by 2020. It has been two years since we reached the Agreement, and each minute that passes takes us further from the goal.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: - Mister President! COP23 is taking place in Germany, but the presidency lies with a country that has already been hugely affected by climate change - the Fiji Islands - as do the other island states in the Pacific. I therefore believe, along with other colleagues here in the House, that Bonn must be a moment again when the world is committed to the Paris Agreement and climate protection and where we put the climate doubters and critics in their place, point them into isolation. We know that at the moment we are, of course, closer to the three-degree Celsius target than the two-degree Celsius target. So there is no doubt that industrialized countries like the EU member states still have to do more. I hope, Commissioner, that we can relaunch the High Ambition Coalition. We have to do that with our 2030 Agenda. Parliament is proposing much higher targets for renewable energies and energy efficiency than the Commission did, and by 2030 we must also become much better. I believe that we have to have the goals clear in the long term up to 2050 - the actors have to know where we're headed - and climate protection is also development policy, it is also industrial policy. China has been mentioned here. Commissioner, you are doing things together with China. Be careful that China does not overtake us at the pace of renewal and technological change.

name: Stefan ECK
text: –Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The time window to do something about global warming is getting smaller and smaller. We need a transformation towards politics that focus on caring for the planet and its people - and not on economic growth, corporate profits and the creation of as many jobs as possible. In order to achieve the climate goals, we have to focus more on climate-damaging emissions from agriculture. I have already pointed out several times here in this House that the global meat and dairy industry is responsible for around 18% of the emissions calculated in CO2 equivalents. According to the latest studies, the clearing of land for livestock farming even accounts for 20%. That is why the national climate protection contributions, as far as agriculture is concerned, must be massively improved. Agriculture, which is harmful to the climate, in particular factory farming, has to face up to it. Whether we will save our earth from a climate collapse depends on the political will to break new ground. I hope, Commissioner, that you will also bring up these explosive topics in Bonn.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, we have had it all this year: droughts, floods, fires and hurricanes that it is time to rename Exxon, Total, BP or Trump! Obviously, we need the Paris agreement, but the Paris agreement is two things: diplomacy, with an ambitious, serious objective of 1.5 or 2 degrees, but it is also action climate and, on this point, the climate action of States, today, it is 3, 4, 5 degrees of global warming. Therefore, it is chaos. Our topic is to move from diplomacy to climate action because that's where all schizophrenia slip in. My President of the Republic, Emmanuel Macron, the President of France, guarantor of the Paris Agreement, gives a magnificent speech on the climate at the United Nations but, at the European level, you know, he sabotages the objectives in renewable energies and it sabotages European cooperation strategies on climate action. Yes, the good news is that the European Union needs to be a leader in climate action. The good news is that the European Union has it all: cheap renewables, jobs created, land use planning. So, for the European Union to become the leader in climate action, it is good for the climate and it is a wonderful project for all Europeans.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: – Mr President, I have been listening to my colleagues’ beautiful words about the future of our countries and the future of our children, and I think they have been the best words we can say in such circumstances. My question is, how many of you really want to pass from words to facts? Because it is a fact that climate change and global warming are caused by fossil fuels. However, while we are here, among the best words we can say to save the planet, the governments of the Member States are financing fossil fuels with an incredible – an astronomical – amount of money. While we are here speaking, France is giving EUR 250 million to the Green Fund but at the same time financing fossil fuels to the tune of EUR 1.5 billion. Germany is giving EUR 250 million to the Green Fund but at the same time financing fossil fuels to the tune of EUR 5.5 billion. And Italy, my country, while contributing only EUR 84 million to the Green Fund, is at the same time financing fossil fuels with EUR 3.5 billion. We are here to find the best solution to save the planet and not to find the best compromise with oil companies. Therefore, let us stop saying beautiful words and let us move on to facts. Let us eliminate subsidies for fossil fuels right now. There is nothing else to do.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: - The Paris Agreement demands it: all sectors together for the salvation of the global climate. That is why I ask the Commission and the Member States in particular to finally recognize and financially promote the climate efforts of family and family farms in European agriculture. I remind you that the Paris Agreement requires countries to adapt to the negative effects of climate change in a way that does not endanger food production. Farmers and horticulturists in Member States such as the Netherlands are already fully engaged in reducing their greenhouse gas emissions and with a climate-friendly production method for our daily bread - with toppings. That is why the European Union must quickly get started on action plans for financing climate-efficient agriculture, as Parliament also demanded in the ESA report, the Gerbrandy report. The growing world population develops a growing food demand. The growing middle class outside our continent demands "luxury" food such as meat and dairy. Because of the global climate and the precious rainforest, the European Union, which will soon be participating in Bonn, must prevent carbon and investment leakage from European agricultural production to third countries in all climate measures! Our farmers and gardeners produce sustainable food for the world's population. We need to nurture our European farmers and horticulturists, help them transition, give them more confidence and ultimately be clear about the climate transition. Ultimately, this is of great importance for a liveable countryside.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, how good it is to pat yourself on the shoulder and congratulate yourself on a job well done. From COP to COP, we like to portray the European Union as being at the forefront of the climate fight. And yet, what do we see? That certain 3X20 objectives will not be met, that the ETS system, even revised for phase 4, will remain far too generous for polluters, not ambitious enough to achieve objectives and will generate a CO2 price that is far too low to reorient priorities. That the TTF, which some imagined could finance the Green Fund, has still not seen the light of day. And yet, what do we hear? That the Stiglitz report mentions a price for all global emissions of between 50 and 100 dollars for 2030, we are very far from it. We therefore need urgent measures, and I have been advocating, for example, for the implementation of the carbon adjustment at the borders for a long time, but it has been talked about for so long and nothing has changed. This lack of political will is reinforced by the comfort of telling ourselves that we are doing better than others. We know Talleyrand's formula: "When I look at myself, I feel sorry, when I compare myself, I console myself", but we should be wary, because if we are all sorry, it is our children and our grandchildren who will be. sorry.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: - Mister President! Anyone who takes the Paris climate goals and climate science seriously knows that we only have a very tight budget for greenhouse gas emissions. And, Mr Arias Cañete, this directly to you: the climate targets that you represent for the European Commission and that are not exceeded or topped in the Council mean that almost everything that the EU Member States do within the framework of the Paris targets may still be released until 2030 will be used up. Their hesitation over the years means that emissions will be after 2030 - in just a decade! - then have to be brought to zero if we want to have even a slim chance of reaching the 2-degree target. And the lack of courage and the whole reluctance in the European Commission not only mean that we are losing out on climate protection, but at the same time the European Union is left behind in the international competition for creative solutions and future-proof technologies. It is already the case today - Jo Leinen mentioned this - that the creative solutions, clean cars, solar and efficiency technologies are politically supported and promoted outside the European Union - for example in China - that the production sites will also be built there and that the work of the future takes place there. We think that what coal and steel were in the founding phase of the European Community, namely its focus, and what was done there, must now become efficiency technologies, climate technologies, and that this is where the real renewal of the European Union's industrial location lies .

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, we do not need a lot of evidence to believe in the existence of climate change, they are evident. And that is why I am guided by the speech of Jean-Claude Juncker, who said that we as the European Union must take the lead in the fight against climate change when he spoke about the state of the European Union. Clearly, it will be very difficult to make up for the exit of the United States, but Bonn is an opportunity for the European Union to continue to be a leader here. But it is necessary to move from our political decisions really to concrete actions and we must concretize our decisions. In particular, we need to reach 100 billion euros a year or dollars a year by 2020, which we talked about, in order to really be able to implement all these conclusions. What I believe in is energy efficiency, it’s energy security, it’s less air pollution to affect people’s better health. I also believe that it is necessary to use in any case in any diplomatic dialogue, to use as our strategic basis, speech on climate change and the fight against climate change. We also have to fight against all these situations by always putting climate change at the forefront, to fight at the level of the entire planet. No national policy, no national strategy can bring results on its own and so we go to Bonn together and try to continue to position ourselves as the bearers of the fight against climate change. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- President!Honorable Member, you said that the time had come for action to be taken and that we had listed a great many things that could be done.I respectfully ask whether you would be willing to expand this list of tasks by saying that the European Union must also reflect its will in its trade agreements.In Hungarian, to make discounts and trade discounts conditional on compliance with the provisions of the Paris Agreement.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- Mr. President, I completely agree with you and believe that the trade agreements we enter into and sign must have exactly these characteristics, and that is the fight against climate change and must carry everything that leads to sustainable development.I agree with you.I am sorry that we are leaving the negotiations with the United States, and I am looking forward to the entry into force of CETA and continuing negotiations with New Zealand and other countries, and I believe that the European Union will protect its interests and the interests of our nation states.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with this resolution, we reaffirm our commitment to implement, with force and coherence, the Paris Agreement on the fight against climate change, Trump or not.We need a new model of more sustainable development at an economic, environmental and social level to get out of the crisis and produce new and good jobs for our young people.The European goal of reducing emissions by 40% by 2030 passes through commitments that cross all sectors of the economy and at all institutional levels, from states to local communities.Particularly in transport, responsible for 25% of global emissions, a gap concerning heavy vehicles must quickly be filled: even the emissions of trucks and buses, which cause 40% of road transport pollution, must beequal to those of cars, certified, monitored and regulated by European standards.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: – Mr President, the presence of the fossil lobby at the climate conferences is a huge conflict of interest that we need to address. Soon the world will be going to Bonn. Politicians, scientists and civil society will be there to seek solutions to the climate crisis. But the dirty coal and oil lobby will also be there and they have an economic interest in trying to delay, water down and prevent those solutions. We need strong rules on conflicts of interest if we are going to be able to limit emissions so that we can stay below 1.5°C. We have no time to waste. This is about our children’s future. The fossil lobby should not be allowed to pollute climate policy. I urge you all to support the Green Group amendment on conflicts of interest.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, in March of this year the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) observed that sea ice had reached a record low wintertime maximum extent in the Arctic. At the end of the summer, in the southern hemisphere, the ice around Antarctica hit its lowest extent ever recorded by satellites. While there is year-on-year variability, up to last year the trend has been towards more melting of the ice caps. Additionally in 2016, the great barrier reef lost 29% of its coral due to rising ocean temperatures. In Port Douglas, Queensland, up to 70% was lost. Rising sea levels, along with an increase in the frequency and magnitude of storm events, will bring increased rates of coastal erosion around the world. My own country, Ireland, and especially the south coast, is particularly exposed. Waterford and Cork are highly exposed to the problem of erosion and the local authorities are doing excellent work in developing coastal management strategies at Cork harbour and Tramore strand. Tramore is particularly subject to coastal erosion. However, we must act at European and global level to ensure that this work and the millions of similar examples around the world are not in vain. Countering these effects is the challenge of our time. Having represented Parliament at COP21 and COP22, I am lucky enough to have witnessed at first hand the coming into force of the agreement that will see us meet the two-degrees target. That target must be met, and I compliment Commissioner Cañete for his role in that matter. In the EU we must ensure that we reduce emissions by at least 40% by 2030 by deploying more renewable energy, pricing carbon and moving to lower carbon and a more sustainable society. I look forward, as shadow rapporteur on the Renewable Energy Directive, to playing my part.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: - Mr President, in a few days we will be one year away from the entry into force of the Paris Agreement. Unfortunately, within this year, the United States, the second largest polluter in the world, decided to withdraw from the Agreement. Fortunately, the first reactions isolated Mr. Trump and prevented a domino effect. Nevertheless, the danger remains. At the forthcoming COP23, which, although to be held in Bonn, is being organized by the Fiji Islands, a country at risk of extinction due to climate change, the European Union must live up to expectations. Our initiatives and our priorities must be towards safeguarding the interests of all peoples. To remain at the forefront of the fight against climate change, even if America changes its strategy and withdraws from the commitments made by President Obama. To ensure that what we decided in Paris will be implemented. Prosperity, democracy, stability depend directly on the living conditions of people in all parts of the world.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - Mr President, I want to speak to you on four points. First, I want to commend the ambition of the Paris Agreement and its strengthening at the Marrakesh Summit and the speed of its ratification by most parties, as well as showing my hope that, after an initial phase of absurd statements by President Trump, the United States realizes the importance of this agreement. Second, it is important to continue investing in technologies that enable zero net emissions, through carbon capture strategies, being an area with a huge potential for creating sustainable jobs. We must therefore take the European ecological transition seriously and here I want to highlight the role of the social economy in this challenge. Third, there must be a strategy for global agriculture that is respectful of the use of water and soil resources, their reallocation and the sustainable exploitation of forests, as we do at European level. There are no more environmentally friendly people than informed farmers. We must therefore promote good European agricultural practices to other places where they can be an asset. Fourth, and I finish now, the ones most affected by climate change are, unfortunately, the poorest developing countries, or even islands, as we saw recently by the devastation caused in one of the most outermost European regions, Martinique and Guadeloupe, by Hurricane Maria. I express my solidarity with them here, since I also come from an ultra-peripheral region, the Azores.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: - Sir.Chairman!The UN Climate Conference COP23 in Bonn is important.Climate change is one of the greatest challenges facing humanity in our time.So we need this conference to show both that the EU is ready and that the EU is willing to take the lead globally.We must also say that an effort for the climate is not an obstacle to growth and development.On the contrary: a green transition is actually the key to ensuring sustainable growth and new jobs as well as a cleaner future.We have shown part of the way for this in Denmark.We have shown that a green transition provides more jobs, and we must help to spread that message, because otherwise I think we will have too much resistance to deliver.The Paris Agreement must be implemented.We need more action and faster action.That should be the EU's message in Bonn.The planet and the citizens of the world need it.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Cañete, in Bonn one of the main topics of discussion will be the escalation of funding to tackle climate change and its consequences. It is true that the common goal of mobilizing $ 100 billion annually for the environment is ambitious and may not be enough, although here in the European Union we are already committed to spending 20% ​​of our budget on environmental goals. . However, it is very crucial to see how this commitment is implemented, especially in the Member States. Anxiety about losing jobs in areas where there are carbon dioxide emissions must be replaced by the answer we will give by creating sustainable jobs in new technologies. It is necessary to create a policy that strengthens projects and infrastructure to tackle climate change. A targeted policy that will create sustainable markets and thus be able to be attractive for resources from the private sector. Examples abound: carbon sequestration, encouraging the use of alternative energy sources in transport, further promoting the energy efficiency of buildings and renewable energy sources. We here in the European Union can, with or without the United States, continue to play a leading role in achieving the Paris goals. We owe it to our children.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, I welcome the resolution under debate, which is a strong and consistent position for the European Parliament. Climate change is the most important challenge facing humanity and it is no longer just a question of prognosis, it is something that people suffer from daily. In Portugal, for example, the brutal wave of forest fires this summer is just one of many examples that we face daily as a result of climate change. They are destroying the planet, affecting populations, in particular the most economically vulnerable. That is why it is necessary to act now and now, to implement the Paris Agreement in all its policies. Combat the backward view of the American administration, take advantage of the digital energy transition to create new opportunities for sustainable growth and quality employment, combat inequalities and improve living conditions on the planet. We must strengthen existing partnerships and seek new economic, political and research and development alliances. Therefore, this resolution constitutes a strong political mandate for the delegation of the European Parliament to participate in COP23 and is also a political mandate for the Commission and the Member States.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, climate change is one of the greatest environmental, social and economic threats facing the planet and humanity. Every day, we see examples of severe and unprecedented weather phenomena that show everyone this truth. From the hurricanes Irma, Maria, which devastate everything in their passage, to the forest fires that in my country recently claimed the lives of 64 people. At COP23, the implementation of the Paris Agreement will be discussed and negotiated and, in particular, the issues of transparency, adaptation, emissions reduction, financing, training and technology, allowing these matters to be approved at the next COP, to be held in 2018 in Poland. The signing of the Paris Agreement was a historic moment around a consensus in the fight against climate change. It is an unprecedented multilateral agreement. Mr. Trump invoked, to abandon the Paris Agreement, that it is unfair to American workers and perverse to the competitiveness of the United States. But if this announcement can make the fight against climate change more difficult, I am sure that there is no return in this fight and that the global transition to clean energy is here to stay. The success of COP23 implies strong political determination and robust climate diplomacy. The European Union must continue to lead through its ambitious climate policies and support to those who are particularly vulnerable, in order to build strong and sustainable economies. The world is in a race against time and the European Union and its Member States must remain united and absolutely committed to the full and rapid application of the Paris Agreement. Hence the importance that I understand that COP23 will bring to our Planet.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the encyclical Laudato si ', also cited in the resolution we are going to approve, Pope Francis writes "God always forgives man; sometimes nature never forgives". And in fact it is enough to look at what is happening today: prolonged droughts, halving of rains and then floods, water bombs, tornadoes even in our European regions. These are given, they are facts; therefore it is not necessary to bother science to give a name to all this. But we need to act and act quickly. Climate change is not a problem that we can think of moving into the future, because we are already seeing its effects. And if we do not act, change will impact our communities much more than we think, causing social costs but also economic damage to people and entire production systems. And so, Commissioner, we have a great responsibility: we must accelerate the transition to a sustainable, low-carbon and circular economy in Europe and involve, like Europe, other global players in this process, even those who today allow themselves to tear up the Charter of the Paris Agreements and, however, put our future and future generations at risk.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Paris Agreement is irreversible and cannot be renounced and, in the process of combating climate change, the COP 23 in Bonn must be a fundamental step for completing the elaboration of the modalities by 2018 detail of implementation of the agreement. The roadmap for mobilizing $ 100 billion by 2020 for climate action in developing countries is just a starting point. The steady increase in EU climate finance is unsatisfactory and does not give guarantees that the target will be achieved: an ambitious commitment is needed by governments and public and private financial firms, banks, pension funds and insurance companies to align lending and investment practices with the goal of containing the temperature rise to well below 2% and to abandon investments in favor of fossil fuels. Specific public guarantees are needed for green investments, as well as certifications and tax advantages for green investment funds and for issuing green bonds. In short, we must move from words to deeds.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Mr President, I think we agree on two things around the world. First, that we humans have caused climate change that is causing us such problems as we are witnessing, either in the Caribbean or in Europe. And secondly, that Europe was the first to recognize its commitment and also its role in green economies and in reducing greenhouse gas emissions. We have a number of policies, either a transition and a strategy for the transition to a circular economy, where we talk about resource efficiency. We have already done a lot in the field of energy, we are increasingly switching to renewable energy sources in the field of efficient energy use, and a big step is still needed in the field of transport. I am also pleased that pollutants such as China are following the European example of completely ceasing to build new thermal power plants, and that China now produces more wind energy than the whole of Europe. We will show the most by example and we must persevere on this path.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, global warming is really having a huge impact on the development of the earth as a whole, but of course on our future as well. On the other hand, we need to look at the situation we are in, because the world's second largest polluter, the United States, has withdrawn from the Agreement. In addition, China, I would say, "throws the ball on the podium", because by 2030 it has not made any commitment. So those who have made the commitment are our side, but that does not mean that anything can happen in practice, because when the United States and China, as well as India, are not committed, any activity of the European Union Union will have very little effect on the protection of the environment. At the same time, with the policies we follow, traditional industries are being dismantled. It must therefore be taken seriously that the basic pollutants are not bound at all.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, there is no reason for any struggle and no battle if we do not manage to save the planet. But how will this grandiose goal be achieved when we do not find a way to pressure the United States to change its attitude? If we do not find ways or do not want to find ways to deal with Monsanto, the company that subjugates the global food chain with actions that negatively affect the climate? We need policies that promote change in the functioning of the economy that promotes the idea of ​​over-consumption, as well as an end to the reckless use of the earth's natural resources.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: - Mr President! The climate development we see in large parts of the world will contribute to political instability and an escalation of refugee flows. Around 2050, the UN estimates that the world may have 200 million people driven from their homes due to climate change. Notes with concern that around 21.5 million people were forced to leave their homes between 2008 and 2013 due to natural disasters; It is important that we take the displacement and migration of people as a result of climate disasters seriously. We need to develop the UN systems for migration and the existing definitions and tools so that they also include this category of refugees. Gender equality shines with its absence in the various processes that take place within the framework of the Paris Agreement. It's a serious mistake. The UN Green Climate Fund will play an important role in financing adaptation needs in the hardest-hit countries. At the climate summit in Bonn, an action plan for increased gender equality will hopefully be negotiated and adopted. I therefore call on the Commission and our Member States to help bring about a decision in Bonn on an ambitious action plan with specific objectives, because we can forget about the climate if we do not invest in gender equality.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, it’s impossible to talk about climate change without drawing attention to the grave situation in Amazonia, Brazil, where violence, land grabbing and serious human rights violations are now endemic under Michel Temer’s corrupt presidency. The current administration is propped up by agri-business, extractive industries and the hydro-electric dam lobby. Multinationals given carte blanche to tear down the forest, rip open the earth, pollute the water supply and flood historic settlements such as San Juan de Araguaia, a 400-year-old town doomed to inundation by plans for mega electric hydroelectric dam on the nearby Tocantins river. The guardians of the environment are the indigenous people and it is them we should be listening to. I listened and I saw. I went to Amazonia in August – into the heart of the forest – and I bore witness to the unfolding environmental disaster, not just for the indigenous people or for Brazil, but for the whole world. There is a direct link between the extratropical storm Desmond that devastated my constituency in December 2015 and the destruction of the Amazon. Climate change knows no borders. The Amazon is the lungs of the world, and its breath is life on earth.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened carefully to the debate today and I am encouraged by the engagement shown by the Members of this House. I appreciate your commitment to maintaining the European Union’s role as a pathbreaker in the field of international climate action. I would like to thank the honourable Members for raising this important issue in Parliament, thereby providing additional political momentum, and I am convinced that, with your support, the Commission and the Council under the leadership of the Estonian Presidency will be able to deliver substantial progress on the implementation of the Paris Agreement at the next climate conference in Bonn in November. Many of you referred to the need to raise our level of ambition. In this regard, I would say that the European Union, along with the other parties, is required to communicate by 2020 its mid-century development strategy for the long-term lowering of greenhouse gas emissions. These long-term strategies will have to explore the feasibility of our 1.5°C scenario, which certainly goes beyond the level of domestic reduction we are heading towards with the current 2030 policy framework. For the long-term strategies, we are, however, dependent on further international developments in order to have the necessary science and analytical basis in place. We will have to obtain the science on the 2°C and 1.5°C pathways, including through a report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in the second half of 2018. The UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCC) Facilitative Dialogue at the end of 2018 is also essential, as it will show us how countries are implementing Paris and what more is needed. To facilitate the preparation of these strategies the Commission will prepare an in-depth analysis of the economic and social transformations needed in order to feed the political debate in the European Parliament and the Council and with the stakeholders. I want to conclude by thanking you again for the opportunity of having this debate, and I hope we can continue our dialogue in the future.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank you again for your cooperation. I am very much encouraged by the debate today on COP 23 and the next steps in the implementation of the Paris Agreement. As on previous occasions, the support from Parliament in our outreach efforts to our international partners is very much appreciated. I look forward to continuing this exchange and working closely together in the run up to the Bonn Conference in order to achieve the best possible outcome.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I have received a motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure.The discussion is over.The vote will take place on Wednesday 4 October.Written declarations (Article 162)

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - In November this year, it will be particularly important to make concrete, substantial progress at the Bonn meeting in order to maintain the momentum of the Paris Climate Agreement in 2018 and beyond. In addition to the practical implementation of the agreement, one of our biggest tasks is to maintain the level of ambition and keep the issue of climate change on the agenda. Another challenge in the negotiations is to identify common features of national commitments, while at the global level, the treatment of losses and damage proposed by developing countries is a headache for Europe and developed countries. An increasing number of citizens are advocating for decarbonisation with the aim of becoming more resilient to climate change. I particularly welcome the commitment of non-state actors, such as religious organizations active in the protection of creation, to the Paris Agreement. It is important to exploit this potential and align it with state-level commitments. Accordingly, we need to assure them of our recognition and support. I believe that well-founded national commitments can only be defined with the participation of the non-state and private sectors, for which dialogue between public and non-state actors must be encouraged.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: in writing. – To avoid acceleration of further uncontrollable climate disruption, we must stay strongly committed to the full implementation of the Paris Agreement. We must be clear that this agreement is irreversible and will not be renegotiated. This clarity and certainty to all actors is crucial to build trust and help solidify confidence in the global commitment to climate action. In that sense I deplore the opening Commissioner Cañete made to the Trump Administration to ‘chart its own path’ within the Treaty and to come back on the terms under which they agreed to participate previously. Such a back step is dangerous and could open a Pandora’s box, since other Parties to the Paris Agreement might start to consider weaker contributions as well. This is contrary to the Paris Agreement itself that states in art.4.3 that ‘Each Party’s successive NDC will represent a progression beyond the Party’s then current NDC and reflect its highest possible ambition, reflecting its common but differentiated responsibilities and respective capabilities’. Current NDCs will still lead to a global warming of 3°C. Parties should do more, not less. The EU also has to raise its ambitions. The Facilitative Dialogue in 2018 is an excellent opportunity to do so.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Next on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the thousands of flight cancellations by Ryanair and the implementation of Regulation (EC) No.261/2004 / EC on the rights of air passengers (2017/2876 (RSP))

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, air travel is a vital transport link for EU citizens. In the European Union, some 918 million passengers travelled by air in 2015 and this figure is increasing steadily from year to year. Ryanair has grown to become the largest EU airline by scheduled passengers flown, and has carried more international passengers in 2015 than any airline in the world. It currently operates from 84 bases connecting 33 countries across Europe and North Africa. The abrupt cancellation, in the six weeks from September to October 2017, by Ryanair of thousands of its flights in the EU has caused major disturbances for passengers. A large number of them were left stranded at airports and many had to cancel journeys or re—route their flights. There are complaints that in a number of cases the airline has given little or no notice of such cancellations. Furthermore, there have been claims that the limited information dispensed by the airline with regard to reimbursement, re—routing or return, as well as the right to assistance and the right to compensation, may have been misleading to passengers. It is deeply regrettable that the passengers were left in such a position. Airlines operating in the EU must respect European rules. Air passengers’ rights are indeed protected under EU law. The Flight Compensation Regulation sets a minimum level of quality standards for passenger protection, adding an important citizens’ dimension to the liberalisation of the aviation market. When a flight is cancelled, airlines are obliged to inform passengers of their rights. These rights include the right to reimbursement, re—routing or return, as well as the right to care and, in some circumstances, the right to compensation. Any EU airline not adhering to these rules must be held accountable. The national enforcement bodies in each Member State must act to verify that airlines are respecting EU rules and that passengers’ rights are protected. They must also strive to ensure that passengers are aware of their rights.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission wishes to make the following statement on the recent case of Ryanair cancellations. A few days ago, Ryanair publicly announced that it would reduce its operations by cancelling thousands of scheduled flights, disrupting the travel plans of passengers across Europe. This affected firstly flights scheduled until the end of October, totalling 2 100 flights, and then others due to operate during the winter season. A very large number of passengers will be affected and, just like all of you, the Commission wants to make sure that those passengers are treated fairly. The EU is the only area in the world where citizens are protected by a full set of passengers’ rights, whether they travel by air, rail, ship, bus or coach. All passengers whose flights are cancelled have a comprehensive set of rights. It is essential that they receive correct and complete information about their rights in order to be able to enforce them. Let me recall that these rights include the right to reimbursement, re-routing or return, as well as the right to care and, in some circumstances, the right to receive financial compensation. The Commission has asked the national authorities to be vigilant on this issue, and to try to cooperate with each other in order to ensure that passengers can fully exercise their rights. As guardian of the Treaties, the role of the Commission is to oversee and monitor the implementation of EU law in each Member State. For this reason, the Commission immediately issued a statement underlying, in particular, that Ryanair just – like all airlines operating in the EU – must fully comply with EU air passengers’ rights. We are in direct contact with all the national enforcement bodies to make sure that passengers’ rights are respected, and I specifically welcome the enforcement actions already taken by the UK civil aviation authorities and further actions by other civil aviation authorities, including in Ireland and Spain. I’m also confident that the Irish civil aviation authority will continue to fulfil its oversight obligations and ensure that Ryanair continues to comply with our aviation acquis. Mr President and honourable members: let me also use this opportunity to remind you that in 2016, the Commission issued guidelines on the existing rules to make it easier for passengers and national authorities alike. The Commission also proposed to modernise the rules on air passengers’ rights in 2013 – a proposal which is currently blocked in Council. I hope that we will soon be able to make progress on this for our passengers travelling across the EU. This incident clearly highlights the need for a modern and robust European regulatory framework. Honourable Members, President: the Commission has contacted Ryanair and we expect them to fully comply with its obligations. Together with my colleague, Commissioner Jourová, I have written an official letter to Ryanair to underline our concerns and highlight the obligations under EU law. Firstly, we recalled that the passengers must receive correct and complete information about their rights in due time in order to be able to enforce them, including on re-routing and compensation. Secondly, Ryanair has to ensure that all communication channels are working properly and that passengers can communicate with staff. Thirdly, another important issue is the complaint handling process. Ryanair shall make information available on its website on its complaint handling process and on the relevant contact addresses where passengers can file claims. I am pleased to report that the Ryanair has already responded by giving a number of assurances addressing the issues we have raised. Indeed, for September and October 98% of affected customers have had their claims processed. For November to March 2018, the figure is at 75% and we expect this to go up rapidly in the coming weeks. This is a positive development. I will be pursuing my contacts with Ryanair in the Irish civil aviation authority during a visit to Dublin in a few days, and the Commission will of course remain in close contact with all national enforcement bodies to further follow-up on this issue. President and honourable Members, the single aviation market has many benefits, but also many obligations. We therefore expect all airlines operating in the EU to fully respect European rules.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for the clarification and for her action in this area in contacting Ryanair. On 18 September last, Ryanair suddenly announced flight cancellations and it was only last Friday, 29 September, 11 days later, that we seem to have come to a point where we had full clarification on the issue, and – in relation to passenger rights – for the passengers’ entitlements to be communicated directly to them. That followed meetings with the Commission for Aviation Regulation in Ireland and the UK and in Spain, as you have mentioned, so it took that time to ensure that passengers’ rights were outlined clearly and communicated to them directly. Regulation (EC) No 261/2004 has been in place since 2004 and we are all well aware of it, and I am sure a European airline that is benefiting from the liberalisation of European airspace should have been aware of the issue. They have said that they take the matter seriously and have put in place strong communication now with their customers.  All this came from what has been described as a rostering management failure. It is not a safety issue, as some people would like to think or would like to link it to, and we should be clear on that. Flight time regulations were established by these institutions: the amount of time a pilot can fly, and indeed the time that cabin crew can be in the air, in one calendar year was established. In an effort to ensure that they remained compliant and continued to remain compliant, Ryanair had a rostering issue and they had to cancel flights and ensure that they could remain compliant. They are compliant, they continue to be compliant, but there is a serious question mark over their management, certainly in the compliance area, when it comes to EU rules and regulations.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Ryanair has announced that 20,000 flights will be canceled by March 2018. Approximately 700,000 passengers will be affected. This naturally raises questions, namely questions about whether air passenger rights are actually being respected. Who wears z. B. the additional costs if such a flight is canceled? Are the customers also adequately informed? The question must be allowed: where was the Irish Aviation Authority? After all, it is ultimately responsible for the approval and it must ensure that flight operations ultimately run smoothly. Something must have gone wrong, the people in charge have to put up with that too. Why - the question arises for me - do flights have to be canceled? It is said that punctuality should be increased - that is also perfectly fine - but we know that Ryanair has not only been coming up with positive headlines for some time, but also negative ones - negative ones, especially with regard to the conditions of employment of the pilots. Maybe it is actually because of the employment practice of the pilots, who only get money when they fly? Could it be because of these terms or conditions of employment? Commissioner, you as the Commission must ensure that this is not actually carried out at the expense of colleagues and customers.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Undoubtedly, low-cost airlines have played a huge role in promoting flying as an important and affordable mode of transport in the European Union. Ryanair is today the undisputed leader in this segment, so it must be emphasized that apart from high profits, this position also entails responsibility. The current situation, especially the information chaos related to the cancellation of thousands of flights, causes legitimate passenger anxiety and poses a serious challenge to many local airports, for which connections via this airline are often crucial to maintaining profitability. It is unacceptable for Ryanair to avoid or not fully comply with its obligations in the event of cancellation of a flight, especially to provide the passenger with an alternative connection. European regulations are clear here and the passenger must be sure that his rights are respected. It is the Commissioner who is responsible for the enforcement of Art. 5 of the Regulation of the Parliament and the Council, to which I hereby call and urge you. I expect the Member States and the Commission to monitor the situation and take appropriate steps to protect passenger rights.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I too am glad that we have this point on the agenda in the plenary today and that we can debate it. I think it is worth saying that clearly something went wrong in Ryanair. To put it bluntly, Ryanair has messed something up. If I were the CEO, I would probably take measures because, of course, the first affected in this respect is the company, with its business and its reputation. There is no doubt something went wrong: it is obvious due to the implications that we are debating. However, the Commissioner said one important thing and I think it is something we should focus on in terms of where we go from here and what the policymaking is to be. That is that, regarding the European Union, our internal market, the rights of consumers and passengers’ rights, if we compare the situation with any other region in the world, or any other country, we have the most protective legislative framework. That goes without saying. I also see that the Commission has acted and has given a response so I am sure that, as far as the competences of the Commission are concerned, it will make sure that Ryanair implements what it has promised and what it has to implement. And of course we also have the relevant national authorities. What I am more concerned about is that, although we have had this most protective legislative framework for 10 years, there are still entities and people that do not know what passengers’ rights are today, what can be reimbursed and what kind of obligations the airline has. That is something else that we need to draw conclusions from. I hope that, in the future, apart from the monitoring of implementation – on which, of course, I will focus – we will be able to bring forward the question of passengers’ rights, not only in aviation but also in other modes of transport, in a combined way. Lastly, I apologise that, due to a previous commitment, I have to leave. Please do not consider that as disrespect to you, Mr President, Madam Commissioner, or to the issue, which I think is a serious one.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr. President, Ryanair deliberately misled customers concerning their rights as passengers under EU regulations. It refused to disclose correct information on compensation rights until its hand was forced, but we shouldn't be surprised by Ryanair’s disrespectful behaviour towards its passengers. For years, its CEO has prided himself on the company's disrespectful treatment towards its workers. Ryanair refuses to negotiate with trade unions, it forbids its workers on many bases from organising, and remember this debacle of cancelled flights is the direct result of pilots and other workers fleeing Ryanair. The episode demonstrates that promoting so-called competitiveness to the detriment of workers’ rights cannot and will not succeed. Therefore we across the EU institutions have to stop pushing ahead with our aggressive competition agenda in the transport sector and acknowledge first and foremost that flights cannot run and planes cannot fly if we do not have pilots and workers to service them. (Applause)

name: Karima DELLI
text: , on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the cancellations of flights by Ryanair are a new provocation by the low cost company. Some 400,000 passengers are penalized for poor planning management. But this is a joke! This company clearly makes passengers an adjustment variable. I tell you as I think it is: it is no longer low cost, it is zero service. In the face of such acts, I ask the European Commission to ensure that Ryanair respects European legislation on passenger rights, but also to consider sanctions because it will not stop there. Ryanair has just announced the cancellation of 18,000 new flights by next March. This episode highlights the limits of the low cost model, which is neither virtuous for the planet, nor for employees, nor for consumers. It is high time that the European Union realized this, and stopped encouraging low cost, social dumping and the subsidies it benefits from. Therefore, let's strengthen passenger rights, make it clearer, but create a sanction mechanism against "rogue" companies.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a scandal because more than 21 000 flights have been canceled. Millions of passengers are on land and mostly in remote areas and on islands. This because? Because it is a monopoly. This gentlemen is a monopoly at the expense of the citizens. Done with what? With the money of the citizens, precisely, of the taxpayers, with the contributions that regions and municipalities give to Ryanair to maintain flights on their territories. The European Commission investigation is welcome. Consumers must be protected but in our opinion they must not only be reimbursed but must be compensated. Attention also to the protection of workers' rights, however, because we would like to understand if the rest period proposed by the company for an economic consideration is in line with the full respect of the psychophysical condition of Ryanair workers. The European Union cannot pull back, nor can it turn to the other side: even if it is a mismanagement of the company or if we are witnessing a market operation, setting aside resources to buy airport slots or companies smaller, we care about the rights of citizens and workers.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Mr Chairman! Ten days ago, my flight was unexpectedly canceled and I only recovered two hundred euros because, as I was told, no more is due under some convention. If I have a problem, that is my problem. If a million people have problems, it is a million individual problems, not a social or political problem. I've always heard complaints about Ryanair picking up passengers on other airlines. If now in the winter season it wants to hand over tens of thousands of passengers to other airlines, they should be happy. Ryanair has the right to cancel half of its routes. If Ryanair flies, you say it's banditry. If Ryanair doesn't fly, it's banditry too. Ryanair cancels flights and pays passengers legally required compensation. I do not see the slightest reason for any institution to interfere in the decisions of a private enterprise. If I were to be Ryanair, I would be the answer to any such institution: Kiss my forehead. Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Bulc! Well over 300,000 Ryanair customers are already affected by flight cancellations, and by March 2018 another 400,000 will be added. Of all the reasons Ryanair puts forward regarding cancellations and delays, I can't really accept a single one. The decisive question now is whether or not the existing rights of the passengers were preserved in this flight cancellation marathon. I would therefore like to encourage all passengers concerned to find out about their rights and to enforce them with the relevant national authorities. The airline is responsible even for late, incomplete or incorrect information on the Ryanair website. Depending on the canceled flight route, 250, 400 or even 600 euros in compensation may be due if the information came too late and a travel alternative with few deviations was not possible. I do not trust the promises regarding the future flight behavior of Ryanair. For me, this situation is one more reason to encourage the Council of Transport Ministers to stop blocking the revision of air passenger rights, which was passed in our House on February 5, 2014. We urgently need this revision of the 2004 regulation in order to bring about further effective and uniform enforcement of air passenger rights.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Mr President, while we are here, anyway, complaining with good reason about the loss of rights of 400,000 passengers, the company itself is launching a mega-sale of one million seats for the same months and at a price that ... Finally, I am not going to say it so as not to advertise, but it is shameful: «I leave 400,000 on the ground and mistreat them and, at the same time, I advertise myself and launch a million places for the others, for which battered in the next wave. ' That is why I think that, in some way - because I am beginning to think that it is perverse financial engineering - we should get our hands on this company because, of course, it misleads travelers. Your organization cannot be worse and your forecasts absolutely unacceptable. There is also the mistreatment of pilots - whom he laughs at and whom he criticizes - in addition to directly attacking European standards and the forecast of fatigue in crews. Therefore, Commissioner, I would ask you not only for the specific sanctions that we can mandate at European level and for their harmonization. Because there are some companies that ask for some things, others others ... In the end, we don't really know what the final sanction will be. And, on the other hand, facilitate claims. From a digital point of view, each traveler should receive, at the time he buys a flight, information about his rights and how to automatically claim the company.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: - I deeply regret that we are only now starting a debate on this issue. More than a year ago, I already asked the Commission a question about customer complaints against Ryanair and about non-compliance with consumer rules. Then I received the reply from your services that nothing was wrong. On July 4 this year, I again asked you to take steps against airlines that make it almost impossible to file complaints. Again the answer came that you would look into the matter. With thousands of consumers affected, I hope you will finally take steps. As a result of the Ryanair case, you already responded in the press that airlines must respect the European rules, because those rules already exist. It is primarily up to the Member States to enforce those rules and to the Commission to inform to point out. I would therefore like to call on you to finally act on this and remind the Member States - and therefore also the companies - of their responsibility.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: - I wonder: what is aviation all about? Isn't it all about transporting passengers safely and efficiently to a destination? Their travel goal is certainly not to get caught up in proceedings with the airline, which suddenly cancels numerous flights. Proceedings about the right to financial compensation, about the right to alternative flights, about the right to care and information, in short about their rights as passengers. Europe once had the ambition to protect people who fly against malpractice. Europe intended to help consumers get their rights. Europe has a proposal to tighten passenger rights in aviation and this amendment to Regulation No. 261 from 2004 is becoming increasingly urgent. Because in 13 years the world of aviation has changed dramatically and passengers should be able to more easily cash in on their rights in case of cancellations and delays. Passengers should be given an extended right to alternative flights and passengers should be better informed by airlines. In my Europe there is no room for deception and non-transparent communication. This tightening up of passenger rights through the amendment of Regulation No 261 is stuck in the Council. The European Parliament, we, the parliament, we take people who fly seriously. But the Council, the representation of the Member States, has been refusing to reach a compromise with us for three years. And all this, as is known, because of the dispute over the status of Gibraltar airport. European Council, take responsibility, make political decisions, despite the complexity of Brexit. You can avoid personal tragedies surrounding cancellations and, with us, the European Parliament, ensure that passengers in aviation can still get a soft landing in such unpleasant circumstances - to stay in aviation terms.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: – Mr President, dear colleagues, passengers’ and workers’ rights need to be respected. This is unfortunately not the case for Ryanair. This kind of unfair business model and ultra-low cost model in the transport sector in general needs to be avoided. If we look at the current situation for customers, no real safeguards exist against flight cancellations or delays. How do passengers really feel when they book a Ryanair flight, but they don’t know whether it will ever take off, and then the company blames poor planning of staff holidays. It is not only the customers who are affected, it is also the crew members, who work on an hourly rate and don’t get paid when flights get cancelled. What are the workers’ social conditions if they are only being paid for the hours when they are flying, with no income security when flights are cancelled? Is this the model of aviation we want in Europe or elsewhere – a new model of legal slavery? We need to fix the grey areas of the current air passenger rights regulation. We know very well the regulation is open to interpretation, and Parliament is ready and willing to get an agreement on this important subject. We need a clear and fair air passenger rights regulation, and the citizens of Europe are waiting for European Union leadership in this matter and for fair conditions and fair aviation that is safe for customers and workers alike.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
