text: - Mr President!Ryanair has recently announced that it will cancel a large number of flights until March 2018, which will affect hundreds of thousands of passengers.This is very unfortunate and an expression of Ryanair's very problematic business model, which is based on indecent working conditions for staff and indirect public support from regional airports.In this way, pushing prices on air travel that destroys the climate and also allowing price dumping to affect staff and travelers is not sustainable.Now we must ensure that the hundreds of thousands of travelers who have been affected are taken care of.But in the long term, we must ensure that legislation is strengthened so that cabin crew have good working conditions and passengers can safely book their flights.And finally: aviation must start paying for its climate impact, and fossil fuel subsidies must end.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the last fifteen years the various governments of the Member States have sold out the European sky, filling the pockets of the Irish company, giving concessions, contributions more or less disguised as operating aid, especially for smaller airports, those who struggled to maintain sufficient passenger traffic, and all in defiance of competition rules. It is the various Member States that have allowed the proliferation of an airline, which has made precarious work its watchword. After giving away almost free flights throughout Europe for years - and we know well at whose expense - Ryanair has now moved into the cash register: but national governments are not the only architects of the current crisis. How many times has the Commission washed its hands of the countless violations reported by this Parliament? How many times has it ignored our questions on Ryanair's tax evasion and illicit state aid, dumping the barrel of responsibility on the national courts. For twenty years the European Union has left the posting of workers in limbo and for twenty years each State has interpreted those rules as it wishes: today the rights of passengers, which have gone up in smoke with a click, pay the price for your indifference. , and workers in the sector, not only those of low cost, but also of scheduled flight companies. Not to mention the damage to national social security systems.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I must say that I am very impressed by the discussion on the Ryanair scandal. I am very impressed, because within Parliament and within the committees in which I work - the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, the Committee on Transport and Tourism - we often find ourselves debating how protect the European market and safeguard the high performance of our companies in terms of market protection, the protection of workers' lives, the protection of users and in this case of passengers. We defend ourselves from those who are outside the market, that is, from those who do not respect the rules of competition. And we do well! However, in this case we find ourselves in a paradoxical situation because, as usual, speaking of companies, we are dealing with the customer, the worker and the company itself. As far as passengers are concerned, we have said: users have ample scope to protect their rights. On the other hand, the workers have filed an appeal, the Court has expressed itself and therefore have all the space to create the conditions for their work to be protected and to operate in conditions that can guarantee a correct service. At this point, let's talk about the company. I'm not used to early trials, but apparently, the company has created conditions of unfair competition, taking jobs and deceiving passengers. Well then, what's our job? Our job is not to make a process but to ensure that everyone works under the conditions under which we can still say that Europe is the largest market in the world. But the largest market in the world has to take all these factors into account and it seems that this has not been done in this case.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, unfortunately this is not the first time that we have pointed out the anti-social practices of the airline Ryanair. Today, we again denounce the abusive practices of this company in terms of non-respect of passenger rights: 2,000 flights canceled today, and tomorrow 20,000, a logical consequence of the failure to take into account the obligations of leave for pilots and crews. This case illustrates the limits of business models that push employees to their limits. Passenger rights and workers' rights are two sides of the same fight to improve the quality of service. On these two issues, the European Union can act. In 2014, our Parliament adopted a proposal for a regulation to expand the rights of passengers with regard to compensation and assistance. It is high time that the Council adopted its position for this new regulation to enter into force. In addition, in accordance with the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union of September 14 against Ryanair, it is essential to better define the main place of activity to prevent companies from employing their staff under prevailing social conditions. in countries other than their home base. European legislation must strengthen these decisions to better protect the workers in question.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the behavior of Ryanair, which has so far abandoned 400,000 passengers and canceled flights, is unacceptable and painless, and it says it will cancel more until the beginning of spring. Ryanair is the largest company, operating at 84 airports and of course having a monopoly. This is the situation. It utilizes this monopoly position in order to make super profits. Everything was caused because there is a serious arrhythmia in her relations with the pilots. It does not guarantee their rights and of course the pilots are not available to work overtime. The same goes for the cabin crew. But the main thing is that it is not enough to hear wishes from the Commission. What action will be taken against Ryanair which is really illegal? How will passengers be protected? How will there be consumer protection? How will they get their compensation? These are the questions we need to answer in order to stop Ryanair from abusing its current dominant position in the market. Everything that happened was done because the goal was to make a profit and of course the company "did not give a damn" to its own employees. This is the reality.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Ryanair has announced that 98% of passengers affected by cancellations in September and October had their money back or a rebooking. If you weren't informed about air passenger rights, you would get the impression: “Man, that's great, what they did!” The problem is, however, that they haven't informed their passengers about all the options that exist there. In the case of canceled flights, it's not just about getting money back, but also about compensation - Mr Koch has already said it - of 250, 400 or 600 euros, depending on the route. And as an airline, you are also obliged to offer rebooking with more expensive airlines. I think it is very good that the Aviation Authority in Ireland just last week practically forced Ryanair to inform passengers of their rights after the fact. The point is this: if this is done, it is no wonder that many actually say: Passenger rights must be tightened. My colleague van Miltenburg has already said: We have better air passenger rights, but these are unfortunately blocked in the Council. We urgently need that, because it has to be such that as a passenger you also get your rights and can rely on the airlines.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, it is not just passengers' rights that are at stake, nor can this case be separated from the political options that the EU has imposed on the sector. Options such as the systemic promotion of privatizations are the destruction of the model of flagship airlines and groundhandling, concentrations in the sector with the apology and permissiveness to low cost approaches and the growing insecurity and deregulation of labor relations, lowering labor costs. personnel, further compromising an element of national sovereignty. This is the root of the problem. The workers have reached the limit of the deplorable conditions that Ryanair imposes on them. We also leave a fraternal greeting to all those, in the air transport sector, who are fighting for the improvement and dignity of working conditions. There is an urgent need to reverse the imposed options and affirm the need to regain public control of this strategic sector, essential for the development of any country. Only in this way will the best labor and operating practices in the sector be guaranteed.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: - Mr President, my dear colleagues! 18,000 flights have been canceled, affecting almost 800,000 customers. Applicable laws have been violated - we can tighten them, but existing ones have been violated - and I am convinced that the lawbreakers must be punished, but not the customers, as Ryanair did! A colleague told me how it was. She wanted to fly from Riga to Frankfurt. The flight was canceled, no SMS, no email, no meal vouchers, no assistance, information only on a hotline that was only activated three hours later, there was only a change in booking for a Ryanair flight a week later! Everything else was refused. There was no assumption of costs for accommodation or meals, and no reimbursement. And when she said that, she was told, yes, you don't have Ryanair cancellation insurance, so you don't get any money. You knew exactly what was going on! You broke the law. We cannot accept that. A law that is not prosecuted, punished, not sanctioned is not a good law! It is therefore up to the Commission, the Member States and the organizations to investigate. The customer has priority, not Ryanair, who exploits the colleagues, who exploits the pilots. That's why there weren't enough pilots left who did that. The bogus self-employment must be punished, and this wage dumping must end! Otherwise we will lose our credibility here in Europe.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! During today's debate, many questions and doubts arise, but the most important thing, which was often emphasized here, is the issue of passenger rights and the liability of the company, which, in an effort to reduce costs, but also ticket prices, has recently canceled several thousand flights, and also about what nobody says, it suspended flights on thirty-four routes during the winter. Commissioner, what responsibility will the company bear? Thousands of passengers have found out that their flight has been canceled and we do not know whether they are aware of their rights under the Council Regulation, whether they have been informed that they can claim compensation and whether they know that they can travel on other airlines at Ryanair's expense. The issue of the company's employees is very important. This raises the question of what was the reason why so many pilots quit their jobs with a relatively good salary, and how the numerous discussions in the European Parliament on rest, drivers 'working time, drivers' salaries and social dumping relate to the functioning of Ryanair. Please note the proposed ticket prices. How is it possible to buy a ticket for two and a half euro for a connection between two European Union countries? Weren't we dealing with social dumping here? Somehow nobody touches on this topic. How is it possible that many of the thirteen thousand employed workers are self-employed, have no paid holidays and no social benefits? I hope, Mr President and Commissioner, that the Commission will hold the company accountable and will also make sure that the company complies with European law and consumer rights.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and I am well aware of the issue we are dealing with today. I care about transport at competitive rates to give a more accessible service and to develop tourism, a sector that is giving us a lot of satisfaction. But it must be said that to be a leader in the aviation sector, it is not enough to have conquered a fair share of the market: above all, we must be respectful of the rights of workers and passengers' rights. There are legitimate doubts on these aspects, so it is urgent that the Commission does the necessary clarity and quickly. There is talk of unused pilots' holidays: are we really sure that these are the reasons and are there not other reasons? As for canceled flights, the rules are clear: no discount transactions will be accepted. Whoever causes damage must compensate it in full. Finally, I ask that we go ahead with the revision of the regulation on passenger rights, which has been held in the Council since February 2014. We must give passengers greater protection that is in step with the times.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the mass cancellation of Ryanair flights is an opportunity to demonstrate the usefulness of the Union through cooperation between all the relevant parties on the matter. Although it is the national authorities who must control in each State, the Commission must guarantee homogeneous criteria in all the States of the Union and that the process offers satisfactory and identical results. To achieve this, and with more than 400,000 affected, the Commission could produce a digital guide that, in a simple and cheap way, little more than an interactive PDF and a specific banner, could be offered in all official languages ​​through the Member states. By consulting it, Rayanair users who purchase their tickets, mainly online, could compare this official information with that offered by the company itself and, in this way, all the rights that correspond to users would be protected and they would be better informed about claims . It is also a good time to review the operation of this company again -for years under the magnifying glass for unclear practices- and, in addition, promote the transparency of the private organizations that sell their advisory services for this type of claims and guarantee They offer the benefits they advertise.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Mr President, 18,000 flights on 34 routes and 400,000 customers affected in four months. If we were talking about a public company, we would talk about disastrous management and surely those responsible would have to have resigned by now. But since it is a company with a long history of cancellations and lack of protection for the consumer and its workers, it seems that you have to resign yourself and believe that these cancellations are due to a small company that makes a holiday readjustment. However, Ryanair is today the company that transports the most passengers in Europe and we must demand the highest levels of responsibility from it. These irregularities must be investigated by the European air authorities. Regulation (EC) No. 261/2004 on the rights of passengers establishes certain minimums in terms of cancellation, information, compensation and alternatives, which Ryanair has not complied with. This case opens a Pandora's box that the Commission has tried to keep hidden by announcing the supposed success of the liberalization of the aviation sector. It is seen that they were more concerned with deregulation than with the protection of passengers. Will you wait for the next massive cancellation? Would things change if European commissioners ever traveled low cost?

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: - In the Netherlands we have a wonderful proverb and that is "pride comes before a fall". Ryanair always prides itself: "We are the largest airline, we transport the most tourists." But in practice it turns out to be much more difficult to get all those people to their destination in a proper way. This in itself is a serious fact, especially when you advertise so much. But now it's about how we fix it and I hope that Ryanair will not let the whole refund - the compensation of the people - go down in endless bureaucratic internet procedures, but simply and fairly return the money and compensate the people. Finally, I repeat the question from Mr Ertug: where was the Irish regulator? Surely it cannot be that Ryanair is protected by the Irish regulator on such matters? I hope the Commissioner will give a clear answer to that. We have regulators and they have to do their job. The second question I repeat is Van Miltenburg's question to the Council: that passenger protection regulation has now been with the Council for three or four years and we can all cry crocodile tears here, but where is the solution? The Council, under the Presidency of Estonia, could play a very good role in this.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Mr Chairman!Commissioner!I have the feeling that we are participating in a debate where someone is sitting on the sidelines and is just laughing at us disparagingly.I mean the great, famous and extremely unusual manager that is the owner and boss of Ryanair.Firstly, we are reaping the fruit of impunity, secondly, we are reaping the fruit of disregarding the applicable rules, and finally we are reaping the fruit of the Commission's and individual Member States' games and of simply striving for Ryanair to be everywhere.An illusion was being sold because an unrealized flight schedule is just selling an illusion, and that should be prohibited.So a dilemma arises, as I dare say that it is Ryanair that turns its back on the passengers, not the passengers away from Ryanair, because I expect that, unfortunately, for wasted money, they will be ready to return.Commissioner, is it just Ryanair, have you checked other low cost airlines?Will we have another Ryanair?

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to make three points: first, the cancellation of tens of thousands of flights shows a lack of respect for passengers. Lack of respect that has been expressed differently: we have a Ryanair official saying that he is considering the possibility of passengers traveling on special planes. Secondly, in all European Union countries where Ryanair operates, labor laws must be complied with and employees' rights must be respected. Thirdly, treating passengers with disrespect, treating them like animals traveling upright, and also having no work rules affect flight safety. Planes fly, they are engines, but planes are handled by people. Staff who are relaxed and happy are staff safe. If this does not exist, we risk having other very unpleasant events and we will all be responsible. You see the climate here, Commissioner. It is time to take action.

name: Ivo BELET
text: - It has been said many times here, but the way Ryanair has dealt with the rights of passengers, which has been brutally flouted, is truly unseen. And it is really crude and unacceptable that society has only decided to offer its customers compensation after a long hesitation and after much pressure from the media and politicians. It has already been said 100 times here: European rules state that passengers are of course entitled to compensation if they are not informed in time about the cancellation of the flight. The Belgian Minister of Consumer Affairs has already launched an investigation into Ryanair for unfair trading practices, and I think the European Commission cannot help but follow that example. You have indeed sent a letter to Ryanair with your colleague, but we are convinced that more decisive action is needed here and that Ryanair must be brought to order. Finally, another point that has already been discussed here, but that we may want to give extra attention to. We must also work to improve the functioning and accessibility of national intermediary bodies so that they are more accessible, more quickly accessible, more easily accessible to affected passengers; so that all consumers, all passengers, have the right, in a smooth and accessible way, to what they are indeed entitled to under European regulations.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, when Ryanair said a few weeks ago that it would have to cancel up to 50 flights a day, hundreds of thousands of passengers affected the measure.Their flight was canceled overnight and, of course, the company's employees were also affected.The air carrier promised to compensate passengers affected by the cancellation.However, this compensation does not include a clear obligation to divert passengers to other carriers.In other words, the ability to fly on time with someone else.This obligation to redirect is included, inter alia, in the revision of the regulation on air passenger rights, which was discussed by the European Parliament in 2014. It has been blocked in the Council for about the same period.The call for the Council to finally agree on a new revision of the regulation is therefore more than appropriate.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the thousands of travel cancellations practiced by Ryanair have caused great damage to the confidence of European consumers. Many consumers have reported a persistent concealment of information about their rights and many complaints submitted to the air carrier, national authorities, consumer associations and the Commission refer to the lack of response, the non-application of the rules of Article 5 of the Regulation (EC) No. 261/2004 and misleading information to avoid compensation or the use of loopholes in the Regulation with regard to sequential flights. It is regrettable that only three national authorities have threatened sanctioning measures. The others are limited to monitoring the situation. Support has been provided mainly by consumer organizations and the European Commission has not been clearly expressed in this process. Effective consumer protection is a fundamental element in the smooth functioning of the market. Poor management of a company cannot be used as an excuse to evade the duty of compensation and compensation for affected passengers. From the reports that came to us, we are dealing with cases of misleading commercial practices by omitting the information necessary for affected consumers to be able to assert their rights. National consumer protection authorities must act. The Commission must not be stuck in an objectively transnational case that affects thousands of Europeans. And reality gives us reason when we proposed strengthening cooperation between national consumer protection authorities, which we will be voting on here in Strasbourg next month.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen!The events around Ryanair show the dark side of the aggressive business practices of the low-cost airline.In this specific case, 700,000 passengers who will be affected by flight cancellations pay the price for this “greed is cool” mentality.I really dare to doubt that Ryanair will comply with its information obligation on air passenger rights.At the same time, the cancellation of the flights means massive income losses for the flight crew.If the planes stay on the ground, there is no money either.The group management speaks of problems with vacation planning.The fact is, however, that the workforce and the pilots have had enough of zero-hour contracts and precarious jobs.Ryanair and all other low-cost airlines must finally adopt a social partnership dialogue and fair employment relationships in their day-to-day operations.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I want to contact the Ryanair boss directly. Dear Mr. O’Leary, imagine that you have booked a flight, e. B. with Ryanair, and have booked a nice hotel in Tallinn, Paris or London, or have a very important business appointment and suddenly you are told, the day before the trip or on the day itself, that this flight is not taking place because it has been canceled is. I think, Mr O'Leary, you would curse like Captain Haddock. It was the same with all those who had to experience this now. One speaks here of 400,000 people, there are 300,000 more. In my small constituency, many citizens called me angrily and protested and I was asked: 'What is Europe doing about it, or what can I do as a citizen or as a person concerned?' The answer here is the regulation from 2004. It is a regulation that defines citizens' rights. These rights are good, passengers have to claim these rights. You have to honestly say: the short-term nature of the cancellation was and is a cheek, and it cannot be that way. Ryanair will have to pay for these canceled flights and you, Ms. Bulc, will have to keep an eye on Mr. O’Leary. While freedom above the clouds may be limitless, there are limits to the insolence of such planning. And that's in your hand, Ms. Bulc. Keep an eye on him, and I can only advise every customer to assert these rights. The customer is sitting on the longer lever. If everyone asserts these rights, you will prevent such things from happening again in the future.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the cancellation of flights across Europe by Ryanair is creating great inconvenience for European citizens. The cause is, in my opinion, to be found in the reckless social dumping on the skin of the employees of this company, which thus tries to outperform the competition. It is worth remembering that only yesterday, the British low cost, Monarch, operational since 1968, went bankrupt. The current layout of the internal market in this sector must probably be rethought, as well as the European rules for the protection of passengers must be enforced. The Commission needs to shed light on how airlines inform travelers. It seems that Ryanair communicates the cancellation of flights between 48 hours and 6 hours before the departure time: it does not seem to me a sufficiently large advance margin. But beyond the reimbursement of the ticket, the real crux is the compensation that is due to users in the event of cancellation close to the flight date, which Ryanair has the duty to arrange automatically and without any expense for consumers.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner and dear Council, you have a unanimity here in Parliament. All political groups support the same thing, it was said where Ryanair went wrong. I think he defies us. It cannot be justified that you canceled tens of flights, hundreds of thousands of passengers affected because you did not plan your holidays. This company is a shame. We need to find solutions, we must not fail to increase the demand for consumer rights. I am also a member of the TRAN Commission and the IMCO Commission. I and everyone else are sent here by the citizens to defend their rights, all their rights, including those of passengers. This company also operates in my country. In 21 flights, even in the city I belong to, citizens of my country were affected. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, we need to take action. Enough has been said here, I don't think we need to argue that this company is making fun of us. It is not a management mistake, this is a qualified theft and we must put an end to it. One more thing I want to say, my colleague Liberadzki said: Commissioner, you should know that passenger rights are being violated by other companies and we must stop, don't let Ryanair's situation get worse. You need to check in advance.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, it is obvious that the development of low cost airlines has opened up air transport to millions of Europeans and, as a result, has generated thousands of jobs through the development of certain airports and their region. In my region, in Charleroi, the airport is one of the biggest Belgian economic success stories of recent years, and it has been sufficiently demonstrated. But current events oblige us to reaffirm the protective principles defined by Europe, which must necessarily accompany this development. First, the rights of passengers must be fully protected. The rules are clear: any company that cancels a flight must inform each passenger of their rights, including the right to be compensated under certain conditions. Therefore, Commissioner, I think you need to take an initiative to facilitate this compensation procedure and monitor the process. The clear example of Ryanair shows that this does not work. Second, the social rights of crews must be fully respected. This involves in particular the recent judgment of the European Court of Justice on the national court competent in matters of labor law. Here too, the device must be secured. We are obviously counting on you, Commissioner, to change these two elements.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: - Mr President, it seems to me that there was a lot more emotion in this debate than there should have been. There is no crisis that can be resolved in such an emotional way with screams and cheap populism. I find it important for the European Commission, in cooperation and dialogue with Ryanair, to quickly clarify the rights of the passengers concerned. It is unbelievable that in the times we live in, there are still people who do not know what rights they have. And here the responsibility is ours. To provide this information in an accessible way, in an accessible language, as people expect. I am surprised to learn that it is common practice for airlines to notify passengers by email. For better or worse, there are people who still don't have email or don't use it as actively. We owe it to each of them to be clear about what they can use and when. Because the damage is much more than just a canceled flight: failed plans, hotel reservations, meals, accommodation and more. This crisis will pass. Unfortunately, we can expect others like her to come. It is an indication that we have a problem to solve: to reform consumer protection and explain their rights in the best possible way. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)) (Rules of Procedure) (

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- It's not about the passengers not knowing the rights they have.Even if you know them and want to bring them in - Ryanair is the one who knows the rights exactly, but doesn't want to uphold them!That is the problem, not the incompetence of the passengers, but the brutal behavior of Ryanair against the passengers who are demanding their own rights!That is rejected, that is the scandal, not the ignorance of the passengers!

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: answer a question asked by picking up a blue card. - Let's assume, Mr. Kramer, that you are right and there are cases in which an airline has abused its rights and violated the rights of its passengers. That's why we have created a system and procedure - for people to know where to complain and what they can get. Otherwise what - will we close any airline that has violated or violated a procedure? People need to know in every situation what they can do, how to claim their rights and, if someone has violated them, to pay fairly for it.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Mr President, an airline’s operational measures cannot be influenced but, in every circumstance, airlines must act in accordance with the high standards of the consumer protection rules established by the EU. Therefore the failure to inform passengers or others of passenger entitlements, as happened in the case of Ryanair, is unacceptable. After announcing thousands of flight cancellations, Ryanair failed to inform passengers on several occasions that they have an option to be re-routed with other airlines where there is no suitable Ryanair service available within a reasonable time frame. This kind of misinformation has negative consequences beyond the damage done in the given case. When consumers are misled in such a way it discourages them from seeking access to their rights and destroys the enormous work that has been done on empowering EU consumers. Ryanair must meet its legal obligations and act in compliance with EU rules, which means it must take responsibility for the re-routing of passengers, including with other airlines. However, we must not forget about the damage that has been done in the field of consumer rights awareness.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, the Ryanair crisis has not responded to a problem of organization and management of the company. It is more, it is much more. We found a company with the most harmful recruitment practices in the aviation sector, which has meant that more than 140 pilots from the Irish company have left it. More than 70% of the Ryanair pilot workforce is made up of false self-employed workers, without the right to charge during sick leave or vacations. Rest times are not respected and, in order to work, they are forced to open their fake company in Ireland, benefiting the low cost company from taxation. It is the lack of regulation and control by the European Union that Ryanair is benefiting from and this is what has led to this crisis, in which hundreds of thousands of consumers have been affected. The fault lies not with the management, but with the denigrating labor practice and the permissiveness of the European Union.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - Mr President, so how far can a company, a company, go in making a profit, in this case an airline?Can this exploitation also include this exploitation of pilots and, of course, cabin crew, which this company puts in a position that is contrary to labor law standards and relationships?So is it appropriate and justified in this forging of profit to mislead passengers and cancel so many, so many thousands of flights?And, of course, the question of security can justifiably arise here because of all this.And if, of course, Ryanair estimates the total cost of its cancellations at less than 50 million euros, but said that this will not change the forecast of annual net profit of around 1.4 billion euros, it means that such behavior pays off,but I think that, of course, it is the European Commission and, of course, the European Parliament that must react to this and, of course, adopt the appropriate sanctions.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, I apologise that I was delayed getting to this debate, but it is about Ryanair so I suppose that being late is quite fitting. Are we really surprised that we are here debating Ryanair, the airline that charges you fifty quid to check in at the airport? I mean, seriously, can you imagine if any other business made its customers’ lives a misery on purpose? Imagine if it was somewhere like McDonalds and they charged you extra to have a cup for your drink or to carry your food on a tray? And now we’ve got planes with no pilots because they treat their pilots in the same way that they treat their customers and there is not the slightest hint that they give a stuff about their customers. On a serious note, the Irish Government needs to pull its finger out and do something about it. The worst part of it all is that Ryanair loves it: they love the rumours about standing-room on planes, or charging to go to the toilet, because they see criticism as free advertising. Ryanair literally wants to charge you for absolutely everything. Frankly they’ll probably want to charge us for Brexit as well! No, hang on, that’s the European Union.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, as the Council representative said, air transport is one of the main means of communication and one of the main drivers of development for any modern nation. Ryanair - one of the main airlines operating in Europe - canceled thousands of flights between September and October this year, causing thousands of euros in losses to its customers. Dear Colleagues, any and all operators operating within the European Union must, as the Commissioner said very well, have to respect European legislation. Passenger rights must be scrupulously defended and protected and those who are absent must be penalized with appropriate and, in my opinion, very heavy sanctions. Commissioner, the liberalization of airspace cannot be understood as debauchery or the application of the Western law. The Commission must take a firm hand and not let this type of attitude, which violates the rights of air passengers, on the part of Ryanair, be repeated to the detriment of the citizens and economies of the Member States. Commissioner, those who do not comply should not be allowed to operate within the Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Faria!A very short question: 800,000 passengers in the shortest possible time.Could you tell me how many of the passengers who might fly from Hamburg to the Ukraine or elsewhere for 15 euros really believed that they would fly there for a break even?

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Answer according to the "blue card" procedure.- Dear Colleague, I did not understand your question very well, but what I mean is that passengers are entitled to be compensated for the losses they suffer, be it 15, 20, 30, whatever, and there is, in fact,, provisions in the law that tell the amount for hours of delay and cancellations.So it's nothing new.The rules must be applied and they exist.European legislation exists, it is there.It is necessary that it be implemented.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, if we do not want to 'turn a blind eye', the problem with Ryanair has been around for many years and there is a violation of basic employment rights not only of pilots but also of many other employees. The question that is being raised today is what steps the Commission will take to repair the damage suffered by some 400,000 people and what steps will be taken so that the company itself can assume its responsibilities. It is not possible for companies to work with this data for so many years and we here "turn a blind eye" and just come to discuss an issue, devoting even a little more than the allotted time.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I believe I am the last passenger for tonight’s debate. I just want to say that I am sure Michael O’Leary, Chief Executive of Ryanair, is listening to this debate and his ears are burning, and that may be no harm. I hope he has heard the emotion of many colleagues in the Chamber, who have expressed the upset caused to passengers and the fact that we need to take this on board. Ryanair is a very large airline. The statistics, if you bear with me, are these: 131 million customers this year; operating in 33 countries; an unblemished safety record of 32 years. But the cancellations were of such a scale that people did begin to question whether there was more behind this than simply a rostering error. So Ryanair has work to do. On connecting with passengers, they have work to do, as all airlines have. When there is a problem, we need to talk to a human being, and perhaps that is something we could stitch into a regulation. Two further points. Firstly, could the Commission study the follow-up to this crisis? How many people actually claimed their rights? This would be an exercise that would be useful to us, to see if the legislation is working effectively. And lastly, Commissioner, do you think there is a need to tighten up the rules, or do you think everything is fine as we have it today?

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, first let me thank you for this very rich debate and I would like to assure you once more that the Commission will be in close contact with all national authorities and enforcement bodies concerned, to make sure that European rules, including those on passengers' rights, are strictly respected.  Let me now address some of your more specific questions. First on social problems. I'm not here to really speculate on the root causes of Ryanair's decision. At this stage, Ryanair has confirmed that this is solely due to rostering issues and management failure. European rules are really crystal clear. It is the responsibility of the Irish authorities to oversee Ryanair as an Irish airline and I'm confident that they are closely monitoring that Ryanair respects all its obligations. If they discover wrongdoing, I'm also confident that they will act accordingly.  On communication with stakeholders – information campaigns have been present since 2010 including videos, brochures, leaflets and so on. Interactive content is present on Your Europe. Coordination with NAPS ensuring airlines provide info, check-in online and at the airports is also ensured and present, and there are also more mobile applications that the customers can download. Obviously, this still is not enough. I issue a special statement before every holiday, summer and Christmas, and we can still look to see if anything else can be done so that people learn about their rights.  What were we doing on social conditions? There were several questions regarding that. There are concerns regarding the development of social conditions of mobile workers in aviation and I am very committed to moving forward on the social dimension of aviation and it will be the focus of my portfolio and an aviation strategy next year.  As far as state aid is concerned, the rules are the same for all airlines.  My services will soon launch also a study on certain employment and social aspects including bogus employment and alleged pay-to-fly schemes for pilots. The purpose is to understand better the facts on the ground and how they relate to existing legal obligations and EU policy for the future. Our work will take into account the case-law of the EU Court of Justice, including the recent one on the home base of air crews and the determination of the place of work.  The next question was related to intervening and sanctioning Ryanair, and, here, let me say the following. Member States have designed national enforcement body called NAPs, which are responsible for the enforcement of EU air passengers' rights. The sanctions for infringements of this regulation are laid down by Member States. For the time being, there is no reason to initiate any infringement procedures against Ireland and, as I said, I’m confident that they will do the work that they have to do.  And last but not least, EU safety rules – EU rules are the same for legacy and low-cost carriers. The EU has the highest aviation safety standards in the world and I'm also confident all national authorities follow this closely, including Ireland. So let the system do the job.  President and honourable Members, the single aviation market has propelled European mobility forward, bringing Europeans closer together and providing a solid foundation for more jobs and economic growth. Successful reforms played a key role here and the Commission along with national authorities has ensured and will ensure that these common rules are respected by all players, big or small. It is thanks to the EU that all passengers have a full set of rights when flying. This very unfortunate event has only further cemented the importance of these rules and the need for their full implementation, and it is in this spirit that I'm inviting you to see the challenge in front of us, as well. A challenge that we are actively addressing to the benefit of passengers. I can only hope that we can unblock the new proposal on passengers' rights in the Council and get it up and operational as an important tool for even stronger enforcement of passengers' rights. And I really welcome your support, honourable Members, on this point. This is exactly why we put forward guidelines last year to provide clarity and certainty, and yes I do travel low-cost, as a Commissioner and as a private citizen.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, some speakers have referred to the revision of the current legislation, something the Commission duly proposed in 2013. We all know what the state of affairs is with this piece of legislation, and we also all know why that is. The Council is, however, aware of its obligation. Similarly to the Commissioner, I can only hope that this highly regrettable Ryanair case will also give incentives to the Member States concerned to reconsider their position, so that we can adopt this set of stronger new rules for the passengers’ sake – for our citizens’ sake. Meanwhile the Ryanair case must be resolved. It must be resolved soon and all affected passengers must be duly compensated. Secondly, the national enforcement bodies must do all they can to assist passengers affected and to ensure that EU airlines abide by their legal obligations in the future. Similarly, EU airlines should be more proactive in providing clarity to their customers regarding the rules on compensation and assistance. The airlines are legally obliged to make passengers aware of their rights and should act accordingly.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The discussion is over.Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Recently, the news has been mixed with the news that the low-cost airline Ryanair has been forced to cancel thousands of flights, making the lives of tens of thousands of passengers bitter. A few days later, the company announced an even bigger wave of cancellations over the winter schedule. They justified their move on the grounds that they wanted to increase the punctuality of their flights, which fell from 90% in the first two weeks in September, to 80%, and that they were moving to a new leave system that projects the calendar year instead of April-March. freedoms. The negative contribution of these measures is the large number of cancellations. What the company must keep in mind is the European Regulation 261/2004, which strictly regulates passengers' rights in the event of cancellations. It is very important that Ryanair takes this into account and acts accordingly for harmed passengers. It is not enough to pay compensation to those concerned, but also, where appropriate, to provide hotel accommodation and other services to its passengers stranded abroad in accordance with the provisions of the regulation. Even so, there may be many thousands of people in a situation where they have already booked their accommodation, bought their museum tickets, concert tickets for specific dates. In such cases, it is important that those concerned receive individual assessment. I can only hope that the company learns from the current situation and will act much more prudently in similar cases in the future, always with the rights and interests of passengers in mind.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing.- The situation with thousands of Ryanair canceled flights is clearly unacceptable and should never have happened.However, it also shows clearly how much Europeans need the European Union in their daily lives.If there were no EU legislation, passengers would only depend on the goodwill of the airlines.Meanwhile, it is thanks to the European Union that injured passengers have the right to receive compensation and assistance, including in the form of accommodation and meals for the duration of an extended stay as a result of flight cancellation.However, compensation and reimbursement are due to passengers on the basis of proactively applying for them to the airlines, so I believe that Ryanair should conduct a broad information campaign and encourage passengers to pursue their rights.

name: Alex MAYER
text: in writing. – This crisis of cancellations, inconveniencing thousands of passengers has been on the cards for some time, and it is right that we debate how passengers’ rights should be enforced but what people really want is a convenient and reliable service. The truth is there is an inherent vulnerability in the Ryanair model, relying on unsustainable employment practices: zero-hour contracts, bogus self-employment, degrading treatment and even paying for one’s own training. You cannot pummel pilots for decades and then expect a smooth ride. This crisis may pass but the problems will roll on unless there is a change of mind-set. As MEP for the East of England, covering Stansted airport, my message is clear. This does not take blue-sky thinking just an end to employment practices that are unsustainable and wrong.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing. - The issue of Ryanair's flight cancellations could not be left out of its plenary agenda, as it affects around 2,000 flights and hundreds of thousands of passengers. The European Union has particularly high standards in the field of aviation, and this includes adequate protection of passengers' rights. That is why it was important to draw Ryanair's attention to informing the passengers concerned in good time of the situation and the means at their disposal so that they could receive adequate compensation. Ryanair is Europe’s largest low-cost airline and allows thousands of families to travel at affordable prices. This year, 131 million people used the airline’s services, which operate in 33 countries. I am confident that the airline's management will be aware of the serious consequences of flight cancellations and will do everything in its power to avoid such measures in the future.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - For twenty years, the European Union has been trying to defend the rights of airline passengers. It turns out today, however, that European regulations are still insufficient and imprecise, leaving the carriers with a wide margin of interpretation. Contrary to our expectations, passengers are less and less protected. Recent events and the sudden, massive cancellation of thousands of flights by the Irish carrier Ryanair clearly show that passengers are constantly exposed to unpredictable behavior and arbitrary decisions by airlines. The lack of rational planning and effective management skills not only reduces the reliability of carriers and destroys their reputation, but most of all reduces public confidence in transport. Ryanair often failed to notify canceled flights in advance. Thousands of passengers without the right to compensation, limited re-booking of a ticket for a flight of another carrier and airlines that are not responsible are the image of today's passenger aviation. In view of this situation, the Union must immediately increase the liability of carriers and strengthen the obligation to pay compensation in the event of cancellation of a flight. I also believe that in the event of cancellation of a flight by low-cost airlines, the obligation to re-book tickets for flights of traditional carriers without setting price limits should also be introduced, so as to prevent airlines from evading their obligations.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - While the low-cost airline had already announced the cancellation of 2,100 flights on September 17, Ryanair has once again decided to cancel more than 18,000 flights. Almost 400,000 European passengers will be affected by these cancellations. This situation is unacceptable. European travelers are held hostage by Ryanair's poor personnel management policy. Our priority must be to ensure respect for European law and passenger rights. Indeed, the European Commission must ensure that Ryanair does not shirk its responsibilities and respects the European legislation of 2004 on the protection of the rights of travelers. Passengers should have full access to compensation information as well as all available rerouting options. These cancellations are a reminder of the need to unblock at Council level discussions on the revision of the rules relating to passenger rights for which Parliament gave its position in 2014. It is urgent, the European Union and the Member States must act.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. - Passengers are still in a weaker position than airlines, despite having specific rights. It is very common for airlines to fail to notify passengers of their rights in the event of a flight disruption (delay, cancellation), although the Air Passenger Rights Regulation imposes such an obligation on them. In the last week alone, Irish carrier Raynair announced the cancellation, by the end of October, of more than two thousand connections to various European cities. EU regulations say that if a flight is canceled, the passenger has the right to reimbursement, re-routing or a return flight, as well as the right to assistance and compensation. Airlines operating in the EU must respect European regulations! We expect Ryanair to follow European rules relating to passenger rights. Action by the Community in the field of air transport should aim at ensuring a high level of protection for passengers. Moreover, attention should be paid to general consumer protection requirements. Further steps need to be taken to ensure that airlines comply consistently and that Member States enforce compliance more effectively. There is a need for further work in a number of areas, such as: improving enforcement, interpreting the unclear aspects of the regulation, distinguishing between delays and cancellations (as passengers have different rights depending on the circumstances), and increasing the role of national enforcement bodies overseeing the application of common rules.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda was the debate on: the objection pursuant to Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure on the draft Commission Regulation amending Annex II to Regulation (EC) No.1107/2009 establishing scientific criteria for the determination of the properties of endocrine disorder (2017/2872 (RSP))

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Author. - Mr President! I will speak Swedish because it is such a subject that I feel so strongly about. Endocrine disruptors are found in children's toys, in food packaging, in clothes, in various types of plastics, but also in pesticides that we can get in us through food. These chemicals can lead to several types of ill health, including problems with having children, cancer and the risk of diabetes. Young children and fetuses are extra exposed and sensitive to these chemicals and the effects show up later in life. Nevertheless, there is currently no proper regulatory framework in the EU that provides comprehensive and adequate protection against endocrine disruptors. More than seven years ago, the Commission was commissioned to develop scientific criteria for identifying endocrine disrupting chemicals. The Commission has, I'm sorry to say, handled this very poorly. After several years of delay and after being convicted in the European Court of Justice for failure to act, a proposal has now been presented. The question we must ask ourselves is: does this proposal live up to what it is for, to protect the environment and public health? Unfortunately, the answer is no. We have commissioned the Commission to identify which chemicals are endocrine disruptors - nothing more than that. What the Commission is now proposing is neither compatible with EU law nor provides adequate protection for human health and the environment against endocrine disruptors in pesticides. This is about the basic principle of the rule of law here. The Commission does not have the right to violate EU law with this proposal. This is a violation of the Commission's mandate. However, the Commission's proposal for an exemption for pesticides has been put forward precisely to attack the hormonal system of pests. They are thus endocrine disrupting in design. Nevertheless, the Commission does not think that pesticides should be classified as endocrine disruptors, even though they also have an effect on animals other than the target group. For example, we are talking here about bees, butterflies, bumblebees, crayfish and crabs, all of which have hormonal systems that can be affected by these pesticides.It is not scientifically defensible.Today it is about pesticides, but the Commission states that in the future the proposed criteria can also be used in other areas.Therefore, it is even more important that these criteria are good.We demand that the Commission do the right thing.Remove this irregular exception and come back with a new proposal without delay.Children and bees take precedence over the financial interests of individual stakeholders.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: author. – Mr President, I think my colleague Ms Guteland has already explained the importance of this debate on endocrine disrupters. To be very clear, we have been debating this since 2009 when the Commission was asked to come forward with criteria to define what endocrine disruptors are. This was part of the regulation on biocides and pesticides and it was one of the key debates. What are the criteria for endocrine disrupters? It took many years before the Commission finally came up with those criteria. It actually took the Court of Justice to push the Commission to come forward with the criteria. But another very important discussion that took place in 2009 was to ask what the cut-off criteria were with regard to the definition of endocrine disruptors. These cut-off criteria were crucial because, of course, if you fall outside the scope of the definition, you are not considered to be an endocrine disruptor. That was a crucial debate. An entire annex was drafted to design these cut-off criteria, and one of the key provisions there was that substances should be approved only if they were not considered to have endocrine-disrupting properties on non-target organisms. I repeat: ‘on non-target organisms’. It is precisely this provision that the Commission is now changing – through comitology and a delegated act. The Commission is changing a key provision of a law through comitology, and that is precisely what we are objecting to. The key question is whether the Commission is exceeding its implementing powers and the answer is ‘yes’. We even have advice from the Legal Service saying ‘yes’, the Commission is exceeding its implementing powers. That is exactly what we are discussing here. The Commission will say that we need to hurry up now, as this will delay things. Well, sorry! I say to the Commission: you have been delaying since 2009. Secondly, the Biocides Regulation is putting the same criteria on the table and there is no objection to that one. So we are objecting to the Commission exceeding its implementing powers, and that is a legal question that all our colleagues need to answer. This is not about whether you like it or not: this is about whether we allow the Commission to change a crucial part of the law through implementing powers. If they want to make that change, then they should come forward with a proposal for codecision. That is the way we do it. My question to our colleagues is: are we here for the rule of law or for the rule of industry?

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, yes, we will together follow the rule of law. It is crucial today for all of us, and I stress it because the Commission is following the mandate from the pesticides and biocides regulation, and of course this Commission started work in 2014 and started to deal with these very complex issues. We are here today debating the draft objection tabled in Parliament against the Commission regulation setting out criteria to identify endocrine disrupters in the context of the pesticides legislation. This proposal was sent by the Commission to Parliament and the Council for scrutiny on 20 July. I strongly ask the honourable Members to support the proposed criteria. I strongly request this. There is no benefit for health and the environment in keeping the interim criteria that are currently applicable. These are clearly not fit for purpose and this is recognised by all the stakeholders. Indeed, they fail to identify those that are real endocrine disrupters. I would like to stress that our proposed criteria are protective of human health and the environment, and are based on the widely agreed World Health Organisation definition of an endocrine disrupter. The criteria are also designed to identify known and presumed endocrine disrupters on the basis of all available scientific information, including human and animal evidence, as well as in-vitro and in-silico data. Furthermore, a ‘weight-of-evidence approach’ is to be used for the analysis of all the available scientific information. The Commission’s proposal is thus based on science and reflects a reasonable approach. It is supported by a clear majority of Member States. In fact, on 4 July this year after more than a year of intense negotiations, a qualified majority of Member States supported the draft Commission regulation setting criteria to identify endocrine disrupters for pesticides. Twenty-one Member States, representing more than 72% of the population, voted in favour, while those voting against, or abstaining, did so for different and sometimes opposite reasons. Some wanted stricter criteria, others weaker criteria or more possibilities for derogation. The proposed criteria are therefore a careful compromise and I would like to draw your attention to that. Yes, we know very well how difficult it is to build a compromise. This one would not have been reached without the inclusion of the specific provision which is at the centre of the draft objection tabled here in Parliament. This particular provision was added at the request of some Member States, during the negotiations – yes, during the negotiations – to improve their policy on sustainable use of pesticides, and was instrumental in getting the necessary support. And here we are discussing necessary support. The Commission did not want to oppose a reasonable and limited exemption for substances which target only arthropods and have no impact on vertebrates (human or animal). The Commission strongly believes that it has not exceeded its powers by including this provision in the draft Commission regulation, as it does not concern an essential element of the regulation. Furthermore, this provision is in line with the general objective of the regulation to promote the development and use of active substances that have, overall, more favourable properties in relation to the protection of human health and the environment. Let me also remind the honourable Members that, with the adoption of the draft regulation under scrutiny, the European Union would become the first regulatory system in the world with legally binding criteria to define what an endocrine disrupter is and to apply those criteria to pesticides, not only with regard to human health but also with regard to the environment. I am aware that some consider the proposed criteria to be imperfect, for different reasons. However, their adoption would be a significant step forward compared to the current situation with respect to better protection of human health and the environment. We are not in a hurry: our concern, as always, is how to protect human health and the environment. I strongly believe we owe that better protection to European citizens and the European environment. Only when the new criteria start to apply and we gain experience with them can we evaluate how they work in practice. The Commission had proposed to evaluate and report on their functioning at the latest in seven years’ time. In addition, the adoption of the criteria would constitute a solid basis for the Commission to advance in developing a new strategy on endocrine disrupters. Without finalised criteria there is no chance of obtaining a horizontal perspective, in relation to various types of chemicals. We need to have final criteria now because otherwise there is no possibility of moving forward. This House has repeatedly asked the Commission to come forward with criteria to identify endocrine disrupters. I believe we now have a solid compromise and criteria which represent a real step forward. Therefore, and to conclude, I invite you to seize the opportunity for better protection of human health and the environment from endocrine disrupters in the area of pesticides by not supporting this objection, and by enabling the Commission to adopt these protective criteria and move forward. Otherwise we will remain in the same situation as now. Today’s situation is very dangerous for people’s health and for the environment.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: , on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we have been asking the European Commission for criteria for the identification of endocrine disruptors for almost eight years. We finally have a proposal, which is certainly not perfect, but which at least has the merit of existing. It not only takes up the definition of endocrine disruptors given by the WHO, but above all it allows the European Union to once again place itself at the forefront in the protection of health and the environment. Endocrine disruptors are everywhere: in furniture, clothing, packaging, containers and food products. It is therefore essential to set strict and scientifically based criteria. We can't wait any longer. In addition, this proposal will replace the legislation currently in force, which is outdated and no longer responds to the challenges we are facing today. We must ensure an ever higher level of protection for citizens. For this, we must move forward with the technical and scientific knowledge at our disposal and it is therefore fundamental to encourage research and innovation in this area. However, it is manufacturers, SMEs and very small businesses that are developing research and innovation. They therefore need clear guidance on which direction to take and to be able to develop safer products for the future. If we reject the Commission's proposal, and adopt this objection, we will keep the current legislation and resume negotiations which risk taking another ten years. This is not a step backwards, as some suggest, but a step forward towards the implementation of one of the strictest laws in the world.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, as a matter of fact, the issue of the definition of endocrine-disrupting chemicals, as was mentioned, has been an ongoing and contentious issue over the past years. And trust me, we are not enjoying it! However, it is totally unacceptable and uncalled for to place the responsibility of the delay in the adoption of identification criteria on the European Parliament, particularly when the delay is mainly due to the unnecessary, and often biased, impact assessments carried out, despite the pressure from the European Parliament.  And yes, the European Parliament has the right of scrutiny. If every time we object we are told that nothing else will be proposed, this is completely unacceptable. Ultimately, as I have said, we have the right of scrutiny even when the Commission thinks it should not be reminded of the limits of its regulatory power.  Yes, in this case the Commission has exceeded the mandate granted by Parliament and the Council by coming back to the co-legislators’ decision to impose a strict ban on endocrine-disrupting pesticides. It is not acceptable that, in the current proposal, the Commission incorporated a special exemption for certain types of pesticides. This goes way beyond what we asked for as the European Parliament. Furthermore, the way the proposal is presented, it is simply introducing a derogation – an exemption – that is creating an improper loophole in the regulation, allowing continuous use of dangerous pesticides.  The Commission’s task was to set scientific criteria – nothing more, nothing less – and we will not accept the Commission deciding to go beyond its legislative power and introduce exemptions. That is why we want the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation and submit a new one, setting strict, straightforward and legally sound, scientific criteria without this aforementioned derogation.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mister President! We are discussing EDs, endocrine disruptors - unsavory, but ubiquitous: children's toys, lipstick, S-pesticides, everywhere - the effects of many of which have been completely unexplored. This is exactly why the EU has been active since 2000 to break new ground against EDs. Since 2009 we have been negotiating the registration system discussed today in order to better record and ban EDs. I am not satisfied with the length of this process. I think the system put forward by the Commission is at best a small triple step in the right direction - a step that many have to follow. I am therefore also concerned about the negative attitude of some. Do we really want to ignore five years of scientific work - back to zero - even though we were on the right track? No! Because whoever votes against, votes against the health of our children. Let us follow the scientists, not the lobby - for the citizens. I therefore also respect the warnings from the 3,000 petitioners and numerous non-governmental organizations. Let's make a start in the right direction - for our environment, for our children, against hormone-disrupting chemicals!

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, it is a very bad thing that we are having this debate here tonight, because the issue of endocrine disruptors is a very serious one that should have been settled years and years ago. The Commission had to set the scientific criteria, but by introducing a derogation it took not a technical decision but a political decision. That leaves us with no other choice than to object. Commissioner, I am afraid you have just given all the arguments why this is a political decision. You talked about year-long negotiations within Council. Why should you negotiate for a year if it is a technical decision? That is incomprehensible. You talked about a balanced compromise, but that is incompatible with a technical decision. I am afraid that you have completely side-lined the European Parliament: we should have been part of these negotiations with Council, and that is why you leave us no other solution than to object.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - The European Commission has been making excuses for years to keep hormone-disrupting substances on the market, while hundreds of studies have shown that even in low doses they are harmful to health. And they are everywhere. They are in cosmetics and toys, they are in agricultural poison and they are in the rubber granules on the synthetic turf fields where our children play. The Commission has a legal duty to protect people, animals and the environment against hormone-disrupting substances. I remind the Commission that this protection will not be effective if it keeps the back door open to endocrine disruptors and does so through an illegal procedure that makes Parliament's participation impossible. I remind the Commission that such protection will not be effective if the burden of proof is increased and the precautionary principle is not applied. Half measures are not accepted. All endocrine disruptors must be off the market. The Commission has already had many opportunities to do so. Commissioner, as far as I am concerned, you have not deserved more opportunities. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! I hope we are all aware that hormone-changing substances - i.e. endocrine disruptors - are highly problematic. That is why the legislature largely banned them in pesticides in 2009 - with good reason. The 2009 mandate was for the commission to establish criteria for how endocrine disruptors should be scientifically assessed and how consensual criteria should be set. What the Commission is now putting forward goes far beyond that. It goes beyond that because the Commission is not trying to set criteria on many points, but is simply trying to get rid of bans in the environmental sector. We cannot tolerate that, Commissioner! You are changing a legal basis, so to speak, and so that is not a question of how to evaluate it, but rather a highly problematic political decision that you are making here and that we cannot accept. Our legal service at Parliament says very clearly: This is a violation of the law! If we take ourselves seriously as a parliament - this has to be said very clearly - then this parliament has to veto it. You still have enough time to revise this and make a new template. But we will not allow ourselves to be put under time pressure now. After all, you had enough time to come up with something sensible. Unfortunately, you did not do that, Commissioner.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner. Endocrine disruptors are a problem but I think the problem with this issue is the time it has taken to get to this stage. Others have mentioned the eight-year gap in addressing the issue, which does not help in terms of confidence. I think all of us want to protect public health. The question I face, somewhere in between the extremes in this debate, is whether we are better to go with what the Commission has tabled, so that we make progress – it is better than the status quo, as I understand it, and I listened carefully to the Commissioner’s statement – or whether we should go with the objectors and say that we reject the Commission proposal and start from scratch. My fear with that proposal is that we would then wait another eight years to achieve any progress at all. Perhaps I am exaggerating the case but it does seem to me that that is the likely outcome. I am looking towards an election in the European Parliament, a change of Members of Parliament, a change of Commission, and all the reasons why things get delayed along the way. I am not sure what is wrong with the World Health Organisation definition, which we are accepting here, and I think that is something to follow, and wisely so. But if we accept the Commission proposal, which is my inclination at this stage, and reject your objections, colleagues, then I would like us to keep a close eye on the monitoring in relation to your idea of the definition, so that we can intervene earlier than is suggested. These are my thoughts at this stage. But we are talking about the health and well-being of consumers and of farmers, and we have to put that as our priority.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: - Sir. Chairman! Endocrine disruptors are a major health problem for us. We as legislators need to do something about it. That is why, for years, we in the European Parliament have wanted a basis on which to take action against endocrine disruptors. So it is important to have some criteria. Now that we're going to do it, we'll also have to do it properly. The proposal from the Commission is simply not good enough. One part is about what colleagues have been talking about, the exception. It does not matter that we start with our basic criteria and then already introduce an exception. But it is also about several things. It is also about the level of documentation that must be made to find an endocrine disruptor at all. The level of documentation is so high that it is far, far above the criteria we have when, for example, we have to assess carcinogens. It simply does not work! It is not only us in this House, but also some Member States, who think this is a problem. This includes my own member state, Denmark, which certainly does not want us to say yes to the proposal that is on the table now. I get angry when we are given the responsibility of dragging it out when the responsibility lies with you in the Commission for not having acted. There is talk that this is a compromise. I do not believe that we can compromise on the health of our citizens. We'll have to do it right from the start.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: - Mr President, this question of the definition of endocrine disruptors is essential. WHO took stock in 2013: 800 chemicals alter the human hormonal system. These are 800 substances that are responsible or suspected of increasing a whole series of diseases: certain cancers, diabetes, obesity, infertility, as well as various disorders linked to brain development. . This is to say whether the public health issue is major, but the Member States are divided on the question of identifying these criteria. The compromise adopted at the start of the holidays is the best proof of this, with its boulevard of derogations. Going beyond its powers, and Bas explained it perfectly, the Commission excluded from the definition of its pesticides those which are designed precisely to target the hormonal systems of insects and plants with considerable damage to those nearby which are not. targeted. The Endocrine Society, which brings together 18,000 researchers and clinicians around the world, expresses its deep concern. Citizens in Europe are mobilized. We are therefore asking tomorrow for a new definition of endocrine disruptors, a definition that truly protects public health and the environment.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner for Health, a few days ago the European Parliament closed its doors to Monsanto, because Monsanto does not simply despise our health, Monsanto despises our democracy. It has been eight years since, on endocrine disruptors, the Commission has left the door open to all chemical and pesticide lobbies ... For eight years you have despised our health and we are constantly obliged to remind your prerogatives and democracy. So today, now that it has been proven that you are going beyond your prerogatives, that you are going beyond your powers, you are right to mention that the Member States are not clear on this subject, and I myself have deeply regretted the retreat of France on the subject, but it is your responsibility to be the guarantor of the laws which are adopted, including in this Parliament. You read them every day, the studies that denounce the dangers. So tomorrow, for health reasons, for democratic reasons, we will refuse your criteria so that you can do your job again, for health and for democracy!

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, in small doses, endocrine disruptors often have a generational effect and come from a number of sources. We all know that this is an underestimated, irreversible and long-term risk. It has therefore been unfortunate to see how the Commission has set foot in this matter, both in the preparation of the criteria, which, through justice, had to speed up this process, and in the creation of the content. It therefore also seems unfortunate that the Commission is now referring to Parliament in terms of urgency, when at first the whole preparatory process has been very problematic. Secondly, according to Parliament's legal assessment, the Commission has indeed exceeded its powers. It has made a political compromise. Commissioner, I understand how difficult it is to make political compromises, but for human health and legally it was not possible here. Sometimes it is better not to make bad legislation that is long-lasting than not to do it. That is the reason for Parliament's rejection, which I think makes sense.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, history repeats itself indefinitely.
