The Commission does not act on absolutely essential health problems, such as endocrine disruptors, so it ends up being condemned for this inaction. Then she sets out to act, but the result is poor and insufficient. Serious exemptions are granted to set in stone the fact that large companies, large multinational chemical companies, can continue to pollute us. But you tell us: "Take it or leave it, and if you don't accept our proposal, then you won't get anything." So here we are attacking not only people's health, but also democracy. In short, we, who were elected by the peoples of Europe, would not have sufficient legitimacy to ask you, the European executive, to do a very simple thing, namely to withdraw your proposal and to present a news. This is your role, and this is what you owe the peoples of Europe today and what you owe us to us, who were elected by the citizens of Europe. So, whether on the issue of health, seriously endangered, all scientists say, by endocrine disruptors - and we know that your current proposal on the subject is insufficient, even dangerous - or whether it is on the issue of democracy, today you are completely wrong. This is why we are going to vote for this objection, and we ask you to show responsibility and to make a new proposal which, this time, meets expectations, especially with regard to the health of our European fellow citizens. .

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: - Mr President, it is a scientifically based fact that endocrine disruptors are substances that have the ability to affect people's hormonal systems and thus adversely affect their health. These chemicals are often associated with serious diseases, not excluding cancer, obesity, fertility problems, mutagenicity or various nervous diseases. The European Union is fully aware of the seriousness of the risks involved, and we have been fighting the consequences of such negative effects in this House for a long time. After all, many substances contained in endocrine disruptors are already banned by current European legislation on pesticides and biocides. From the doctor's point of view, I consider human life and health to be the highest values ​​and a goal that we should primarily pursue in the process of norm-setting. At the same time, I believe that, even in connection with the legislative proposal currently under discussion, it is necessary to take into account, in particular, scientific knowledge and to ensure that scientific criteria are rigorously incorporated into legislation in order to ensure the highest possible protection of the health of adults and our children. By adopting the criteria proposed by the Commission, the Union's regulatory framework will become, on a global scale, the strictest and therefore sufficient to effectively protect the health of European citizens. However, the key will be a thorough implementation process - I insist - without which even the best prepared legislation is only an intention and not a fact.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! I see it as our job to do two essential things: one is to protect the environment and human health, and the other is to comply with our legal principles. With what you have presented to us, both criteria are not met. We do not meet the highest possible protection of health and we do not fulfill the highest possible protection of the environment, but we also contradict our legal principles. Because, contrary to what you said in your remarks, that the Commission has not exceeded its powers, this House and Parliament’s Legal Service also clearly believe that you have done just that, namely with of this exception, the basic legal act has been changed so significantly that it is not within your competence. Today you really heard the factual and technical arguments against your proposal very clearly. We expect from you that we will receive a modified proposal as soon as possible in which this exception cannot be found. Nor do we feel responsible for the fact that it took almost eight years to come up with something. I am convinced that if this one paragraph that is at issue, namely this derogation, is removed, we will very quickly find something that does justice to the rule of law and also the best protection for health and the environment.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, the Commission’s proposal is the result of efforts and dialogue between the Commission and the Member States, and it is very balanced and reasonable. The proposal is based on the WHO definition of endocrine disruptors and it is based on three elements: adverse effect, endocrine activity and causal link. Unfortunately, the discussions on endocrine disruptors derive from arguments that are more emotional, and much incomplete and false information has been circulated. The stringent EU regulation framework in place does address endocrine disruption, maybe not as ideally as some of us would want to, but there is no legal vacuum now in Europe. As we speak, citizens are not left unprotected. I do not understand the goal of the objection because there is no benefit for health and environment in maintaining the interim criteria. The criteria are based on science and reflect an approach supported by 21 Member States, as the Commissioner stated earlier. The EU would be a pioneer in this field, and we could inspire other global players in legislating on endocrine disruptors. Those colleagues who are now initiating the objection, opting instead to reject the proposal and ask the European Commission to come with a new proposal, are either idealistic or are merely engaging in an exercise of rhetoric. It is impossible to come up with a new proposal as soon as possible. It will take some time, maybe years. So let us be reasonable and really work to the benefit of European citizens.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time we have addressed the issue of endocrine disruptors in this House and it will not be the last. We all know, for example, that the European regulation on the placing on the market of plant protection products provides that an active substance can be authorized only if it does not adversely affect the endocrine system. I believe that the Commission's proposal for the identification of endocrine disruptors goes beyond the powers conferred on it, because it arbitrarily restricts the field of disruptors and is therefore unsuitable for ensuring adequate protection of human health and the environment. Such a decision should be preceded by an amendment to the regulation on plant protection products, which can only be done through a normal legislative process and therefore with the approval of the Parliament and the Council. But there is more: the failure to include in the Commission proposal a category of suspected endocrine disruptors and cross-references, in the event of the concomitant presence of two or more disruptors, is an unacceptable deficiency. We cannot continue to put the economic interests of large industrial groups before the health of European citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, endocrine disruptors are dangerous chemicals contained in materials, in toys, in food. It is a given that measures must be taken against the use of all these chemicals which have a detrimental effect on public health and the environment. As it turns out, the criteria for identifying and locating endocrine disruptors must be determined on the basis of scientific and technical specifications. It cannot be the result of a political compromise between the Member States. But what we see is that there is a political compromise that has nothing to do with scientific criteria. Nor, of course, should we accept the reversal of the burden of proof. In our view, the Commission has exceeded the powers it has acquired in this area. We therefore consider that this is a unilateral breach of powers and of course the European Parliament, in cooperation with the Council, is responsible for taking decisions. We reiterate, therefore, that this is a "carbine" excess of powers by the European Commission.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, you said that we must protect health and the environment. If we are where we are today, if we make this objection, it is primarily because of the Commission. The first time, in 2013, you had to define criteria. As of 2015, these criteria had still not been set. We had to go to the European Court of Justice. Now, we don't agree with your definition. Why? Because you are making an exemption on products that are made to be endocrine disruptors. Legal Services say you are overstepping your rights. Also, I address my colleagues: today, if we vote for this definition which does not satisfy endocrinologists internationally, we will have it throughout the legislation because it will be the reference. You should absolutely not be complicit in a definition that does not correspond to the protection of health and the environment. Consequently, Commissioner, this definition must be reviewed. You must not be complicit in a system in which the chemical lobbies push for this exemption. Review your copy because if we are here today and we are fighting so hard, it is in the interest of European citizens and not in the interest of the private sector.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Commissioner. - Colleagues, honorable Members, I have listened very carefully to what you have said. I would like to make a few remarks on each of the speeches, but it is unfortunate that some colleagues decided not to listen to my answer, left the Chamber, even though they spoke very categorically. And I would like to draw attention, colleagues, to a few necessary facts. The first thing we know very well is that these proposals were launched in discussions with the entire scientific community in the European Union: endocrinologists, toxicologists, oncologists, cardiologists. I myself am a cardiac surgeon. I know what human health means. And no multinational corporations will help here. It’s not about talking. It’s about scientific criteria and we’ve seen a lot of very different opinions among scientists. As the spheres of regulation are also very wide, we decided to reach a scientific consensus. We are not judges of scientists. They presented their consensus and common view. And they also discussed methodologies and the regulatory mechanism. I would very much like to hear your specific suggestions on methodologies. After all, we have been discussing in the ENVI Committee since 2014, when I came here. We introduced in 2015. positions, then we discussed impact assessment, then it was time for public consultations, we discussed a lot. In fact, we have talked about this more than once in committee, because the profile committee is working on those positions. That is acceptable to me, acceptable to me. Of course, we also discussed legal arguments, and here we started discussions not only with the Council of Europe a year ago, but only in July this year, because we have completed the difficult negotiations, we have coordinated with the Commission's Legal Service, it is not incompetent, because, as you know, it is not possible to submit a proposal without the consent of the Legal Service. I understand that the legal services of different institutions may interpret differently, but I am not a proponent of a legal dispute. And so I think we made a balanced offer and with certain methodologies. In our discussions with the Council, yes, the Member States put forward different arguments, which needed to be reconciled, but this amendment is without prejudice to common criteria and scientific definitions. No more, there is only a common definition by the World Health Organization. We rely on it. Therefore, I think today is a really great opportunity to have a discussion, especially with those who have come out and who are not listening to me now. Discuss because I am open to discussion. A lot of people have talked about democracy, here is democracy - to discuss, but not to express an opinion and come out. I tend to debate. Let me conclude. I am aware that some of you consider the criteria proposed as imperfect. I would, however, like to strongly emphasize once again that their adoption would be a significant step forward compared to the current situation with respect to the better protection of human health and the environment. The current applicable interim criteria are, indeed, not fit for purpose. It is true. We could discuss the theory of the perfect criteria for many more years, as opinions and views on this topic remain deeply divided. However, we will only make progress on this issue if we replace the interim criteria and start to apply new criteria. We will be the pioneering Union in the world. These criteria will provide a unique opportunity to better protect the health of citizens and the environment. I therefore ask you not to vote in favor of the proposed object tomorrow.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: written. - We have become used to quiet springs, with almost no insects, no birds, and very little wildlife. The widespread use of chemicals in all areas of human activity and their effects as endocrine disruptors was warned in 2013 by the WHO. This body highlighted that exposure to these products is a concern not only for wildlife, but also for humans. The WHO insisted that legislators should take steps to regulate human and environmental exposure to these substances. After a long wait, the Commission surprises us with a definition of a hormone disruptor, which excludes hormone disrupting pesticides from insects and exempts them from being considered as such, even if they have a hormonal effect on other arthropods. Is this how the Commission fulfills its mandate to protect people, animals, the environment and their ecosystems? This exclusion affects 95% of the animal kingdom formed by arthropods, with key roles in the balance of ecosystems, in addition to risking the health of humans and other vertebrates. Such a definition is unacceptable and, in addition, it requires weighty tests to be carried out to determine the endocrine effect that could take years.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - Endocrine disruptors, these substances which disturb the organism and induce harmful effects, can in no case be authorized. Unfortunately, under pressure from certain Member States, the European Commission, within the framework of the text which will be submitted to us, largely exceeded its mandate, by adding a derogation authorizing pesticides. The reason: the purpose of said products is precisely to prevent pests from reproducing. But what about human beings? After the saga of glyphosate, here comes the saga of endocrine disruptors? No. In these two cases, the precautionary principle must continue to prevail! That will be the meaning of my vote, as it has always been. Let's remove the clause on disruptors by design. Call for the withdrawal of the implementing regulations and call for the presentation of a new proposal, without delay. Once the text, I hope, is adopted, the European Commission will have to withdraw its draft and review its copy in negotiations with the Member States. And we will prove in passing that, no, "Brussels" does not decide everything.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on: - the report by Daniela Aiuto, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2009 / 45 / EC on safety rules and standards applicable to passenger ships (COM (2016) 0369 - C8-0208 / 2016 - 2016/0170 (COD)) (A8-0167 / 2017), - the Izaskun report Bilbao Barandica, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council that modifies Council Directive 98/41 / EC, on the registration of persons traveling on board passenger ships from ports of the Member States of the Community or destined for them and Directive 2010/65 / EU of the European Parliament and of the Council, on the information formalities required of ships upon arrival or departure from the ports of the States members (COM (2016) 0370 - C8-0209 / 2016 - 2016/01 71 (COD)) (A8-0168 / 2017), and - the report by Dominique Riquet, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on a system of inspections to ensure the safety in the operation of ro-ro ferries and high-speed passenger ships in regular service and amending Directive 2009/16 / EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on the control of ships by the port State and Council Directive 1999/35 / EC is repealed (COM (2016) 0371 - C8—0210 / 2016 - 2016/0172 (COD)) (A8-0165 / 2017)

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have come to the end of this process of revising European legislation on maritime transport, doing an excellent job in concert between Parliament, the Commission and the Council. I thank all my colleagues from the Committee on Transport and Tourism, the representatives of the European Commission, the representatives of the Maltese Council Presidency for their fruitful and constructive work. Maritime safety is an issue of vital importance for all European passengers and it is essential that we work to achieve ever higher standards in the Member States, while respecting all the international standards defined within the IMO. It is therefore important that there is congruity and effectiveness of all the rules adopted and that Europe always maintains a proactive and leading role in this regard. Parliament and the Council welcomed the Commission's proposal for revision and simplification in order to clarify several areas covered by the existing legislation and to remove the ambiguities that created problems in the implementation and transposition of the rules. We agreed on the exclusion from the scope of the directive of a number of categories of vessels for which, indeed, the implementation of the required rules was considered disproportionate. I am referring in particular to passenger ships of less than 24 meters in length, to service ships carrying workers to offshore installations, to sailing ships, provided they are equipped with auxiliary mechanical propulsion. I think it was important to clarify and include the concept of aluminum as an equivalent material. It is important that this happens, as we must take into account what are the intrinsic properties of the material and the need to compare them to the fireproofing capacity of similar materials. Aluminum must be considered a material equivalent to steel: passenger safety is at stake in case of accidents and fires. However, as Parliament, we have strongly insisted that there are no gray safety zones for the excluded categories. That is why we have reiterated the need for a commitment by the Commission and the Member States to work, both at national and IMO level, to ensure that safety is always guaranteed. Another important point for us, which emerged in parliamentary proceedings and also carried out in negotiations with the Council, was that of the importance given to the human element and to correlate the social dimension of workers directly with safety on board. The conditions affecting the life on board of the personnel and the social aspects affect the efficiency and effectiveness of the prevention of risks, problems and accidents. It is important that this link becomes a constant and transversal in all EU transport policies. This is why I appeal to the Commissioner to be the spokesperson for this body also in future legislative initiatives. Only if the workers operate in optimal conditions, passengers will be able to have adequate safety standards. Another important point for Parliament was that of transparency: we insisted that any exemptions, equivalences and additional security measures be published on a website accessible to the public and on this issue too we managed to find a convergence with the Maltese Presidency. We accepted the requests from some Member States in order to protect national specificities, in some cases of a geographical nature, in others linked to employment and work aspects. We have therefore managed to reach an agreement with the Council, aware that the provisions adopted by this Assembly must always be an added value for the Member States and not a deleterious element, as unfortunately sometimes happened in the past.In conclusion, I hope that this procedure for revising the legislation in force in the maritime sector will lead to a real benefit to passengers, professionals, companies in the sector and, more generally, the issue of transport safety in Europe.I hope that the Commission will continue in the future to carefully monitor the evolution of the rules adopted to ensure consistently high standards for European citizens.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: speaker. - Mr President, improve the safety of passengers in maritime transport, offering homogeneous data to rescue services in the event of an accident throughout the Union, and do so with the most scrupulous respect for privacy and European regulations for the protection of data, is the goal of this report. We collect here an agreement that has been from the beginning with the best disposition on the part of all, an attitude that I want to recognize and I want to thank especially Itxaso and Mae for the work they have done, the shadow rapporteurs and also the Commission. But let me particularly emphasize the role of the Maltese Presidency, which deserves public recognition for the commitment with which it has carried out its six-month presidency. This report also wants to contribute to the shared objective of better legislating, of eliminating obstacles thanks to simpler rules, because, in this specific aspect of passenger data, the regulatory dispersion, organizational conditions and the distance between what they raised The rules and what technology allows was already unacceptable today: a gap that, in addition to penalizing the effectiveness of a possible rescue operation, contributed to legal uncertainty. Thus, this agreement with the Council focuses on the new rules to digitize the passenger registry of ships and offer complete data to rescue services to improve their operation. In this way we protect the right and also respond to the need of family members to have verified and secure information in emergency and distress situations. The purpose is to make the exact number of passengers and other useful information immediately available to search and rescue services in the event of an accident. Nowadays, valuable minutes can be lost, because the data of the people on board is stored by a shipping company. The search and rescue center has to ask the company contact person the necessary information, and, in digital form, the information will be directly accessible. To facilitate assistance to victims and their families, the data recorded will include the nationality of the passengers. Current regulations oblige the shipping company to register the name, date of birth, gender and, if the passenger so wishes, the need for special assistance in case of emergency. In addition, the voluntary possibility is added for the passenger to include a contact telephone number for emergency cases. In accordance with the new requirements, the data will be sent to the competent authority in electronic format within 15 minutes of the ship's departure. Two means of transmission can be used: the national single window or the automatic identification system, subject to certain conditions. I hope that progress in the development of national single windows will serve as the basis for promoting a European single window in the future. The agreement is also characterized by its ability to offer solutions and flexibility and contemplates specific situations for short voyages that affect Germany, Denmark and Sweden. In these cases, data transmission will be accepted up to one hour after the start of the trip. Privacy and data protection is guaranteed by the immediate destruction of these passenger lists, automatically and without undue delay, as soon as the trip is over and the data is no longer necessary to support rescue services in an accident, emergency or for use in court cases. Member States will have four years to carry out the necessary technological and organizational transition and another two from the entry into force of the Directive to be able to incorporate the new rules into their national legislation.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: , protractor. - Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, dear colleagues, this report on the inspection system for ro-ro ferries and ferries is an opportunity to recall this terrible accident which took place at one o'clock in the morning on September 28, 1994, between Tallinn and Stockholm. That day, in less than ten minutes, an uncontrolled opening of the loading doors allowed water to rush into the Estonia ferry, which sank, killing 852 people. It was the deadliest passenger ship accident in Europe after the Titanic, and it happened less than 23 years ago. And this is not an isolated accident. A few years earlier, it was off the port of Zeebrugge that another disaster had caused the death, under the same conditions, of 193 people. And four years ago, off South Korea, 454 children were killed in a sinking ferry. In 2015, the ports of the European Union recorded 395 million sea passengers. This is a considerable number, which is why it is essential that the safety of these passengers be ensured to the highest standards. This directive on an inspection system for the safe operation of regular services of ro-ro ferries and high-speed passenger craft is an amendment to the directive on port state control, which becomes the reference directive, and at the same time repeals the directive on a system of compulsory inspections specific to ro-ro ferries. The first exercise was to simplify, rationalize and concentrate the existing standards. We then strengthened and clarified the regulation, the key elements of the report being: clarification of responsibilities between port state and flag state by avoiding duplication and loopholes; definition of the competent authority of the Member State; clarification the frequency of inspections, which must take place twice a year, including one in operation, and at intervals of four to eight months. Another novelty is that inspections of ro-ro ferries and high-speed passenger craft should be considered as an absolute priority in the quota of annual inspections of the Member States. An article has been added on taking into account risks related to passengers and crew, in order to include an additional human element in these inspections. Commission wording allows delegated acts to be adopted as much as necessary under appropriate conditions. Finally, we have an agreement on re-inspections in the event of a change in the use of the vessel. Finally, a database will be set up to allow information to be exchanged as quickly as possible during ongoing inspections between Member States. Let me here thank all the shadow rapporteurs of the Committee on Transport and Tourism for their work and excellent collaboration, the responsible Director of the European Commission for his support and expertise, not forgetting of course the Maltese Presidency for its cooperation, its ambition to carry out this triplet of directives and its ability to comply with the remarks and requests of the European Parliament. This is how last June we quickly reached a trilogue agreement on this directive. I hope it gets a massive vote from our Parliament.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, passenger ships play a key role in the mobility of our citizens as well as being a holiday experience. With more than 200 million passengers embarking from European Union ports each year, their safety is at the heart of our common transport policy. The vote in this House will make our safety rules clearer, more proportionate and better fit for purpose.  The three directives on passenger and ship safety that we are debating today were put in place 20 years ago to provide for a common level of safety and to remove barriers to trade. It was now high time to ensure that these objectives are improved upon in view of the implementation of experience and technological progress. We can only applaud the constructive and positive approach of the co—legislators that made it possible to reach a compromise in one month. This clearly shows that the safety of European Union citizens is our principal and shared objective.  The new legal act can still be adopted this year as we regard 2017 as ‘Maritime Transport’ year, during which we are working intensively with all stakeholders and, of course, for the benefit of citizens as is the case when safety rules are reviewed. On Directive 2009/45/EC on safety rules and standards for passenger ships: concerning the safety rules and standards for passenger ships, we welcome an agreement reached on how to deal with an aluminium ship built outside the scope of the directive. The agreed phase-in period provides for a clear direction to influence the business strategies of the shipyards in question in order to adapt and maintain jobs. The duration of this transition still remains long.  On the issue of derogation for land-locked countries with no passenger ships, we are reassured by the agreed solution. While minimising the administrative burden, it provides for strong safeguards that prevent Member States from allowing ships to fly their flag unless they have transposed the corresponding directive.  On Directive 98/41/EC on the registration of passengers, we are glad to see that the Commission’s proposal has been preserved and the vision of electronic data reporting confirmed. However, the six-year phase-in period is a lost opportunity considering the speed of digitalisation in many areas of life. We truly hope that most Member States will not make use of such a long phase-in period in practice. To finish on a positive note, the Commission wholeheartedly welcomes the amendment driven by Parliament to halve the delay in reporting the information on persons on board to the single window. On Directive 1999/35/EC, the inspection proposal means a reduced administrative burden for shipowners. Member States maritime administrations will be able to rationalise their inspection efforts, all the while preserving the same safety level. The new rules should make it easier for the operators to comply with legislation and for the national competent authorities to apply it. It also makes it easier for us – the Commission and the European Maritime Safety Agency (EMSA) – to support Member States in implementation and enforcement. We want to take this opportunity to highlight the indispensable contribution of the EMSA in this respect, including its role in enabling the information sharing between Member States.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: , rapporteur for the opinion of the JURI committee. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate my colleague Daniela Aiuto for having presented in her report the objectives that we had set ourselves in the Legal Committee, namely the maintenance of a high level of safety on ships and preservation of passenger confidence. As part of the simplification process operated by the Commission, many of the definitions contained in the Directive have been adapted to current circumstances, in particular due to the development of technologies in the field of maritime transport. This is the case in particular for ship building materials. In fact, in its initial version, the Directive only applied, for example, to ships made of steel and equivalent materials, but it has not been implemented in the same way in all the Member States. in disregard of safety rules. The proposal therefore clarifies the scope of the Directive as regards the definition of aluminum as an equivalent and resistant material other than steel, in order to achieve high and common safety standards for all these ships. It is therefore a question here of raising the level of safety for passenger ships, and this European initiative should be welcomed.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the LIBE Committee. - The 1998 directive was the first European law on passenger ship safety in the EU. The aim is not only to ensure that the safety of passengers on passenger ships is not endangered by exceeding the maximum number of passengers allowed, but the Directive also stipulates that search and rescue operations following an accident must be conducted efficiently. This guideline is now being updated. In the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I followed up this file and tabled a number of amendments. I am pleased that many of my proposals have been included in the final version adopted by the Committee on Transport. For example, in addition to data protection principles, the obligation to communicate the nationality of a crew member to the captain of the ship was also included. In this way, reliable information can be provided to relatives faster in the event of an accident. Therefore, the identification procedures have been simplified. Identification always takes time and so the faster the better for concerned family members.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - First, I would like to apologize to my colleague Cláudia Monteiro, who was shadow rapporteur for two of these reports. You would not infer from the interest in this debate that this is a large maritime dossier. There are several aspects that we are discussing this evening that directly affect the work of the internal market. An internal market in the maritime field, and that is very important for Europe. Indeed, first and foremost the safety of ships and passenger ships. A big topic, unfortunately with a few accidents in the past. And if we look outside of Europe, we still see many of these accidents. The second element is indeed automation and registration. Mrs. Stevens said it already: better safety for the passengers, that they know where they stand. The third topic is inspection. We must be careful in Europe that we do not have too much overlap of inspections. With the latest proposal, inspections are simplified, simplified and improved. Finally, the service to citizens. That is an important part of these three reports. People know more quickly where they stand. People know more quickly who is on board and that will in turn improve safety. Finally, thanks to the rapporteurs, the shadow rapporteurs, but also to the trilogues that went smoothly for these technical files. We are taking a step forward for the safety and development of “Maritime in Europe”.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Dear Mr. Chairman, Commissioner! (Although it is a pity that Commissioner Bulc is not with us today, because I have some kind words for her, which is rarely the case.) The tragic incident of the Costa Concordia ferry was an impulse to remove the existing inaccuracies and differences in interpretation of the rules on safety on passenger ships, which are used by nearly 400 million people every year. Therefore, the action of the Commission aimed at clarifying many provisions, especially when it comes to issues related to the construction of passenger ships, should be assessed positively. It is worth praising the new legal framework for accelerating the digitization of the ticket booking and passenger registration process. Quick access to travelers' personal data is extremely important for security reasons, also during rescue operations. The flexibility of the proposed solutions, which will introduce reasonable transition periods and significant exemptions, for example for passenger ships up to 24 meters in length, should also be appreciated. I wholeheartedly support this package and hope that it will bring tangible results quickly.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, on behalf of Mrs Bulc! Indeed, it is not only the accident on the Costa Concordia that caused us to deal with ship safety here in Parliament, but also other ship accidents that have occurred. It was just about time to bring ship safety to a new level, including in terms of materials and digitization, and that is what happened here. This is of course very, very important because shipping is becoming increasingly popular. It's not just about ships on which freight is transported, but above all about passenger ships and ferries. It is really very important that we have now found a solution that is not only adapted to the current situation, but also means less bureaucracy and avoidance of duplication, which means that it also means better regulation. That is what the new Commission was aiming for. We very much welcome that, and that is why we in Parliament support it very much. Malta is a seafaring nation. This was still being negotiated under the Maltese Council Presidency. And the Maltese are no longer there, but that was also a great success. So, once again, congratulations to everyone who was involved!

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, a constituent of mine,  Sally Lloyd, contacted me in relation to a family tragedy four years ago when her brother, Richard Fearnside, disappeared while travelling on a ferry. The lack of CCTV cameras on the ferry passenger decks left his family with many unanswered questions, not knowing whether Richard suffered an accident, took his own life, or was possibly even pushed overboard. His name is added to an increasing list of missing ferry and cruise ship passengers and I am humbled to be able to support his family’s campaign for mandatory CCTV and thermal imaging cameras on all ferries operating from British and EU ports. Nearly 100 000 people have now signed their ‘Change.org’ petition and tonight I formally urge all international institutions to act accordingly on this important matter. All the bereaved ask for is a degree of closure. Surely that is not unreasonable?

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, the proposed changes, like the current directives, are moving in the direction of boosting the profitability of shipping capital. The European Union and its governments, such as that of SYRIZA-ANEL, in continuation of the previous ones, entrust the security controls of ships, passengers and merchants, to private companies-classifiers, connected with the shipowners and other parts of the capital. These "sell" perforated certificates of airworthiness in old and under-maintained "caps" of the shipping capital, with reduced organic compositions, destructive working conditions of seafarers. In this way, the European Union and governments cover up shipping crimes, which cost lives and cause environmental disasters, such as the recent one in Greece in the Saronic Gulf with the sinking of a tanker full of fuel oil. Compensation is required here and now for all victims. The people can conclude: the capitalist profit and the system that serves it are incompatible with the safety of the lives of passengers and crews, the protection of the environment, the popular needs for modern, cheap, quality transport.

name: Werner KUHN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! If we proceed from the arguments of the previous speaker, it is really conclusive that it is necessary to keep updating the safety regulations, especially for passenger shipping, for roll-on / roll-off ships. Safety of Life at Sea - that is the SOLAS agreement. Of course we have to comply. The employers' liability insurance association, which is responsible for the crews, is also behind, so that the working and living conditions on the ships continue to improve. But of course we also look at the passengers in a special way, and the passengers have to be registered as soon as possible when they go on such a ship. This data should be digitized. They should - even if such an IT system is not on board - be transmitted via the automatic ship identification system to the respective port into which this passenger ship is entering. Because especially in difficult situations - when search and rescue is the order of the day, i.e. when marine accidents are looming there - the rescue equipment must be available and land-based rescue units must of course be able to come to such a passenger ship as quickly as possible. Earlier, we heard very specific examples of this from colleague Riquet - whom I would like to thank again for the good work he has done. The ship's construction naturally also plays a crucial role, which is also constantly evolving. Estonia: What was the cause of this unbelievable shipwreck? The bow hatch did not close properly and seawater got into the hold, a free surface, and within a short time this ferry sank and 800 people were killed. We have to have things like that on it. Whether aluminum constructions or steel constructions are the right thing to do - I believe both works very well.And with the high-speed ferries it is of course also necessary that the drive power is appropriate, also with the other passenger ships, so that there is maneuverability, the steering gear is in order, the life-saving appliances are there.In principle, this is how we can shape the future of maritime transport in Europe.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, one of the tasks we set ourselves as legislators is to check the impact of the rules we are proposing and, if necessary, subsequently revise them to make them leaner. And this is precisely what happens with the regulations concerning the safety of passenger ships. Simplification, in addition to meeting the changing needs of the sector, is the means that also allows us to obtain greater transparency and to make these ships safer. I therefore absolutely agree on the exemption, for boats under 24 meters, from the scope of the legislation and also on the equalization of aluminum and equivalent materials to steel. With regard to inspections, many things have changed since 1999 and therefore it is appropriate to strengthen this regime, combining it with the 2006 legislation. Finally, for the regime for registering passengers on board ships, I agree on a timely sending of data, i.e. 15 minutes from the departure of the ship from the port, by means of a common electronic system. Sadly known cases of shipwrecks and fires on board and in which many people have lost their lives in recent years, perhaps they could not have been avoided, but to know the number of passengers on board, in a timely manner and the possible presence of people with particular mobility needs, it might have helped us to save more.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr President, the proposals made by this package of measures will make the safety system for passenger ships simpler, more modern and more efficient.Both the Commission and the rapporteur have taken a flexible stance towards smaller vessels of less than 24 meters in length and smaller shipowners that mainly perform short domestic voyages of less than 20 nautical miles.This is a good approach because it will not make business more difficult for smaller shipowners, but it will still raise the level of passenger safety.The principle of proportionality in such cases is important to apply so as not to overburden small carriers and make them uncompetitive, which would lead to major transport challenges and job losses.I agree with the rapporteur that it is extremely important to take into account the protection of passenger data and that it must be automatically destroyed once it has fulfilled its purpose.Data manipulations must be avoided if we want to gain the trust of passengers and shippers in the new system.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, I want to thank Mrs Aiuto for the work she has done on this complicated report, because this proposal adds safety guarantees to maritime transport passengers and because it clarifies the requirements that ships must respect during their construction process. In addition, it details its stability conditions and improves fire protection measures. The agreement, which will apply to vessels over 24 meters in length, reinforces the effectiveness of the legislation because the new standards it defines favor a uniform interpretation. The logical consequence is a reinforcement of security guarantees and more possibilities of control. The agreement also solves the problem raised by the original deadline for the repeal of this Directive in relation to aluminum boats, a serious problem for one of the Member States. The solution found allows this requirement to be parked only for ships currently under construction or for orders available to shipyards, for which financing contracts already exist. In any case, these vessels will be subject to national regulations without prejudice to their safety conditions.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, this is without doubt an important package of legislation, which aims to clarify the current EU passenger ship safety regulatory framework and to allow for a simple and clear application of that framework. This will ultimately contribute to a higher standard of safety for passengers, which we all welcome.  This proposed revision will simplify rules and minimise administrative costs, as well as making sea travel safer. It is important that we maintain EU rules where necessary and proportionate and ensure that those rules are applied correctly and transparently. This text achieves the right balance in this regard. Additionally, the proposal looks to prevent any clash of duties and inconsistencies between various related pieces of legislation, which is positive, and I welcome it. It is important that passenger ships are subject to frequent systematic inspections. This revision makes a much—needed update to EU passenger safety legislation and brings our laws in line with the evolving demands and limitations of modern safety standards. The proposal prioritises efficiency and frequency of inspections conducted by national administrations without unnecessarily restricting ships’ commercial operations. With 23 coast Member States and four island Member States, passenger ships play an important role in EU citizens’ mobility. This makes safety regulations in this area all the more important.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: - Mr Chairman!The Costa Concordia cruise ship disaster was the result of a serious mistake by the ship's captain, and not of flawed regulations regarding the safety of passenger ships, as several people have tried to suggest to us here in the discussion.Therefore, the legal changes proposed by the European Parliament and the Council do not have to revolutionize the legal matter.Fortunately, the aim of the new directives is not to create new legal rules, but to organize and simplify them.It seems that this creates an opportunity to maintain the highest possible level of security while reducing bureaucracy.Legal provisions must be clear and must guarantee the highest possible quality of shipbuilding materials, high quality navigation and professional crew.If we meet these conditions, there is a chance for safe ship travel.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, ship travel is particularly important in the European Union. 400 million passengers are handled, of which 120 million are domestic passengers. If we take into account the cruise ships, one realizes that they are a large number of our fellow citizens who are transported by ships. Therefore, we need to have increased safety standards for passenger ships and, of course, for ferries and speedboats. This means that we must stick to the issue of security. Any simplification of procedures must not be to the detriment of security, the process must stop where in some countries, including Greece, strange certificates of airworthiness are given in "sapaki". We had the case of the sinking of the "Holy Zone II" which literally infected the Saronic Gulf and it turns out that stricter standards are needed, because the main thing is the protection of passengers and of course not the profitability of companies and shipowners. This is very important. Finally, passenger data must be recorded, but in such a way as to protect personal data. This is also a very important issue.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the three proposals for a directive on the safety of passenger ships aim at common objectives, which essentially are to improve legislation on maritime transport, standardize safety procedures and introduce the use of digital technologies in the passenger flow management. The work of rationalizing the legislation through REFIT must be focused on eliminating the uncertainties still present today, concerning, for example, the classification of risk areas at sea, safety inspections and digital recording of passenger data and offering tools effective designed for operators in the sector and authorities, in compliance with the sensitive data of passengers. In this regard, it is important that the role and competences of EMSA, the Maritime Safety Agency, which in recent years has been carrying out complex and delicate tasks, especially in the Mediterranean basin, be enhanced. 2017 is the European Maritime Year: there is no better occasion to give a new boost to the sector, enhancing maritime transport as an essential part of the European Union economy.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on all three reports. These are complex reports, they are technical reports and, all the more, it is worth congratulating them on the fact that they have managed to move in the direction proposed by the Commission, but, of course, to make improvements as well. As a member of the TRAN Commission, but also IMCO and LIBE, I tried to take into account all three responsibilities of the commission: consumer protection, data protection, citizen safety. Because I don't have time, I want to take care of the first report and congratulate Daniela Aiuto. The Commission's proposal to amend the Directive is welcome for raising quality standards, but also for the mutual recognition of ship safety certificates. I support the report, the exceptions to the application of this directive are justified and I support them. The report clarifies the classification of maritime areas according to the risks to ships operating in a given area of ​​the sea. Because, as I said, I am also a member of the IMCO committee, I also looked at this report from the perspective of passenger protection. I believe that safety standards must be applied by all Member States. For specific local approaches, exempting ships from certain requirements, for example, requires the Member State to notify the Commission. Safety and living and working conditions on board are extremely important, and these three reports bring an improvement in safety and life, as well as work on board in the end.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Andriukaitis, today's debate is at a crucial moment for the maritime sector, since this year we are celebrating the European Maritime Year. This proposal concerns the need to maintain high safety standards for passenger ships in the Union and is the result of the Commission's assessment of the quality of existing legislation on the safety of passenger ships, including consultations with Member States and interested parts. Commissioner, this assessment has shown that certain ambiguities in the legal provisions have produced divergent readings by the national authorities and, therefore, this proposal proposes amendments to bridge these divergences. Ladies and gentlemen, the safety of passengers and crew must be the top priority and concern for all of us and, in particular, the Commission and the Member States. Commissioner, passengers and crew must feel safe and travel with confidence on board passenger vessels in the European Union. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur colleagues, especially Mrs Aiuto, for this report, which I believe will help to implement, monitor and apply the rules in the Member States and therefore contribute to maintaining a high level of global security and reforming the dimension social and labor force of maritime personnel on board ships.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, under the pretext of the safety of passengers traveling on passenger ships to and from European Union ports, the Council and Parliament have proposed that the current directive be amended. The proposal is to record passenger data electronically, ie digitally. It is a fact that security is a very important issue and we must approach it with care and responsibility. But security is not ensured by recording passenger data; it is ensured by using modern ships, boarding and disembarking passengers quickly and possibly having cameras in various parts of ships and ports. On the contrary, the digital recording of passengers' personal data carries the risk of being intercepted, processed by unauthorized or even criminals and used for illegal activities. For this very reason, I believe that the digital recording of passenger data serves only procedural purposes and is not particularly important so that we can pursue and accept it.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of Commissioner Bulc, I would like to thank the Parliament and, in particular, all three rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs for their work on these files and for their constructive approach which facilitated reaching an agreement with the Council. Thank you so much. On safety rules and standards, we are sending a clear signal to our citizens travelling on board passenger ships in EU waters that their safety is our priority. I wish to reiterate that the Commission’s services, with the assistance of the European Maritime Safety Agency, are currently focusing on developing guidelines for small passenger ships. We will also duly respond to the Parliament’s call to assess the need for common European requirements for sailing ships and ship carrier tenders. Concerning the legislation proposal, we are ensuring that the competent authorities have immediate access to accurate data on persons on board in case of emergency, and that they can therefore deal with any accident more effectively. I am sure that you will continue to fully support our efforts to further digitalise maritime transport and to enhance the single window for reporting formalities. This is where the Commission is committed to proposing revised legislation on reporting formalities by next April, which will establish a harmonised European maritime single window environment. The new rules on inspections will ensure that the respective regime brings value for money for all parties concerned. Besides the cost savings, it removes the unnecessary duplication and complexity of existing regimes, which had developed over time and resulted in overlapping requirements spread across different pieces of legislation. The new rules will facilitate implementation, monitoring and enforcement. I am sure that you will continue to fully support our efforts to further improve, simplify and modernise maritime legislation, and Commissioner Bulc looks forward to our future cooperation.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: rapporteur.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the Commissioner for his appreciation for the work he has done, the attestation of esteem and I also thank all my colleagues, even those who have rightly already left.This dossier, when it was voted on in committee, was almost unanimous and therefore, a bit from how the discussion has evolved and how things seem to go, I hope that tomorrow there will be a positive evolution because,indeed, the safety of European citizens is at stake and therefore I believe that the value of the excellent work done must be recognized.Thanks again to the other speakers of the two dossiers, because in any case we worked together and it was really a pleasure to work with two colleagues of this caliber.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: speaker. - Mr President, it is clear to us that these are three very important reports, but they must not have generated much enthusiasm in the Chamber. In any case, I am going to respond to the intervention of our colleague, who has spoken that the safety of ships is not achieved with the registry. Obviously, we are talking about a directive that is going to improve data collection so that search and rescue are effective in the event of an accident. Therefore, we have to focus the arguments on this directive and on this content. Regarding your fear, you were talking about the possible abuse that can be made of this information, I must tell you that Regulation (EU) 2016/679 is going to apply here - therefore, voted very recently by all of us - that talks about the protection of personal data and privacy. Furthermore, I, in my speech, have made a reference to the fact that the data will be eliminated, that is, all the information, when it is no longer necessary for the purposes for which it has been recovered. And it will be deleted automatically and without undue delay. Therefore, all the fears that you might have are covered in this report. Nothing more to say, apart from expressing my thanks to everyone. And one last message about the problem we always have: we have made the effort; I hope that tomorrow Parliament will indeed vote with a large majority, but what we need is for the Member States to comply with the directives within the deadlines set out, because this will contribute to the improvement and safety of the entire maritime sector.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: protractor. - Mr President, having the advantage and the honor of being the last speaker for this day's session, I would not like to abuse your patience, nor that of the Commission or of the many colleagues who are still attending the meeting. I just wanted to thank my colleagues and, as Mrs Aiuto said, it has been a pleasure and a joy to work together in an excellent spirit, in close collaboration with the Commission, and with a Council, that of the Maltese Presidency, which was particularly effective and which, I believe, insisted that we come to a conclusion under this Presidency. This report on the inspections of ro-ro ferries and ferries, as well as the entire package on the safety of passenger ships, reviewed as part of a REFIT, is a concrete illustration of the challenges posed by the maritime sector and shows how the institutions of the European Union respond to it, by protecting the citizens, which in my opinion is the most important thing. I think that tomorrow, ladies and gentlemen, we will have a massive vote on these three reports which will conclude this significant improvement in our security.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The joint debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.
